PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: AIDS Commercial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners request that the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health cause to cease immediately the broadcasting of any AIDS commercials which have as their premise that the use of condoms makes casual sexual activities acceptable particularly amongst young adolescents because of the detrimental effect which such campaigns have upon the morals of our society.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Commission: Education Broadcasts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
This petition of concerned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The Education Broadcasts of the Australian Broadcasting Commission is a service which is vital to the maintenance and improvement of educational standards throughout Australia;
The removal of these Broadcasts would severely disadvantage children and other students and their teachers, particularly in remote areas, causing an inequity of access to learning resources;
Cutbacks in funding of educational resources, both human and other, has already significantly hindered the potential of teachers and educators across the nation to improve educational standards;
There are no viable alternatives to obtain the kinds of resources currently broadcast by the Australian Broadcasting Commission.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
Protect and increase current funding for the Australian Broadcasting Commission to continue to broadcast and produce Education Broadcast material for schools throughout Australia;

Provide, protect and increase funding to the Australian Broadcasting Commission and to other production companies to produce material suitable for broadcast as part of the Australian Broadcasting Commission's Education Service.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Environmental Bill of Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate assembled:
The Humble Petition of certain Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth
That there is urgent need for the United Nations to adopt an Environmental Bill of Rights using the 1987 Report by the World Commission on Environment and Development.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament pass an `Environmental Bill of Rights', therefore giving Australia a leading role in environmental protection.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Conservation of Resources
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and senators in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows:

on 1 September 1989 the Australian Tax Office sought to discourage the recycling of glass bottles by imposing sales tax on the cost of reacquiring such bottles and on crating, classifying, storing, sorting, washing and cleaning them;

this will result in major beverage manufacturers abandoning the use of bottles in favour of plastic containers, which are made from valuable non-renewable and imported resources, and which are then thrown away to become waste;
furthermore, the Income Tax Assessment Act encourages businesses to throw away valuable equipment by allowing full write-offs only if the equipment is scrapped.
Your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled should take steps to amend tax laws:
(a) to encourage the conservation of resources rather than the throwing-away of resources;
(b) so that no sales tax is payable on any recycled or re-used components;
(c) so that a penal sales tax in the form of a waste tax is imposed on all throw-away products.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Leader and members of the Senate of Australia, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that the Governor of Victoria has set aside 219 hectares of Reserved Forest in the Apollo Bay water catchment forest to be the West Barham Big Trees Flora Reserve.
We humbly pray that you consider protecting a larger area of the Otways from logging by listing it as National Estate forest so that botanical, water and tourist values may be preserved.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that notice of motion No. 94 standing in my name be taken as formal.
—Is there any objection to this motion being taken as formal?
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) and pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to General Business notice of motion No. 94 standing in the name of Senator Tambling relating to certain documents of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

This matter should be dealt with urgently by the Senate. It is a matter that was subject to some debate on another agenda item and issue yesterday and requires, importantly, information to be tabled for the further consideration of the Senate. The substantive matter is important and I do not anticipate that it would take very much time to be dealt with by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like to indicate that the Australian Democrats support the suspension of Standing Orders as we believe the issue needs to be debated.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tambling for Senator Hill) agreed to:

That General Business notice of motion No. 94 standing in the name of Senator Tambling for this day and relating to certain documents of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission be called on forthwith and have precedence over all other business till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That there be laid on the Table of the Senate on or before 13 November 1990 all documents relating to:
(a) the making of Regional Council Electoral Rules under section 113 and a notice under sections 116 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989;
(b) representations made and advice given to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on the making and content of those instruments and his responses;

(c) in the course of the making of the rules, details of consideration given, and conclusions reached, in relation to the matters raised in the Senate during debate on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill (Senate Hansard, 6 October 1989, pp.1807ff.), whether that consideration was given by the Minister or by those advising him; and

(d) the circumstances surrounding the Minister's failure to observe the requirements of section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 to table the instruments under sections 113 and 116, including any report or reports received by him from officials.

The issue was canvassed yesterday when certain regulations were tabled in this place and there was quite considerable debate. The information that is sought under this particular motion is most important for the consideration of the Senate. Honourable senators will be well aware that there was a court challenge last week prior to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission election, and it is very important to establish that all of the requirements have been met.

Each of the points of my motion seek specific information. In particular (a) and (b), the making of rules and the representations received, of course, would give a very important indication about the extent to which advice was given to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs with regard to the ability of Aboriginal and Torres Strait island people to vote whether or not they were on the electoral roll. Point (c) of my motion seeks to establish that the Minister did take into account the considerations that were importantly put down by this Senate, and in particular by Senator Coulter on 6 October last year when certain information was established. That should of course be re-established before this Senate. Finally, with regard to point (d) of the motion, it is important to establish the circumstances with regard to this issue and particularly the details that were made available to the Minister in reports received by him from the officials. These are important issues and should be canvassed. In the debate yesterday the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner), said:
I personally would have no difficulty in acceding to Senator Tambling's notice of motion and tabling the documentation I have read.

I think that was a very important concession on the part of Senator Collins and the Government in acknowledging that there would be no withholding by the Government of any information sought by the intent of my motion. As I mentioned yesterday, it was unfortunate that Senator Tate took a stance different from that taken by Senator Collins-and an intimidatory one-when he said that we would certainly not get leave today for this motion and that that would, by his choice, be a matter of my choice. That was an unfortunate issue and obviously Senator Tate has the numbers over Senator Collins, because that is the way in which the Government unfortunately chose to proceed with this matter this morning. It was totally unnecessary. The information that is sought should be fully available. There should be no constraint with regard to the access of this Senate.

We saw a press statement yesterday by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs relating to this matter in which he tabled advice from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission where ATSIC is claiming that it is the guilty party. Unfortunately, once again, an officer of ATSIC, Mr Michael Stewart, was named in those statements as the scapegoat. Members of the Senate will remember that Mr Stewart was the officer connected with all of the lack of information and poor advice with regard to the Aboriginal Development Commission and so many other issues relating to the past inquiries of the Senate. I find it very unfortunate that the Minister has chosen to hide behind the officers of ATSIC in this manner. The information sought in my motion is a most important consideration of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move an amendment to the motion in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit all words after ``that'', substitute ``there be laid on the Table of the Senate, on or before 13 November 1990, all relevant and essential documents relating to establishing:

(a) the circumstances surrounding the failure to observe the requirements of section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 to table the instruments under sections 113 and 116 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989; and
(b) the legality of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission elections held on Saturday, 3 November 1990''.

My amendment maintains the thrust of Senator Tambling's motion, which is the procurement of certain documents. It defines what the Australian Democrats believe are the necessary and essential documents for this debate, they being those documents which are related to, firstly, the failure to table the rules before the elections were held and, secondly, the consequent legality of the elections held on Saturday, 3 November.

The Democrats believe this should be the subject of the debate. It should not be an opportunity for any indirect redebating of the whole Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) Bill. We share the Opposition's view that there has been an appalling lapse in administrative procedure. An examination of the relevant and essential documents will enable the Senate to come to conclusions as to the detail. The tabling yesterday of the Torres Strait Regional Council rules was against the spirit and the expectation of the whole ATSIC legislation, but in the narrow sense it was technically sound in that the rules were tabled on the last day before the time limit expired. It is deplorable that the other rules were not tabled at all. However, it is true that the rules were used in the election and that the court has already recognised that.

Senator Coulter and I have seen the rules, particularly those relating to the filling of casual vacancies in which Senator Coulter expressed a specific interest during the committee stage of the debate. We have no objection to the rules we have seen. In fact, I place on record that we would not have voted to disallow those rules which were not tabled and we will not vote to disallow those rules that were tabled yesterday. We are committed to ATSIC and to the important role it will play in the future of Aboriginal Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —With some degree of appreciation for the speeches of both previous speakers, Senator Tambling and Senator Kernot, I will also be very brief in this debate. The issues were canvassed yesterday. First of all, in defence of my colleague Senator Tate, reference to the Hansard record yesterday-I was here yesterday during the debate-will show quite clearly that he did not attempt, as Senator Tambling suggested, to intimidate anyone. I could not think of anyone in this chamber less likely than Michael Tate to want to intimidate anyone. I have said to him on a number of occasions in the past 3 1/2 years that I wish he would be a tad more intimidatory towards the Opposition than he is. He is one of the gentlemen of this chamber. I reject Senator Tambling's accusation against him categorically.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tambling also said that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner)-I guess it was expected that the Opposition would say this-was trying to hide behind officers of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and absolve himself of the blame. I point out to the Senate the basis for Senator Tambling saying that was his `perusal of the papers' which I promptly and immediately tabled in this chamber yesterday.

They were the papers available to me. I had them and I tabled them. I had a meeting with the Minister last night and I can assure the Senate that the Minister will have no difficulty in complying with the Australian Democrats amendment, which the Government intends to support, and in tabling the papers required by that amendment.

I would advise the Senate that we will not have to wait until 13 November. I was hoping to have had the papers here this morning to table at the conclusion of this debate. As this debate will thankfully be short, that will not be possible. But I do expect to have the papers today. If I have them today, then I will be tabling them in the Senate today. There is no difficulty with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —But we were promised them before the election.

—As I said yesterday, and without wanting to repeat it, the Government and the Minister deeply regret what was an inadvertent administrative problem that caused this. It should not have happened; it did happen. Corrective measures are being put into place right now in ATSIC to make sure that it never happens again, but it did happen.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a little cute of Senator Tambling to accuse the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs of attempting to hide behind an officer of ATSIC on the basis of material which I freely and happily tabled in the Senate yesterday in compliance with what Senator Tambling wanted. The Minister in the chamber at the time having immediately tabled the papers that he had, it is a bit rich for Senator Tambling then to say, as a result of reading of the papers, that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is trying to hide behind ATSIC officers.

What the papers demonstrate, as Senator Tambling knows, is that the Minister scrupulously inquired of ATSIC well before this problem occurred-that is, in September-whether all the necessary and required procedural matters had been attended to by the officers of ATSIC in relation to the tabling of documents in both the House of Representatives and the Senate. He received a categorical written response-not prepared, as Senator Tambling would suggest, as a put up job for the purpose of extracting the Minister from some difficulty in this debate, but a piece of correspondence dated 19 September last-which gave the Minister a categorical assurance, and some detail: 400 copies of the rules were brought to this Parliament and no doubt languished in a room somewhere. They were deemed to have been tabled in the House of Representatives, but because of a foul-up, which is detailed in the second document that I tabled in the House yesterday, that did not happen, despite written advice to the Minister that it had.

Is anyone in this chamber seriously suggesting-I do not think that anyone could with a straight face-that one would expect the Minister personally to carry 400 copies of the rules down to the Senate Table Office and say, `Here they are, I am required to do this to make absolutely certain that my responsibilities are discharged and that rules are tabled in the Senate'? That would be a ridiculous assertion to make. The Minister did what he was required to do. He made a specific request for advice as to whether the procedures had been dealt with by ATSIC officers, and I regret to say that on this occasion they clearly failed him. He could not have been expected to do any more.

I conclude by repeating what I said a few minutes ago. The Government will comply, to the extent possible, with the amendment that has been moved in the Senate today. When I say that the Government will comply with this in so far as it can, I would point out one of the difficulties that may be raised. I put this in as pure speculation on my part at this stage, considering the speed with which this debate has proceeded; I know that all senators will appreciate this, as it is always a problem with parliaments and privilege. One difficulty is that there are very serious legal proceedings in train currently in the Federal Court in regard to this matter.

The Commonwealth will be a party to those proceedings. It would be improper of me to attempt to canvass any opinion on those proceedings, and I do not, but I simply state to the Senate as a matter of fact that the Commonwealth's position during those proceedings will be that the elections were valid and can continue to be held by the court as valid. For that reason it may well be that there are documents relating to confidential legal advice which has been given to the Minister in relation to the proceedings that are now on foot in the Federal Court that could not be tabled and therefore made public for obvious reasons. I am simply canvassing that as a problem that has come across my purview a number of times during the time I have been in Parliament and that may well be the only difficulty that arises.

I say again: I have seen a comprehensive range of papers providing written advice to the Minister confirming that all the procedures that the Minister was inquiring about had been adhered to, and I know that there will not be the slightest difficulty in disclosing them. The one area that may be difficult, considering the fact that these proceedings are on foot as I speak and considering the position that the Commonwealth will be taking in the Federal Court, is the sensitivity of some of the legal opinions that have been provided for the Government in relation to that specific matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak only briefly on this matter. I remind those honourable senators who were here before the last election that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation probably received more attention in this chamber than any other piece of legislation throughout history. My memory does not go back beyond 1987, but I remind the Senate that we sent that legislation to the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, which sat for six months. It was then debated in this chamber for, I think, 41 hours in the second reading and committee stages, and it received a very thorough review.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have to agree with the Opposition to the extent that one matter in great contention through both the Senate Select Committee considerations and the considerations which surrounded the debate in the chamber was the processes of election for the regional councils. I would also have to agree with members of the Opposition that a great deal of care went into the debate in relation to the tabling of rules for the elections. They have correctly quoted the Minister who was then in the chamber, Minister Tate, with respect to undertakings that were given concerning the tabling of those rules.

I have to add my voice of beration to the Government and to officers who were evidently responsible for those undertakings not being fulfilled. Undoubtedly, the spirit which lies behind the tabling and the period for disallowance has not been met in this case, and those responsible for the failure of that mechanism to be observed deserve the very strongest condemnation of this chamber.

Having said that, I must return to the two points that my colleague Senator Kernot has made; that is, that there are two important issues at stake here-and not the wide ranging issues which could be opened by Senator Tambling's original motion. Those issues are, firstly, the circumstances surrounding the failure to table those documents and, secondly, whether the elections which were held on Saturday last were legal. The effect of the Australian Democrats' amendment is to confine the investigation to those two matters and to bring forward the documents and evidence which are relevant to those two matters so that the Senate can be satisfied in the first instance that this failure to table documents will not be repeated as far as that is preventable and, secondly, that the very important elections which were held last Saturday were or were not legal.

While accepting that the failure to table was against the spirit of the process for tabling and for disallowance, nonetheless it is my understanding that, to the extent that legal opinions are available at this stage, the technical requirement has been met. I find that unsatisfactory, but it does bear very much on the second issue which relates to the legality of the elections. As Senator Boswell and Senator Collins have pointed out, it is in the hands of the court at present.

I conclude by saying that both Senator Kernot and I have had the opportunity to look at the rules. We would certainly not have disallowed those rules had they been available. To that extent, in our view, the elections are legitimate in that they have properly elected those members of the Aboriginal communities which elect regional councils. Although in a sense it has an element of retrospectivity about it, in that we are now entering the period for disallowance, we must put it firmly on the record that we would not seek in any way to disallow the regulations and we would seek to support the legality of those elections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I propose to move a minor amendment and will speak to it very briefly. The reason I sought the leave of the Senate to do so is that I know Senator Tambling wishes to speak to his motion and it will give him an opportunity to comment on what I propose. A few minutes ago I canvassed the essential matter that must be adhered to, and always adhered to, and that is to maintain the correct separation between this Parliament and the courts of Australia. The legality of the elections-I am sure the Australian Democrats and the Opposition have no argument with this-is a matter that will be determined by the Federal Court in the very near future. Certainly it is not for this chamber to attempt to pretry that issue. For that reason, and to allow the Minister to be as comprehensive as he can be in terms of tabling documents, and to relieve him of this legal difficulty in terms of the privilege of this Parliament and the proper role of the courts, I propose to add an amendment to the Democrat amendment after paragraph 2. Therefore, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of proposed amendment add ``, but excluding documents relating to legal advice regarding the issues which are currently before the courts''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Until now I had intended to vote for the amendment, but the amendment moved by Senator Collins appears to gut the Australian Democrats' amendment. It will not provide the information that the Senate requires as indicated in Senator Tambling's motion. I understand the point that was made by Senator Kernot that the Senate has had the debate on the establishment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), that this is not the appropriate forum to reopen that debate at this time, and that if the debate is to be reopened it ought to be done by way of some substantive motion, but there are matters about which the Senate needs further information and I would certainly like to have that further information.

SPEECH.PARA: As a member of the Senate, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and the subcommittee which inquired into the ATSIC elections, I would like to have this information. In my view, the material now proposed to be excluded is quite vital. Honourable senators are entitled to receive that material. It is appropriate that the Government see its way clear to tabling those documents so that honourable senators can examine them to see just where we are in this whole area of ATSIC elections.

I do not want-and I do not intend-to canvass the matters that were included in the debate last evening. I think that the debate that has proceeded today has been on a rather more reasoned level than that of yesterday. But Senator Collins, by excluding the particular documents that he referred to, is denying the Senate material and documents to which I believe it is entitled.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I will be brief. The fact is that Senator Harradine's proposition, as attractive as it might sound, is really outrageous. There is an action currently in the Federal Court on appeal relating to this issue. The Commonwealth is a party to that process. Senator Harradine is suggesting that specific legal advice that has been provided to one of the parties in that action be tabled and made public in this Parliament. It really is an outrageous suggestion.

—by leave-Neither I nor any other member of the Senate should be excluded from our entitlement to receive documents upon which we want to make decisions. I do not accept that just because those documents may have some relevance to some court case taking place somewhere they should be denied to the Senate. The Government could use that argument on any occasion. Some sort of court case is always being carried out somewhere. All we are asking is that the documents be tabled in the Senate. It is ludicrous that Senator Collins should refuse to table material to which the Senate is entitled just because that material is in some file of some lawyer who is happening to carry a case before the courts.

—In due course I will speak to Senator Kernot's amendment but at this point I shall address only the proposed amendment by Senator Collins relating to those matters of the legal documentation that he has introduced at a very late stage of this debate. We share the reservation that it is unnecessary to add this clause to the motion. The matters relating to the action before the court and the matters attracting privilege and appropriate legal advice would of course be dealt with in the normal way. We ought not in any way to be constraining the proper advices and information that should be available to the Senate. We are not in favour of the amendment moved by Senator Collins.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply point out that the amendment proposed by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) is directly contrary to the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. It really takes away the thrust of the second item of the Democrats' amendment and it means that there is nothing left for the Government to table concerning the legality of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission election which was held on Saturday, 3 November, which is what the Democrats sought in their amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot see why this Parliament is not entitled to the advices. There is no particular secrecy about the advices. They are advices on matters of technical law. They are general advices about these things in which we are interested and they go to the whole thrust of the information that we want and that the Democrats want, in a more restricted way. I think they should dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) has put forward a very reasonable amendment. As I read it, the very terms indicate what is sought to be excluded. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . but excluding documents relating to legal advice regarding the issues which are currently before the courts.

As Senator Macdonald would know and as the Australian Democrats know, as indeed does everybody else, if a case is being conducted before a court it is proper that the parties to that particular action be able to communicate with their legal advisers and get such advice as would help them to forward that case. It is now a tradition that is well and truly embedded in the law that neither side should have to give up those documents and that advice which is pertinent to the action that is taking place. That rule is there so that the court can consider properly the various submissions that are put before it and so that it can go forward without being straddled by outside opinions, particularly opinions from a place such as this which is-and I use the word in its truest and most proper sense-an august body. I consider the Senate to be one of the best bodies that there is, but the opinion of that body should not affect the deliberations of the court.

I suppose that it is really a problem related to the separation of powers. We, as a society, have said that the courts are the appropriate bodies to decide a dispute between two parties. Constitutionally, I think the Senate has a right to have documents if it so desires, but as a matter of propriety and convention it is proper that this chamber does not try to override or affect-it does not even have to be a conscious attempt-the proper resolution of the courts concerning a particular matter.

In the middle of this brilliant speech in which I am defending the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins)-in fact, I was going to sway the Senate and I think everybody was going to vote, on the basis of my speech, for all that I was arguing for-I have received a message from the Minister, whom may I say that I have rushed in here at some cost to defend, which says, `Good speech'. That is a comment with which I agree entirely; but the message continues, `but I am going to withdraw the amendment'.

Let me tell a little story and then I will sit down. During the time when Mr Lionel Bowen, the Attorney-General as he then was-a great attorney and a great friend of mine-was trying to get a Bill of Rights through the Parliament, I was down in Hamilton, the territory where Mr Fraser used to be, addressing an audience of about 500. I thought I was going very well putting forward the absolute necessity of having a Bill of Rights, and how this country would fall apart unless the Bill of Rights was got through.

It was not altogether a friendly audience, because it was Mr Fraser's home territory, but I thought they gave me a good hearing. I thought that on that occasion I was persuading the audience, too. The only thing was that my opponent on that occasion, Mr Spender, who was the shadow Attorney-General, got up at the end of my rather brilliant speech and said to the audience, `That was quite a brilliant speech from Senator Cooney, but the only thing that concerns me is that, if the various principles that he has fought so hard for, said he would go to the wall for and, indeed, suffer martyrdom for-those great concepts which are set out in this Bill and which I oppose but which have been very adequately vindicated by Senator Cooney tonight-are as good as he says, why has the Attorney-General withdrawn the Bill?'. Apparently, he had done that just before I made the speech and it came over on the news. I thanked Mr Bowen, the Attorney-General, with a certain tone to my voice, and I use the same tone on this occasion to Senator Collins.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I withdraw the amendment. I do not resile-neither, I know, does Senator Cooney-from the points that I made about the proper distinction that should be drawn between the Senate and the courts, but I am a realist. I do want to save the Senate time, and I do not want to waste its time with divisions or anything else. The Australian Democrats have advised me that they are not prepared to support this amendment and in the light of that I withdraw it.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed amendment-by leave-withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Minister Collins, I will be brief to try to get this matter finalised. We are now back to discussing the amendment moved by Senator Kernot. While it, in effect, removes the first three tenets of my original motion, I must express my disappointment that the Australian Democrats have chosen to walk away from seeking the additional information that should and quite properly would have added considerably to the pursuit of this information that is required by the Senate. Particularly in light of the previously strong investigatory role that the Democrats have always taken on this matter, I would have hoped that they would have been more open to have sought those particular advices, representations and reports that would have flowed through to the Minister and that would have given us more information.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to note, as Senator Coulter said, that very solemn undertakings were given by Minister Tate last year on this matter which now have not been honoured either by Senator Collins or by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Tickner. I only hope that, in reaching the conclusion of this matter that will now arise as a result of Senator Kernot's amendment, there has not, in fact, been any collusion between the Democrats and the Minister or the Government on this matter. I am disappointed that very obviously Minister Collins and the Government are not keen to table a number of the additional papers which we sought and which, as a result of the amendment of the Democrats, will not now be available for the perusal of the Senate, but we will certainly be supporting the amendment.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT (SUBSTANTIATION REQUIREMENTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Watson) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to clarify the substantiation requirements of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.
Motion (by Senator Watson) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr President, this private members bill has arisen as a result of severe criticism of the substantiation provisions of Subdivision F of the Income Tax Assessment Act by a former senior member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, Mr Peter Roach in case W124 (89 A.T.C.975).

The Bill will amend the substantiation provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, so as to introduce a greater degree of fairness and common sense in the enforcement of the substantiation requirements of the Act regarding the provision of written evidence of claims for expenses.

Members of both Houses of Parliament and representing both the Opposition and the Government who attended a parliamentary seminar on substantiation conducted by the Australian Taxation Office became aware how vulnerable they, and other members of the community could be when facing a tax audit.

This Bill will amend the substantiation provision of the Tax Assessment Act 1936, Subdivision F, (substantiation of certain expenses) Division 3, Part III, by adding another subsection 82kt (7) as follows:
After subsection 82rt (6) of the Principal Act the following subsection is inserted:
``CLARIFICATION 0F THE SUBSTANTIATION REQUIREMENT''

Notwithstanding failure to satisfy and comply with the provisions of this subdivision the Commissioner may allow deductions claimed notwithstanding such non-compliance if the Commissioner is satisfied that, having regard to all the circumstances, it would be reasonable to allow the deduction.''
This new subsection has the purpose of providing the Commissioner of Taxation a discretion to apply the substantiation provisions with fairness and common sense.

Although I am generally opposed to `discretions' as being incompatible with the new system of self-assessment, the ``discretionary'' aspect of the Bill is tightly drawn and it is stated in simple terms to ensure its passage through this Chamber.
In no way have we attempted to weaken the general thrust of the substantiation requirements. The Bill is here to ensure justice and equity.
There are two basic reasons for the need for this Bill. One, the substantiation provisions are too strict and have resulted in cases of injustice.

Secondly, the ATO has already recognised the problem and has declared that in the future, the substantiation provisions will be applied with ``common sense''. It is the interpretation of this view that troubles me.

If it means that the Commissioner will enforce the ``Substantiation provisions in accordance with the terms laid down by the Parliament then, so far as the Commissioner is concerned, there is no problem.

It is the Commissioner's duty to enforce the Act as laid down by the Parliament and interpreted by the Courts. Therefore, the Commissioner will need to continue to administer the Act as in the past, penalising in many instances honest taxpayers.
Consequently, the need for this Amendment, to give the Commissioner the legal basis to give relief to honest taxpayers.

Further, if we do not give the Commissioner this legal basis and he proceeds to apply the present law with ``common sense'', in these instances the Commissioner will be placing himself above the Parliament.
Taxpayers will then not be able to ascertain what the law is or be sure that it will, or will not be, enforced in accordance with that other standard.
The Commissioner, in applying ``common sense'' to the present law, will be giving himself a privilege of deciding whether or not to enforce the laws enacted by the Parliament.

The significance of the point can be seen when considering the position in the cited case-W124. Clearly, in that case the Administrative Appeals Tribunal was of the mind that, for the precise prescriptions enacted by the Parliament and the failure of the Taxpayer concerned to comply with them, he would have been entitled to the Income tax deductions claimed.

But, as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is obliged to apply the law as enacted by the Parliament and interpreted by the Courts, it did not have the authority to grant the relief which, but for those prescriptions, it might have thought appropriate.
In reaching that decision, the Tribunal had available to it to be exercised all the powers conferred by the Parliament on the Commissioner.
Now it seems that the Commissioner claims the power not to enforce the law when it suits him to do so, yet the Tribunal, acting in his place, does not have the same authority.

To remedy this injustice, I have proposed by this Bill to grant to the Commissioner a discretion to grant relief from the strict enforcement of what would otherwise be the law. Parliament thus remains the final lawmaker.
Now, to go back to my first reason, the substantiation provisions of Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, Sub-division F, are far too strict and have resulted in cases of injustice.
The comments made when the decision which was handed down in favour of Australian Tax Office in the Evangelist's Case W124 demonstrates the absurdity of the position.

The distinguishing feature of Subdivision F is that it requires in relation to certain expenses not only that the taxpayer should satisfy the substantive requirements of other provisions of the Act, (such as Section 51) and bear the burden of proving his claim in so doing (Section 190 (b)), but also that the evidence to be relied on in support of his claim must be in specific form.

The substantiation provisions have been enacted in terms which emphasise form above substance. They tend to concentrate the attention of those required to enforce the rules on question of forms and to distract attention from the more basic question as to whether what is represented on the forms is true, in the sense of being both honestly stated and accurate.

Thus, we have the situation in this case of the church worker who, because he did not sign each entry in his motor vehicle log book, even though all entries were dated and in his own handwriting, the expenses claimed were not allowed.

The Administrative Appeals Tribunal was satisfied with the genuineness and accuracy of the claim. In pursuing this case several more examples of this kind occur. The effect of the substantiation provisions were to deny deductions to which otherwise the taxpayer would be entitled.

It is therefore the duty of this Parliament to provide a more appropriate set of requirements as to``substantiation'' of claims honestly made and a more just procedure on a matter of substantial importance to a very large number of citizens, including the honourable members seated in this chamber.

I would like to remind the Chamber that this amendment does not relieve a taxpayer of any obligations to meet the substantiation requirements. They must still establish that ``having regard to all the circumstances'' some non-compliance should be excused.
Therefore, I see the need for the amendment proposed and I, therefore commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Cook) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Vallentine) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act relating to conscientious objection to certain Defence service.
Motion (by Senator Vallentine) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

An earlier version of this Bill was drawn up by Senator Michael Tate-An Act to amend the Defence Act 1982-relating to conscientious objector status for conscripts to the Australian Defence Force. It was considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Conscientious and Legal Affairs in 1985, since when it has apparently dropped into a legislative black hole.
However the Bill I am presenting today is an entirely new piece of legislation and not an attempt to amend any other Act.

Following the experience of the Vietnam War, there was an urgent need to clarify the status of conscientious objectors to conscripted military service and to put into legislation some ruling on their rights for future reference.

I doubt if many honourable senators will object to this procedure apart from those who believe that no-one should be exempt from compulsory military service as with young men in Israel, Iraq or China, for example.

However, since the time of Vietnam there has been an increasing tendency for young men who have joined the military as volunteers to feel that while they are prepared to fight and die to defend their country, they are not prepared to go and fight in some other country's war.

Recent examples include resisters to the Vietnam War, who included conscripts in Australia's case, the British resisters in Northern Ireland, white resisters in South Africa sent to Angola, Namibia and the Black townships in South Africa itself, and now resisters to the Gulf deployment.
We should also remember the 120 Iraqi officers who were shot on 3 August for refusing to take part in the invasion of Kuwait.
There are those senators who would argue that sending troops to the Gulf involves the defence of Australia in a wider sense but I want to question this for a couple of reasons.
First of all, it was the Prime Minister who volunteered to send ships to join the US blockade. The UN certainly did not invite us to join and there was obviously no direct threat to Australia.
In fact it was a very selective choice because there have been other examples of invasion and occupation in the last decade which the world, including Australia, chose to ignore.

I refer, for example, to Soviet interventionism during the Brezhnev era, to French intervention in Africa to prop up discredited dictators, to US interventionism in Grenada and Panama, and the Indonesian invasion of East Timor.
The hypocrisy of this selective choice for national outrage, extending even to a military response, is staggering.
Secondly, if you consider the Dibb Report and the 1987 Defence White Paper which outlined Australia's area of defence interest, the Gulf falls clearly outside the region delineated.
It is therefore not surprising that Terry Jones and other sailors chose to question their orders to go to the Gulf, just as a number of US military personnel have chosen to ask the same questions.
The Navy might say that this is a matter of discipline but I would rather commend such individuals for making considered decisions rather than for blind obedience to orders.

If we are to have a volunteer army, the military will have to face increasing numbers of young men and young women who will say that while they are prepared to defend their country, they are not prepared to go off to the Gulf or other parts of the world because of some foreign policy dictate that is dangerously reminiscent of the days of the Boer War, Gallipoli and Vietnam.

It was only this April, on the occasion of the 75th commemoration of the ANZAC sacrifice, that Mr Hawke said that this country would not be sending any more young Australians off to die on a foreign shore but that is what might happen in the Gulf, if war breaks out.

We may choose to support the US blockade for what some Australians would consider very good reasons, but those who agree with the decision to send the ships must ask themselves why the Australian Government, with the support of the Opposition, chose to support this military action and did not intervene, say, when Iraq invaded Iran in 1980?

And why, in 1975, did the Australian Government remain silent when Indonesia invaded East Timor? This omission, in our region, was, and remains, unpardonable. We refused to lift even a diplomatic finger to challenge the Indonesian occupation of sovereign territory.

This Bill seeks to take note of this changing situation and thus ensure that military personnel who have a selective objection to a particular war beyond our shores, have the right to opt out of a particular operation.
The Bill applies to volunteers as well as conscripts, should the question of conscription arise again in future.
The nature of the military has changed markedly in the last generation.
In Europe, where there are still largely conscript armies, there are now trade unions for soldiers.
Alternative service for conscientious objectors is now widely recognised, at least in most of Europe.

In the United States, conscientious objector status has been available to military service volunteers and not just conscripts since 1962 but only if they became absolute pacifists after entry to military service.

An average of about 1,000 men and women per year have a change of heart after enlistment and apply for conscientious objector status. Conscientious objectors discharged from the military are not permitted to re-enlist, but retain their rights to any post-service benefits to which they would otherwise be entitled. They are granted honourable discharges, and no penalty is attached to their stand.
The nature of war has also changed in recent times. Only 15 per cent of the 130 or so wars fought since 1945 have consisted of one country invading another.

It is therefore hardly surprising that there are service personnel who, while prepared to defend their country from attack, are not prepared to participate in operations that are an extension of foreign policy rather than to counter an attack on national sovereignty.

Obviously for the sake of army morale, it is preferable to have troops who accept what they are told to do, rather than to face internal resentment, as the United States military did in Vietnam or the Soviet Union faced in Afghanistan from 1979 or in Czechoslovakia in 1968. Another unacceptable alternative is open dissent within the ranks during operations.
From the military point of view surely it is better to have a clear-cut way of dealing with dissenters, rather than having discontent festering within the ranks and infecting other service personnel.

It is for these reasons that I choose to introduce this Bill, because I feel that we must recognise the conscientious right of thoughtful individuals who question military operations which do not involve a direct threat to their country.

It is not a question of lack of discipline. It is an issue of selective objection. It will not undermine the Australian Defence Force because I doubt if many serving military personnel will feel the need to avail themselves of it, but we should recognise the right of those who choose to do so.
A hypothetical example from our multi-racial society might include a young Moslem heading for the Gulf who decides that he cannot in all conscience take part in a war against his co-religionists.

This Bill would give the RAN and other branches of the ADF the opportunity to clarify their positions regarding objectors. It was particularly odious to former Leading Seaman Terry Jones to hear the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, claim that deployment to the Gulf was voluntary. This was not the case in his experience.
As his defence lawyer, Michael Adams QC, pointed out, the Navy had some responsibility for Jones's decision to go AWOL as there had been a flaw in Navy leadership.
The Navy should have made it clear that he could apply to be transferred out of the Gulf task force.
Had the Commanding Officer of HMAS Adelaide been aware of what Leading Seaman Jones had said, it would have been sensible for him to have arranged a transfer.

The Australian Defence Force has a responsibility to make it clear to ADF personnel whether a particular task force is for volunteers or not and to tell those personnel the criteria on which they could be transferred.
In his testament to the military tribunal Michael Adams QC claimed that none of this occurred.
It is also important to understand that such a decision would not be taken lightly. It was an emotionally expensive exercise as Terry Jones found.
Neither was it a matter of cowardice, but clearly one of conscience, as he stated at the time:

I am prepared to die to defend my country but not to protect United States oil lines. The largest insult I felt personally in the whole affair was turning on the television last Tuesday night and seeing Mr Bush on the international media refusing to discuss what negotiations were going on (over Iraq) while he was on holidays.

Up until this point I had no intention of jumping ship but after seeing one of the parties responsible for it all on holidays playing golf while committing thousands of young lives, including those of Australians-it was enough for me to decide not to be part of the killing, knowing that I might have killed innocent people for nothing.
I am not a coward and I would be prepared to die for my country but I am taking a political stand because this is not our war-we are just following the Americans.

I believe that most serving military personnel would not choose to question their orders, even in a situation where they are going to a place which they had never heard of before, like the British going to the Falklands or the Americans who went to Vietnam.
But I am concerned about the small minority who do have a conscientious objection or a selective objection and it is for their sake that I ask you to support this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Cook) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: EUROPEAN BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

One of the most dramatic developments in the history of the second half of the twentieth century has been the recent rejection by the countries of Central and Eastern Europe of the communist political and economic system. In rapid succession, and within an astonishingly short period, the countries of this region have set off on a new course based on the adoption of parliamentary democracy, political pluralism and more market oriented economies.

This momentous change in direction brings enormous potential benefits for the future development of Europe, for global peace and for improvements in the lives of the citizens of the countries involved. By its example it should also encourage further reform in many other countries around the world that are currently subject to autocratic political and centralised economic systems.

At a meeting of heads of Government of the European Community held in Strasbourg in December last year, an agreement was reached in principle to establish, as soon as possible, a new Bank to assist in the reconstruction and development of Central and Eastern Europe.

Preparatory work began immediately, with participation by not only European countries, but also a number of others from outside the region, including the United States, Japan, Canada, the republic of Korea, Australia and New Zealand. After intensive effort, on the twenty-ninth of May last, forty-two prospective members, including Australia, signed the articles of agreement to found a new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to be located in London.

Under the agreement, the purpose of the Bank is to foster the transition towards open market oriented economies and to promote private and entrepreneurial initiative in Central and Eastern European countries committed to and applying the principles of multiparty democracy, pluralism and market economics. The Bank will assist recipient member countries to implement structural and sectoral economic reforms, including demonopolisation, decentralisation and privatisation, to help their economies become fully integrated into the international economy. The bulk of the Bank's activities will be directed to the private sector and to assist the privatisation of state-owned enterprises: the articles provide that not more than 40 per cent of the Bank's financing shall be provided to the State sector.

Membership of the Bank is open to European countries, other countries that are members of the International Monetary Fund, the European Community and the European Investment Bank. In recognition of its European character, a majority of the capital will be held by the European Community members and institutions as a financial institution, the Bank will be able to invest in recipient countries in a variety of ways. It will be able to take a direct equity stake in private enterprises and in state-owned enterprises that are operating competitively or in transition to private ownership and control. It will also facilitate access by such enterprises to domestic and international capital markets and, where other means of financing are not appropriate, underwrite the issue of securities. This sort of operation carries greater risk than straightforward lending: careful assessment and management of operations will therefore be essential.

The Bank will also make loans to enterprises either on its own account or through cofinancing with multilateral institutions, commercial Banks and other sources. It will also provide technical assistance for the reconstruction and development of infrastructure, including environmental programs necessary for private sector development.

The Bank will not lend to Governments to support programs of economic adjustment, such as to finance balance of payments deficits. This will remain the preserve of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, both of which are of course already very active in assistance for Central and Eastern European Countries. Another feature of the articles is the explicit commitment given to environmental improvement. Tackling the sad environmental legacy of central planning is an urgent task in all the countries of Central and Eastern Europe. The Bank will be obliged to promote environmentally sound and sustainable development in all of its activities and it will report every year on the environmental impact of its operations.

The Bank's operations will be limited to countries which are applying the principles in the agreement and are proceeding steadily in the transition towards market oriented economies and the promotion of private and entrepreneurial initiative. Progress in each country in this regard will be reviewed by the Bank's board of Directors at least once a year. Recipient member countries under the agreement are Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Poland, Romania, the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia. Concern was expressed that because of its size the Soviet Union might become the principal recipient of credits, reducing the Bank's capacity to assist other countries. It was therefore agreed that, at least for the first three years, the Soviet Union will be eligible for loans only up to the level of its paid in capital.
The Bank will have a capital base of ECU 10 billion (approximately $A15 billion) divided into paid-in shares of ECU 3 billion and callable shares of ECU7 billion.

The callable capital will provide backing for borrowings by the bank in international financial markets. Lending by the Bank will not be subsidised, but the backing provided by the Bank's callable capital, together with sound operating policies, should allow it to lend on favourable terms.

Australia has been allocated 1 per cent of the total shares. The paid in cost of Australian membership will be ECU30 million (approximately $A45 million), payable in equal instalments of approximately $A9 million a year over a five year period.

This Bill will provide authority for the payment of Australia's subscription to the initial authorised capital stock of the bank. Its passage will allow Australia to proceed with its membership and ratify the agreement. The detailed articles of agreement are set out as a schedule to the bill. Australian membership of the bank will provide access to information about opportunities for procurement and other financial and commercial activities in Central and Eastern Europe. It will also provide an Australian voice in important aspects of the reform process through the Bank's policy dialogue with its borrowing members.

But more importantly, Australian participation in the Bank will demonstrate our support for the political and economic changes that are occurring in Central and Eastern Europe. A democratic and prosperous Europe is desirable in the long term interest both of Australia and of the world.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the related explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter relating to anti-dumping and countervailing legislation be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology for urgent investigation and report by 31 March 1991:

The operation of the revised procedures for implementation of anti-dumping and countervailing actions introduced in 1986, and the need for legislative changes to part XVb of the Customs Act 1901, with particular attention to the following:

(a) while recognising requirements under the GATT, the scope for and appropriateness of assessing and taking into account injury to suppliers of components and raw materials used in production of goods allegedly being dumped;
(b) the desirability of implementing cash securities on prima facie dumped goods after the 55 day preliminary investigation of a dumping or countervailing complaint;
(c) the development of a clearer methodology for estimating material injury in industries which have long production periods or processes;

(d) the appropriateness of the current requirement for a new inquiry after countervailing duties have been imposed for three years when the circumstances which led to the implementation of duties have demonstrably not changed, and the scope for a fast track review mechanism in these circumstances;
(e) the availability of timely and adequate statistical data from the Australian Customs Service to ensure the prompt acceptance of applications for anti-dumping and countervailing duties; and
(f) whether the Australian Government's interpretation of obligations under the GATT anti-dumping and countervailing duties code is consistent with the approach by other countries.

Yesterday I presented to the Senate the terms of reference for the establishment of an inquiry into anti-dumping and countervailing measures. Today I seek the support of the Senate for that motion. As members of this chamber would be aware, I have often spoken of the amount of food products that Australia imports and the levels of subsidies that those products attract in their countries of origin. In the midst of the crisis currently hitting our rural community, Australia is importing about $2 billion worth of food products every year. This represents about 10 per cent of this country's current account deficit. In July this year Australia imported $30.3m worth of fruit and vegetables; $1.4m in meat; $9.23m in cereals; and $31.65m in fish products. Much of this product is dumped at unrealistic prices on our domestic markets, or receives excessive government subsidies in its country of origin.

The current anti-dumping and countervailing legislation is time consuming, cumbersome and biased against industries with long production time and fluctuating cost structures. I am referring these terms of reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology and I am sure that this Committee will examine the existing problems within the legislation and recommend ways of correcting some anomalies. I would like to acknowledge the support of the National Farmers Federation, state farming organisations, trade consultants and industry groups.

The terms of reference are a combination of thoughts and ideas of all sections of Australian primary industry. These terms of reference are broad and question legislation which affects many different parts of Australian industry-both primary and secondary. It is my hope, however, that the members of the Committee will see the urgent need to complete the investigation into primary products as soon as possible and will work to ensure that this section of the inquiry is under way quickly.

Australian rural industries are in crisis and the Committee must recognise this. The total gross value of Australian farm production for 1990-91 is estimated by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) to be $22.2 billion. Rural exports for the same period are estimated to be worth $14.5 billion. Just over 12 months ago, I brought to the notice of the chamber the plight of Queensland pineapple growers, whose canned products were being swamped by cheap imports from neighbouring countries. Processors in these countries enjoy developing country tariff preferences and a much lower wage structure, and receive government subsidies like tax holidays, freight assistance and free land.

Since then, at least another 20 industry associations have come to me expressing their concerns at the flood of dumped and subsidised imported food products. Australian horticultural products are fast becoming an endangered species. The list is growing every week. First it was pineapples; now it is bananas, canned fruit, peanuts, navy beans, peas, beetroot, beans, potatoes and other vegetables as well as apricots, dried vine fruits, rice, orange juice, apple juice, jams, mushrooms, dairy products and fresh meat. In fact, a whole smorgasbord of imported foods is entering our market as cheap and subsidised products. At the same time, our farmers are having to plough back their products into the soil.

The Australian community is starved of export income and burdened by foreign debt, yet our table is groaning under the weight of imported foods entering our country. The Australian community should not be deceived. It is not a simple case of the consumer's access to cheap imported food which will have no side effects on the economy. Almost every part of the Australian community, both in the city and in the country, will be affected if this flood of subsidised and dumped imports is left unattended and allowed to close down our smaller primary industries. I say to Senator Cook that I include unionists. Not only will growers of those products be affected but also the entire support network that is dependent on these industries will suffer-the rural communities, the transporters, the processors, the canners, the packers, the storemen, the factory workers and, of course, in the end all Australian consumers will be seriously affected if the horticultural industries are forced to close down.

When consumers buy an Australian grown and processed product, they are guaranteed the best quality product in the world. Australian primary products are grown and processed under strict health and hygiene conditions using the highest level of food technology available. The same guarantees cannot be given for the imported products. The major supermarket chains are perpetuating the situation as they import a large percentage of this food for resale under their generic and home brands. They must also consider their community obligations.

We must take action now to prevent the demise of Australia's horticultural industries and ensure that our primary producers can take action against unfair competition. I want to make it very clear here that I am not talking about trade barriers, quotas or tariff protection. Every one of us here in this chamber should know the benefits of the goal of a free world trade, and hope that one day in the not too distant future it will become a reality, although one wonders about that. What I am talking about is a form of recourse against dumped and subsidised products. Australian farmers have to compete against heavily subsidised products. It is bad enough that they have to compete against the corruption on the world market, but now corruption is being imported onto the Australian domestic market and creating an unfair trading situation.

It is essential that Australia interprets the existing trade guidelines established under General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in a similar way to our trading partners. What I want to outline are some of the problems with the existing anti-dumping and countervailing legislation. Growers are currently being told by the Government that their answer to the rising flood of imported food is through anti-dumping and countervailing legislation; that all they need to do is to establish the level of subsidies and the price of goods in the country of origin, then initiate an anti-dumping or countervailing case against the offending product. That is fine in theory but it does not work out that way in practice.

The associated problems in initiating a case are numerous and cumbersome. The terms of reference identify six major areas that need to be reviewed. In the first instance, an industry has to suffer material damage before a case can begin. The Australian Customs Service and the anti-dumping authorities can take up to 295 days to decide whether the case is positive. This is far too long. Cash securities can only be applied after the case has been under way for almost five months and well after the case has been accepted as being positive.

The terms of reference suggest that these securities should be applied after a preliminary positive case has been determined, that is, after the initial 55-day investigation period. If the anti-dumping authority agrees with the producer that the material damage has been suffered and sustained, and the products are being dumped or subsidised, then a duty is imposed on the incoming goods. However, the producer then has to take that case back through the entire process every three years to have the market situation reassessed, otherwise the imposed duty automatically expires. That is time-consuming and expensive, because it can take up to $200,000 to re-establish a dumping duty. Many Australian primary producers just cannot afford to do that every three years. The necessity for these sunset clauses will be questioned in the inquiry.

Another problem identified in the terms of reference is that only the injury to like goods can be assessed. Therefore, in the case of canned peas and beans, for example, it is only the injury to the processor and not the injury to the primary producer which could be assessed. The vegetable growers have suffered extensive reductions in their incomes and have been forced to plough their crops back into the ground. Yet only the material damage done to the cannery is admissible as evidence in an anti-dumping case.

In many situations the case is to be mounted against the importers of the processed product, usually a major retailer that is also the main customer of the Australian canner, and the retailer is very reluctant to take on its customers in court. By the time a case has been prepared and presented and the Australian Customs Service has made a decision on it, so much damage can be done to one of our industries that sometimes it just does not consider it is worth the money or the trouble, and it walks away and just lets the flood of imported products wreck its industry. There is no alternative; the anti-dumping legislation needs to be made more user friendly.

Australian primary industry organisations have neither the time nor the funds available to chase the information required by government departments. One of the terms of reference questions the availability of statistics from the Australian Customs Service. It is time that the anti-dumping and countervailing legislation was made to work not solely for the benefit of the Australian producer but to give him some protection.

There is also a problem with the methodology used when assessing material injury to industries, such as agriculture, which have long production periods and fluctuating incomes. The terms of reference note the difficulties associated with establishing prices of processed food in foreign countries and establishing some of the subsidies that imported goods receive. The onus and expense in discovering this information should not be the complete responsibility of the primary producer. The Government also has a role to play in this. Some of the primary produce subsidies are obvious, such as those under the United States export enhancement program. In 1988 the United States Government paid out more than $21,000 per farm in agriculture subsidies. The European Community (EC) has similar export subsidy schemes. Last year a tonne of cheddar cheese exported from the EC to Australia attracted a $1,000 per tonne subsidy to compete against Australian producers. Currants were subsidised at $1,300 per tonne to compete against our Australian producers. Japan spends over $6 billion a year subsidising its domestic rice growers.

Last year Canada supported its pork producers by between $37 and $41 a hog. Canadian pork producers are eligible for more than 20 different subsidy programs-to name just a few, the feed freight assistance program, the western transportation industrial development program and the Alberta crow offset program. Even though the Federal Government is well aware of these Canadian subsidies, it has lifted the ban on imported fresh and chilled pork meat and has advised the industry to enact the anti-dumping and countervailing legislation if its industry suffers damage.

In effect, the Government has said that it knows that this pork product is subsidised and it will let it into this nation. If the producers want to challenge it through anti-dumping, they can; that is their option. I am asking the Senate inquiry to investigate products coming into Australia that are known to have subsidies applied to them. Other subsidies are hidden and difficult to verify. These schemes are many and varied, including free freight, free land and fertilisers, electricity, tax holidays and in some cases a complete ban on competing products sold in their countries.

How can Australia's rural community compete with this? We have high interest rates, high transport costs, soaring production costs and soaring wage costs. The rate of effective assistance to rural industry in Japan as determined by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development was estimated at 72 per cent in 1989. Switzerland takes the cake, with 75 per cent, and the subsidy in Norway was estimated at 74 per cent. It is interesting to note that we do import cheese from Norway.

The European Community currently is feeling righteous, being just below the world average at 38 per cent. The United States is slightly lower, with a 27 per cent level of protection. However, Australia has the second lowest rate of assistance, at 10 per cent, with only New Zealand having a lower rate, at 7 per cent.
The situation I have outlined today is just the beginning. Our industries have not yet collapsed but they are standing very close to the cliff. They are almost at the point of no return.

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk them down even further; destroy their confidence.
—I am very surprised at you, Senator. I would have thought that if you could not support the farmers, which you traditionally hate--
—Order! Senator Boswell, address your remarks through the Chair.

—Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I would say to Senator McKiernan that, if he has no concern for the farmers, at least let him show some sympathy for the unionists who work in the processing factories and who are about to lose their jobs because of the non-support of the Labor Party.
—You do not understand what he is saying.

—I entirely understand what Senator McKiernan is saying, and he should be ashamed of himself. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations are not looking good at the moment. There is talk in the media of renewed agricultural trade wars between the European Community and the United States of America if the Uruguay Round is not concluded satisfactorily. Such an outcome could be the final gust that blows our primary industries over the edge. What the inquiry will do, I hope, is throw them a rope. It will give our primary industries something to grip if the trade winds begin to blow in their face.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Australian primary industries need fast, efficient, and reasonably priced access to anti-dumping and countervailing legislation. They need a form of recourse against dumped and subsidised imports which is fast, reliable and readily activated. I hope that, after hearing submissions from growers, processors, unionists and workers employed in the canneries and packing houses-in fact all parts of the industry-the Senate Committee will recommend significant changes to the legislation. These changes will benefit not only the primary producers of Australia but, I hope, the country as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I see that Senator Boswell's notice of motion has come to fruition in this form and that we will be seeking to refer this matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. I intend to state somewhat of a case for arguing that there should be unanimous support from this place for such a reference. I can see no reason why anyone would want to deny the Committee the opportunity to make, as Senator Boswell described it, the operation of this anti-dumping and countervailing legislation more user-friendly. In fact, the aim of finding something that could be operated in a fast, reliable and readily activated manner is laudable and I see no reason why that could not be unanimously supported here.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make a few remarks on some of the terms of reference devised by Senator Boswell-and, I must say, devised after lengthy consultation with interested parties. He was kind enough to show me those terms of reference and ask for our concordance before they were finally submitted. We appreciate the communication that has been offered to us by the Nationals on this matter, and they have our concordance.

Paragraph (b) of the proposed terms of reference has the potential to redirect the onus of action in this matter away from the injured to other parties. I hope that the Committee will take this a little further in considering the direction suggested in paragraph (e), which refers to developing a clearer methodology.
