It might also be able to recommend a means by which, for example, a statutory authority has the capacity simply to ensure that dumping does not occur. Rather than rely on the injured party to demonstrate that dumping may occur, if a statutory authority has the charter to ensure that dumping does not occur, the onus of action is taken away from the injured party to another party which has that as its main responsibility. That is a matter for the Committee which I hope it will consider very carefully in finding its methodology.

Paragraph (c) directs itself to that reference. I hope that the Committee will not only develop a clearer methodology for estimating material injury, but will also devise a methodology which ensures that injury does not occur. Surely that is the whole point of it: if our producers and traders are suffering material injury, then we as a country are suffering as well. If we can devise a way of preventing that from happening, then I think we are doing the right thing. At the moment it seems that the message is that we rely on just the producers. We think that they are a separate group, that it is up to them, and that they have to carry the can all the way.

There are many good reasons to ensure that an expedient and reliable method of properly addressing this whole business of anti-dumping is delivered. Senator Boswell has accurately and comprehensively described the sorts of industries that are affected in this way. Paragraph (c) is particularly directed to industries which have long production periods or processes. I am sure that we could all think of industries which have large initial capital investment and which do not provide a quick and reliable revenue return. In the primary industries, orchard crops come to mind instinctively.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what it is designed for primarily.

—Yes, but other more exotic crops are equally vulnerable, which might not be immediately apparent. For example, one such crop is asparagus in Tasmania. Asparagus is a plant which does not reach full production for three or four years. While there is some production in the first couple of years, the season's production is worth much less than that of the fourth and fifth years. If unfair competition from an overseas supplier caused damage to an asparagus producer during the first couple of years, the estimation of injury would be much lower than for the potential production from seasons four and five.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Boswell is proposing in paragraph (c) is of value to a wide variety of industries. I welcome that paragraph. I think it can serve a good purpose. Another good example is those aspects of the livestock industry where products are developed from animals after a long breeding or product identification process. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would probably agree that programs involving animals such as angora goats or fallow deer are particularly relevant to Tasmania. Those programs are particularly sensitive to market price manipulations.

If overseas market opportunities are lost because our producers are undercut by subsidised or dumped products, then the effect is felt in the Australian market-a market which, in many of these sorts of areas, is in its infancy. It is complicated, but that is what international trade is all about. The more complicated it is, the more likely that we in Australia will suffer when we try to follow the simplistic deregulated free trade route. The sorts of industries I have been talking about are industries where we have been showing some initiative in recent years. If our investment and our initiative are destroyed by a couple of seasons of subsidised or dumped entry of products, then we lose more than just the initial investment from the producers-we lose as a country our access to a variety of products and we lose our spread of investments as a country.

To illustrate this I do not think I need to go any further than one of my regular topics over the past few months-that is, the carpet wool industry. We all realise that currently we have closer economic relations (CER) with New Zealand. One could say that our economic dealings with New Zealand have been essentially deregulated. Perhaps we could describe the situation as resembling this Government's aim of free trade with all nations. Until October, carpet wool producers in Australia paid a wool tax of 25 per cent while New Zealand producers paid 6 per cent. When, after much pressure, the Government exempted our carpet wool producers from almost 20 per cent of the tax, Australia's carpet wool industry and I were very pleased. However, that pleasure was short lived because, through some manipulation, computation and permutation of their arrangements within New Zealand, New Zealand growers are now being paid something like $2.50 for their carpet wool but it is being sold in Australia for something like $1.50 a kilo. Obviously this is wrong, unfair and dangerous to Australia's industry.

The carpet wool growers, who have just begun to see some opportunity to sell wool-and that is a real achievement in the current wool market situation-have been out-hustled by the New Zealanders yet again. I do not know whether this qualifies as dumping or not; that is my point. At present it is difficult, time consuming and costly to mount a case to prove that dumping is occurring. It is especially difficult if it is suspected that the closer economic relations agreement has been manipulated. But in this instance the plain effect is that our producers are being unfairly undercut. Our industry is one of those requiring a lengthy buildup. For example, the carpet wool industry requires a breeding program to move through Corriedales, Romneys or whatever to the actual carpet wool sheep such as Drysdales, Elliotdales or whatever. That is an expensive undertaking for the entire industry. The industry can be wiped out in a couple of seasons because our present anti-dumping legislation is too clumsy to provide effective protection. If that is what closer economic relations means, we have been taken for a sucker yet again.

It seems to me to be symptomatic of this Government's lack of understanding of what happens in country Australia as a result of its passion for deregulation. While Australia has been deregulating with the blind faith that all other international traders are fine, honourable people and that they will follow Australia's example, these international traders have been busily doing what they have been doing for centuries. They have been trading-selling their produce in whatever way and through whatever mechanism is available to them. Invariably we see foreign governments understanding and supporting their producers in this regard. We see that the effect-let alone the reason for it-of New Zealand's recent currency devaluation is to enhance the position of that country's carpet wool producers vis-a-vis Australia's producers. If New Zealand can be such an aggressive and successful competitor within closer economic relations, we must be doubly concerned about the competition we face from other nations. I suggest that international trade is not a polite, genteel occupation undertaken by philanthropists interested in Australia's best interests. As far as we are concerned, we should view international competitors as evil, scheming, dirty rotten scoundrels-out to make a buck whenever and wherever possible and, if possible, they will make it from us.

If the whole country-government, producers and agents together-can appreciate this point of view and act in unison as an aggressive, street-wise operator in the jungle of world trade, then our country as a whole will benefit from the opportunity of the increased sales.

I see this inquiry as an opportunity to send a signal to our producers that we in this place realise that dumping is a problem and that we in this place can do something-I was most entertained by Senator Boswell's phrase-`to make the legislation user friendly' and get it to the stage where it actually works and so demonstrate that we in this country can act in unison and as an aggressive competitor in international trade. If this inquiry can send a signal that we are capable of acting together and that we do realise some of the problems being faced by some of our producers, then the inquiry will have been successful.

This inquiry could also send a signal to our international competitors that we are at last getting our act together and that they had better stop seeing us as an easy target for dumping, manipulation of subsidies, or the sorts of practices which seem to have brought into the Australian market the very sorts of products that Senator Boswell so accurately listed. It is that competition that cannot be left to our producers to fight. The producers need the assistance of the Government and of the Australian community as a whole. It is the Australian community as a whole which eventually benefits from viable and successful rural industries.

While I have been supporting the rural industries and suggesting that we are deregulating too rapidly, I have been challenged with the suggestion that we should not expect the Australian community to support our rural producers with subsidies, tariff regulations or more effective anti-dumping legislation. My answer to that has been that it is the Australian community which has decided that our rural producers-in fact all our producers-have to bear the burden of award wages, health regulations, inspection fees and the other sorts of costs associated with operating in Australia.

Several times in this place we have heard a litany of the sorts of costs which all producers have to face. Some of the costs, as Senator Boswell said, are very hard to determine. The sorts of potential subsidies which governments in other countries could give and are giving are often difficult to determine. That is the very reason that we have to make the point that the whole community benefits and the whole community has the potential to support our producers. If we as a nation and our producers are suffering from unfair competition from overseas, then it is up to us to recognise this and to try to see where this country can support itself and the members of its community.

Quite frankly, this is a very good way to start on this path of giving support. I hope that the Senate gives unanimous support to this reference to the Committee. I also hope that the members of the Committee can see the direction which this inquiry could take and at last give some sort of support and indication to rural Australia that this Government is interested in its welfare. When I say `this Government' I mean it in its fullest sense, comprising all members of the Parliament. We should show that we are all interested in the welfare of the rural community. If that signal can be made through this Committee I will be most satisfied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole question of dumping and countervailing certainly needs clarification and simplification. I am pleased to be able to support this proposal to refer to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology the questions that have been put before us so that the problems being experienced in this field can be looked at and solutions suggested and hopefully implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal and National Party coalition is determined to do something to stop unfair trading practices, to stop dumping and to give some reasonably simple way of getting redress where these procedures and actions by importers interfere with and severely affect the rural producers of Australia. I congratulate the mover of the motion, Senator Boswell, for the work that he has put into this and for the attention to detail that has gone into getting the references correct. I think the wide-ranging support for this proposal to submit this matter to the Committee is something that we, as Australians, will reap the benefits of in the future.

It is pleasing to see the Australian Democrats supporting this motion and I am sure that the Australian Labor Party will see the merit of it and will also support the referral to the Committee. Anything that will get better rules, systems and procedures for bringing actions and investigating these matters must be of benefit to Australia as a whole and to rural producers in particular. It is essential that this be done now, at a time when rural industries are in real crisis and the primary producers are suffering more every day.

It is something that the Liberal and National parties are very keen to see implemented. The inquiry should be wide- ranging. It should delve into these matters, and I am sure that the members of the Committee will do that. If I have a reservation concerning the reference, it would be that it may not be wide enough. I sometimes wonder whether we should not have included also in the reference to this Committee an examination of quarantine matters, because a lot of the problems being experienced by rural producers could be exacerbated a hundredfold if some of the crops that they are growing were to be wiped out because quarantine was relaxed to the extent where diseases could get into Australia through foreign produce.

I have mentioned before in this Senate an inquiry by the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service which is examining quarantining procedures concerning rice and altering the rules to make it easier to bring in foreign rice. Making it easier increases, at all times, the risk of bringing foreign diseases into a disease-free industry in Australia. If the Quarantine Inspection Service gets it wrong and allows in rice that is contaminated, it could wipe out the Australian rice industry.

There are many arguments for and against different levels of quarantining but I think that not enough attention is paid to the dictum that if there is a doubt, that doubt should be decided for the benefit of Australian producers rather than for the benefit of importers and overseas producers. I think too often when quarantine matters are being considered the fine dividing line of the argument is decided against Australian rural producers. This is a problem in the rice industry. It is also a problem in the banana industry, where bananas are being imported and there are doubts about the correct quarantine procedures. If something goes wrong the whole industry could be wiped out. The list goes on. Citrus products are coming in. There is doubt about the quarantine procedures concerning them, and if some germ or disease gets into the country, again, a very substantial rural industry could be wiped out.

These problems, together with the dumping of these crops, have particular relevance to the areas which I represent. If dumping and quarantining are not handled in the correct way, whole towns could disappear off the map. The town that I come from, Ayr, has a very substantial rice industry and the town further north in the Atherton Tablelands, Mareeba, is very heavily dependent upon rice; and dumping of cheaper, subsidised overseas products and failures to look properly at quarantining matters could ruin those industries, ruin the enormous infrastructure that has gone into them, ruin the capital input that has been put into them and ruin the jobs of many of the people who work in the plants that process those things.

Similarly, the towns of Tully and Innisfail are reeling from competition from cheap and, I suspect, subsidised imports of bananas from other countries. A lot of people laugh when the word `banana' is mentioned, particularly in relation to Queensland, but it is a very vital and important industry in the Tully and Innisfail areas of our State. It is an industry which, at the moment, is reeling because of what is said to be unfair competition from subsidised and otherwise supported imports.

The Queensland citrus growing areas of Mundubbera and Gayndah are also feeling the pinch of imported products and are doubly concerned at not only the dumping aspects of it but also the quarantining aspects. If that industry really is affected badly, a whole section of Queensland could well move off the map and again the infrastructure, the jobs and everything else that goes with it would be in trouble.

Even in the sugar industry there is competition from cheaper and, I suspect again, subsidised overseas imports. That is almost unthinkable for a country which has the most efficient and most effective sugar industry in the world-one that for many years has supplied all of Australia's wants and, without question, is run more efficiently than any sugar industry anywhere else in the world. Yet we are importing sugar. Fortunately, at the moment, it is only small portions, but it is coming in. To me, that can mean only that somewhere along the line the imported sugar is being assisted in some way. I hope that this inquiry will enable investigations into that and enable the action that can be taken to be taken more effectively.

I do not want to take up the time of the Senate any longer on this question. I am only a very simple person, and I simply ask this question of whoever might be able to answer it: in these matters relating to dumping, countervailing and quarantining, I cannot understand why it is only Australia that seems to be playing by the rules. We are a very small country. Our influence on world trade would be minuscule. Yet we seem to be the only ones doing it. That is a question that I cannot understand. Nobody seems to be able to tell me, but there must be some reason why we do it and nobody else does.

I think the concept of world free trade is excellent. It is a concept that I think would probably have greater benefits in other countries, but we seem to be the only ones doing it. I hope that somewhere along the line in the not too distant future someone will be able to tell me why we do it honestly, why we do it deliberately and fairly, but nobody else seems to do so.

This inquiry that has been proposed for referral to the Senate Standing Committee is an excellent idea. It is one that I hope will come up with some suggestions and recommendations that can be implemented and can put a new light on these problems and, in that way, can assist the rural producers of Australia in getting their products onto the market without unfair competition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: -I have great pleasure in supporting today the motion moved by Senator Boswell, the Leader of my Party, the National Party of Australia. I thought one passage of his speech was of particular interest. He said that one day free world trade in agriculture will become a reality. We in the National Party of Australia look forward to that day because we have absolutely no doubt that primary producers in this country are the most cost efficient and most effective in the world. What concerns me, as it concerns Senator Boswell, is what will happen to our primary producers between now and when that day finally comes. What we face around the world-in the European Economic Community, in Latin American countries, in China and in North America-is a tide sweeping against free trade in agricultural produce. We see continued efforts by governments in those countries to stymie any attempts to open up agricultural markets around the world to free trade. It concerns me that we in this country allow this to happen, allow goods that are produced through heavy subsidies, goods that are dumped in this country, to destroy the agricultural base of Australia's economy.

SPEECH.PARA: What worries me and frightens me enormously is the possibility that, when the day finally comes when free trade in agricultural products is a reality, there will be no farm sector in this country to take advantage of our natural opportunities to produce better quality goods more cheaply than anybody else. I am particularly concerned at the mechanisms currently existing within the Australian Customs Service (ACS) for the analysis and examination of countervailing and anti-dumping applications.

When we heard evidence from the ACS in Estimates Committee A earlier this year, I asked its officers whether the procedure was satisfactory for protecting Australian farmers from dumping and countervailing. They said, yes, they felt the process was satisfactory because they did not get many complaints afterwards. I said, `Look, this is a non sequitur'. The reason it was a non sequitur, and the reason it remains a non sequitur, is very simple: the whole process of making an application for protection against dumping and countervailing is so complex, so costly and so time-consuming that by the time the ACS comes to the conclusion that there might not be a case, half the time the people who originally made the complaint are either bankrupt or cannot afford to proceed any further and make an appeal against that determination.

That is why the motion moved by Senator Boswell is absolutely critical. It flushes out into the open the unsatisfactory methods currently used by the ACS, and it shows once and for all a very real need for the ACS to have a clear view of what dumping and countervailing is all about and what it does to Australian primary producers.

I note too the answers given to my questions on notice put in Estimates Committee A with respect to the number of agricultural complaints as a percentage of total complaints and the number of agricultural complaints upheld as a percentage of the total. For example, in 1987-88 only 20 per cent of total complaints about dumping and countervailing came from agricultural industries. In spite of the number being so small, not one complaint was upheld by the Australian Customs Service. I am very pleased to see that in the last financial year the figure for agricultural complaints has finally crept up to 27 per cent, with the number of complaints upheld being 29 per cent, but I believe that there is clear evidence-and Senator Boswell in his speech today has done a magnificent job of making that evidence very clear-to show that the cases for anti-dumping and countervailing complaints by the Australian agricultural producers should perhaps be substantially higher than that.

We face around the world governments in other countries that are persistently and wilfully subsidising inefficient farmers for their own ends and in contradiction to the fine words they mouth in forums such as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). It is very clear when one looks, for example, at Japan that its level of subsidy is wholly unsatisfactory. Japanese farmers on average receive 72 per cent of their income in the form of government subsidies. In other countries, such as the United States of America, the level of government subsidy is something like 38 per cent. These are figures I have cited in the Senate before and figures I will continue to push, because it is very important for the Australian public to understand the plight of the rural sector in this country and understand exactly what makes it very difficult for Australian farmers to survive at the moment. It is not because Australian farmers are inefficient; it is not because Australian farmers cannot compete. They can compete, but they are not being allowed to compete. That is what this inquiry is all about.

I read with interest today in the Sydney Morning Herald an article on page 3 relating to the macadamia nut industry. It is interesting that the macadamia nut is a native Australian nut. In spite of this, the macadamia nut industry in this country is on the point of collapse. One reason for that is that the industry is having difficulty competing with subsidised products from South Africa and Costa Rica. Goodness gracious-we are now finding that an industry we gave the world less than 20 years ago is now about to collapse and growers are going to go out of business.

While these conditions in the Australian Customs Service continue, while the ACS fails to take the necessary tough stance on dumping and countervailing, all I can say is that we will continue to see Australian agricultural industries collapse. We will continue to see a loss of jobs for Australian farm workers and people in processing industries. It is absolutely critical that we in this country recognise the risk, recognise the threat to Australian livelihoods and jobs, and take the necessary steps to stand up for Australian farmers.

In the few moments that were available to me this morning I compiled a list of some of the industries that I recognise as being under threat from dumping and countervailing. Of course, these are not the only ones, but they are some that have come to mind. They include the pine- apple, banana, citrus fruits, orange juice concentrate, apple juice concentrate, and canned fruits industries. Jam is coming in from Hungary; frozen peas and beans from the Netherlands; and potatoes from Canada. Cucumbers, beetroot, mushrooms and canned tomatoes are being brought into the country. The sultana industry in Sunraysia is in dreadful straits, as of course is the sugar industry. There are many other such industries on top of those.

Allow me to address just a couple of industries that I believe are very important. An industry very dear to my heart, being a Queenslander, is the banana industry. We have awful problems in north Queensland because our banana growers have had a number of very tough years and, just as the industry looks like picking up, they face the very real threat of having to compete with subsidised products coming in from Ecuador-products that bring with them the risk of black sigatoka and moko, two diseases that have the potential to decimate, if not totally destroy, the banana industry in north Queensland.

I have said it before and I will say it again: if we allow moko to come into this country, we will contaminate the soil in banana growing areas and there will be nothing we can do to allow those areas to grow bananas for 20 or 30 years. The jobs of thousands of north Queenslanders are at risk. An industry worth in the vicinity of $150m to this country every year will be destroyed if we allow these cheap subsidised products to flood the Australian markets.

The Golden Circle pineapple cannery in Brisbane is another case in point showing the dangers of what happens when cheap subsidised products come into this country. In Queensland we can grow some of the finest pineapples in the world-beautiful sweet pineapples-yet we face the prospect of losing our pineapple industry as cheap, inferior products come flooding in from the Philippines. It is not just the farmers who will suffer. I know for a fact that workers at the Golden Circle cannery are very concerned about the future of their jobs, their livelihoods and their families if the Queensland pineapple industry is destroyed by Filipino imports.

That is why we on this side of the chamber and, in particular, we in the National Party believe that it is absolutely essential that this inquiry go ahead. One of the strange things is that many of the so-called home brands-I think in particular of Home Brand peanut paste-are in fact not home grown products at all. If you go into the supermarket and buy a jar of Home Brand peanut paste, that peanut paste almost invariably comes from Israel or China.

I think it is a sad irony that the company that manufactures and markets it in this country should pretend that it is a home brand, because it is anything but a home grown product; it is a product brought into this country and subsidised by the government of the country of its origin. It is brought in here for the sole purpose of undermining a very viable Australian industry such as the peanut industry. In my part of Queensland the peanut industry is very important and Senator Bjelke-Petersen will refer to it in more detail very shortly. These are the sorts of problems we face.

Yet another problem, of course, is the pork industry. Senator Boswell so ably said today that the Canadian pork producers are eligible for up to 20 different subsidies. We have already seen how the Japanese farmers receive 72 per cent of their income in the form of government assistance. Do honourable senators know what percentage of total farm income in this country is government assistance? It is one per cent. One per cent of total farm income in this country comes from government assistance and if the Government has its way and wipes out drought relief, the only government assistance worth talking about will not be assistance to keep a farm going; it will be the money the Government pays to the farmer to get off the farm, to leave the land forever and to destroy another generation of Australian farmers. The time has come when we must take a firm stand on the cheating and frauding of international agricultural trade by countries overseas.

I have said before that Australian farmers in our free trade environment stand stark naked before the chill winds of international trade. I believe that the developments in the European Economic Community, the downturn in the GATT negotiations and the Uruguay Round show that it is not just a chill wind that our farmers currently face, but a full blown blizzard and they need assistance. They need somebody to stand up for them and protect them from what is being done to them overseas. We have seen generations of Australian farmers supporting the future and wealth of this country. It was long said that Australia rode on the sheep's back. But that very simplistic statement forgets all the other agricultural industries that have over the years supported the wealth of this country, for example, the wheat industry, the sugar industry and all of the other industries that I have mentioned.

We recollect during the war the fine efforts of Australian farmers to feed the mouths in this country and to assist in providing agricultural produce for our allies overseas. During the Second World War our Australian farmers were fighting a war of their own and they fought it valiantly. As we supported our soldiers, so too must we support our farmers. We must recognise the contribution of those generations of Australian farmers to the wealth and prosperity that we all enjoy today. I refer not just to generations of farmers that have preceded us, but to the generations of farmers to come.

We in this chamber frequently see school groups come to visit us and I notice that there are a couple of school groups in the galleries today. Many of those school children come from rural and provincial Australia. As they come here they ask what we have to offer for their future. What will we do to ensure a livelihood for the next generation of young Australians in rural and provincial Australia? I believe the move made by Senator Boswell today in putting forward this motion and bringing about this inquiry is a very brave step to ensure the future prosperity of this nation and of future generations of Australians who will be dependent upon agricultural industries.

I close by saying that I agree with Senator Boswell's sentiments. I look forward to that brave day when free world trade in agricultural products will become a reality and we will work towards that end. But until that day comes around we in the National Party will have no hesitation in standing up and fighting for the rights of Australian farmers and for all those in this country who depend upon them because the future of our agricultural industries is absolutely essential to the future economic strength of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks will be brief and to the point because most of the detail of the issue has been covered. I support this inquiry. It is a very important inquiry, because under the current anti-dumping and countervailing legislation industries in this country, in particular agriculture, cop it on both ends. We get penalised through dumping actions in terms of our inputs. The best example I can give is in terms of fertiliser being imported into this country against the monopoly situation which exists as far as manufacture is concerned. In that instance we find countries such as China and India, which use three times as much fertiliser as Australia, having access to fertiliser traded at world prices which is not available to Australian producers. On the other side of the coin, when it comes to countervailing actions, we see that in terms of those countries which are subsidising their producers we do not have effective action to correct the situation. So in both instances we have a problem in terms of free trade and what is commonly termed the level playing field.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point I want to highlight is the method of assessing damage or estimated material injury. This needs to be clarified and cleaned up. An aspect which is crucial to this whole issue is the way that these actions can be strung out. In fact, on the most recent figures I have seen, the average time is almost 12 months to get an action sorted out as it goes through the processes. The amendments which were made in 1986 were designed to speed up the whole process. In actual fact, if a party wants to string out an action to get a decision-whatever that decision might be-I believe it can take up to 457 days. We have a ludicrous situation in this country where we are being denied access to inputs at world traded prices. On the other hand, we have entry into this country of subsidised products, particularly in the horticulture, dairy, fruit and dried fruit industries.

So we on this side of the chamber support this inquiry. We hope that it will address some of the issues in the anti-dumping and countervailing legislation and address the distortions that are created by the present decision making process now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Boswell's motion that the anti-dumping and countervailing legislation be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee have certainly told us of all the industries that have been affected by dumping of cheap products on the Australian market. This is a real problem as far as peanuts and navy bean imports are concerned. I want to refer to those industries in particular in my remarks in the Senate today. My home district, South Burnett and Kingaroy, is the peanut and navy bean capital of Australia. I was certainly very interested to hear Senator O'Chee's remarks about peanut paste. I must admit that I do not buy Home Brand peanut paste; I always buy Kraft peanut paste. So I hope it comes from home grown peanuts. It is always very nice.
—Any more commercials?

—Mr Deputy President, I believe it is very important that we emphasise our home grown peanuts because they have been at the basis of our economy in South Burnett for a long time and they are suffering very much as a result of peanuts being imported, as I will tell the Senate shortly. The Burnett region normally produces 90 per cent of Australia's navy beans and 70 per cent of its peanuts.

SPEECH.PARA: Crops are down to 25 per cent of normal levels this year, owing to either drought or wet harvests. The run of bad seasons has sapped the confidence in what was regarded as one of the nation's safest climatic regions. The peanut industry, for example, has had five particularly bad years of weather. Indeed, as I read in our local paper just recently, this year the peanut growers have had to borrow money to plant their crops. That is a very bad start, because then the growers really do need a good season to ensure that they get a crop to pay back their debts and, of course, the bad seasons have caused growers to get lower yields for their crops as well.

But to compound the problems the growers are facing, peanut processors are importing peanuts-those imported peanuts used in the production of the peanut paste that my friend Senator O'Chee was speaking about earlier. Most of the imports are coming from China, and if the same crop had been grown in Australia it would have been rejected because of the high levels of chemicals that it contains. We have two policies on this issue in Australia. We expect our peanut growers to have a relatively pollution and chemical free product. Yet we then import a subsidised product that would normally have been rejected by our authorities.

In the navy bean industry the situation is similar. The navy bean industry is enduring a difficult time at the moment for two reasons. The first, as I said earlier, is the succession of adverse seasonal circumstances. The second is the declining profitability in the gross margin of production, which is then compounded by the need to compete with inferior products which are currently being dumped at obviously cheaper prices on the Australian market.

Droughts and floods are facts of agricultural production in any year and are elements over which control cannot be exercised. I am certainly very pleased indeed that I do not have to have any say in the control of the weather because I am afraid neighbours would be very upset. There would be some people who want a nice dry season to harvest their crop, and other people who are anxiously praying for rain so they can plant another one.

Farmer profitability is a matter that cannot escape attention. Put simply, the cost to produce a crop of navy beans has exceeded that which can be recovered through the selling price to Australian manufacturers. This industry has lost a 25 per cent tariff protection and consequently purchase prices are kept in line with import parity values.

In the South Burnett region, navy bean growers are having to compete with imports of canned baked beans from Eastern Bloc countries. I can assure senators that this product is not the same high quality in standard that we have come to expect from Australian primary producers, and notably the navy bean growers in the South Burnett area I come from.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great product.

—It certainly is. The ability of the industry to maintain an acceptable level to growers must be regarded as an essential aim, since price will always be rated as the chief criterion on which farmers will assess their decision to produce or not. What has happened in my district is that what was among the dearest farming country in the State in 1982 and worth $2,640 a hectare is now valued at $1,350-a very severe slump. This equity crunch is expected to drive at least 200 of the region's 1,000 peanut and navy bean farmers out of business this year, according to the Queensland Industry Development Corporation. The slow reduction in peanut and navy bean crops has turned the nation from exporter of these commodities, adding to trade deficit problems. This situation has been compounded by growers in developing countries exporting to Australia at rock bottom prices because of preferential tariff treatment for the Third World.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter that Senator O'Chee mentioned in his very excellent speech earlier was the macadamia nut industry. I just want to say to Senator O'Chee that it is the Queensland nut industry. The macadamia nuts have been growing in Queensland for a long time and they were originally called the Queensland nuts. I must say they have got terribly hard shells and are very difficult to crack but they are an excellent nut; there are no two ways about that.

It seems very ironic to me that they can be having competition from other countries producing the same nuts and nearly driving the macadamia nut industry completely broke. I think that this, too, is rather a sad effect of the dumping of all sorts of products in Australia. I agree with all the list of products that Senator O'Chee mentioned before, including the pineapple industry in Queensland which is also having problems. I could go on and on, but I think we really have had quite a long explanation regarding these matters from many senators. A farmer in our area, Ian MacFarlane, told The Bulletin:
It is a common comment up here that people could have handled bad seasons, low prices or high interest rates but to get them all at once is too much.
He continued:

It is devastating to see the erosion of farmers' financial positions . . . the problem we are facing is that the costs of growing these crops has quadrupled since 1983 while the price has not altered-
and that is a hard cold fact.
Combine that with high interest rates and the high value of the Australian dollar and it is a serious situation.

What he is saying to the Australian people is quite simple really and simple enough, I hope, for all the Labor senators and members to understand, that is, that, with high interest rates and a high dollar on top of unseasonably bad weather for quite a few years, these imports that I have been talking about are the last straw for the growers. I believe it is very important that this anti-dumping reference be referred to the Senate Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. Accordingly, I support Senator Boswell's notice of motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. The Government will not be opposing this motion and I understood we made that clear two hours ago. Nevertheless it is still the case, notwithstanding the speeches that honourable senators opposite have made. It is a pity that we have had quite so much duplication. There have been some examples of talking about important subjects instead of saying something important; nevertheless there is an issue of concern to people.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear there is majority support for it being referred in the Senate, so the Government will not be opposing it. I think the timetable that has been set down is unrealistic, but I have great faith in the Committee members and I am sure they will try to achieve it. If they do not I regret to say that I predict that they will come back and seek an extension of time. But that is not an crisis and we can cope with that if it happens.

I think Senator Crane did us a good service by pointing out that perhaps the issue is a bit more complex than some of the speakers had referred to, but the Government will not be opposing the motion. The reference will go to the Committee where I am sure it will be well dealt with, and I hope it is a productive exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am very gratified to hear that the Government is supporting the motion, which means that the subject matter raised in the motion will have the unanimous support of the Parliament. We have heard speakers from the Australian Democrats, the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and now the Australian Labor Party supporting this motion. I am sure that all the primary producers who are affected will be grateful to know that they have the support of the Parliament. Senator Bell raised some questions and as he is a new senator, I might offer him the advice that, if he wants to make a submission to this inquiry, it is not unusual for senators to place a submission before the inquiry and it will be given the same consideration as any other evidence taken.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macdonald raised two questions. He thought that the inquiry should cover quarantine. If he had a criticism, it was that the inquiry was not wide enough. Although I recognise the problems that Senator Macdonald raised in relation to importing disease into Australian primary industries, it would be difficult to combine quarantine with an anti-dumping inquiry. Another way to stop the flow of subsidised imported products into Australia relates to correct labelling. But it is very difficult to combine quarantine and labelling under an anti-dumping inquiry. I recognise that the point that Senator Macdonald made is valid. I took up the labelling point with Senator Bolkus, when he was the responsible Minister, and recently Senator Tate has corresponded with me on the issue. We have not come to a final position yet; we are still negotiating on labelling.

Senator O'Chee made a very worthwhile speech, pointing out what is happening to rural industries, in Queensland in particular. Senator Bjelke-Petersen took him to task about calling our Queensland nut a macadamia nut and I am sure that he will not make that mistake again. I was particularly grateful that Senator Bjelke-Petersen made a very strong speech supporting the industries around her home territory, the South Burnett. Senator Bjelke-Petersen and her family are under stress at the moment in other areas, but that has not stopped her coming into the chamber to defend the rural industries of Queensland, as she and her husband have done for over 40 years.

In closing the debate I would like to thank all honourable senators who have made a contribution to the motion to have this Senate inquiry reference. I do believe it will help overcome some of the problems that are affecting Australian farmers at the moment. As I said, apart from high interest rates and the high value of our dollar, the problem of subsidised food coming into Australia is probably third on the list of areas that are hurting farmers in Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australia Council Act to implement the Government's decisions in response to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure Inquiry into Commonwealth Assistance to the Arts. The Report of this Committee, entitled``Patronage, Power and the Muse'', is generally known as the McLeay Report after the Committee's Chairman, the current Speaker of the House.

The Government's response to the McLeay Report was tabled in the House of Representatives on 28 May 1987. At that time, the then Minister for the Arts, the Hon. Barry Cohen, MP, outlined the process of wide consultation with the arts community which led to the conclusions of the McLeay Report and the development of the Government's response. The Australia Council was involved in the consultation process and conducted its own review of its role, structure and functions at that time.

Many of the McLeay Report's recommendations focused on the Australia Council, the Government's arts funding body. The Government agreed with the McLeay Committee that the Council's administrative structure should be streamlined and that the Council should take account of Government policies at the Commonwealth, State and local government levels. The Government also agreed that community cultural development should be accorded a higher priority in the Council's activities.

The Australia Council supported these recommendations and has already acted to implement those aspects of the Government's response to the McLeay Report which did not require amendment of its Act. In other cases, it has set up interim mechanisms which give expression to the intent of this Bill.
This Bill was introduced into and passed by the House of Representatives in 1988. However, it had not been passed by the Senate before the March election and consequently lapsed.

The provisions of this Bill enable the Australia Council to complete the implementation of those aspects of the Government's response to the McLeay Report which relate to the operation of the Council. The main provisions of the Bill are as follows:

- The Act is to be amended to ensure that the Council has regard to Government policies and, where practicable, the policies of State and local governments as they relate to the arts. The amendments also provide for the Council to have regard to any matters which the Minister may specify in writing. The Minister will have the power to issue directions to the Council but this power will not apply to the Council's ability to make or refuse to make grants. The important `arms length' principle of arts funding is to be retained.

- The amendments allow representatives of the community interest to be appointed to the Council and its Boards. This will allow the Council to broaden its focus to better reflect the concerns of the consumers of arts programs and the general public. The amendments also remove the requirement for Government representation on the Council and ensure all Board Chairpersons are members of the Council.

- In keeping with the streamlined administration which the Council has put in place through the amalgamation of Boards, and also to enhance flexibility, the maximum membership of Boards has been increased from eight to nine and the minimum membership has been reduced from six to five.

- The amendments also allow the Council, its Boards and its Committees to conduct meetings by tele-conference or any other means. In this way the Council would be able to respond quickly to situations which require immediate decisions.

- Another major change is the establishment of a new co-ordinating Board which may have a membership of thirteen, including the Chairperson. This new Board will have a large, flexible membership which may comprise the Chairperson and members of the Council, the Chairperson and members of Boards and wide representation from community arts and the broad public interest. The new provisions allow the Minister to establish this Board as a Community Cultural Development Board to further the development of community cultural activities, in line with the Government's response to the McLeay Report. The Council has already set up a Community Cultural Development Committee in anticipation that it would form the basis for the new Board.

The Community Cultural Development Board will have as a major objective supporting and encouraging the active participation of communities in the development of their own culture. It will seek to identify and develop training opportunities, promote the theory and practice of contemporary arts, support community cultural organisations and encourage research and development.
These amendments to the Act will not require any additional funds for implementation. Since the time of the McLeay Report the Council has put in place significant economies in its administration.

I am confident the amendments provide the impetus to carry the Australia Council forward into the nineties with a structure which is both responsive to changing needs and priorities and in line with prevailing community wishes.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the House of Representatives without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1990-91[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No.1) 1990-91APPROPRIATION BILL (No.2) 1990-91]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 November, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to reiterate the points I made in my speech before the adjournment debate last night which related to the appropriation for and associated matters concerning the Antarctic Division and the Commonwealth's presence in the Antarctic. Yesterday, I raised concerns about the tender for the Antarctic vessel Aurora Australis. In particular, I am very concerned about a decision taken in undue haste to charter a second ship, namely the Icebird, for the next three years. The decision to charter the Icebird for the 1990-91 season cannot be changed, regardless of any circumstances, but the decision taken to charter a second ship for the next three years should be reconsidered. The opportunity to charter the Russian vessel Akademik Federov seems financially advantageous. From private briefings I have had with the Director of the Antarctic Division and from what he has told me in Estimates committees, the Division would prefer to have control of its own vessel and of its own circumstances in the Antarctic. Nevertheless, at this point in history where we have peaceful cooperation with our Soviet friends it might be prudent for Australia to reconsider its attitude towards cooperation with the Russian scientists. I can think of no better way than using one of their up-to-date high-tech modern icebreakers, such as the Akademik Federov which was launched in only 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was in the Soviet Union recently with a parliamentary delegation I raised this matter with members of its parliaments and others and they were very keen to cooperate with Australia. That is natural, because they are in need of hard currency and foreign exchange. In Australia, we are in a rural crisis which we have just heard about from previous speakers. We are trying to place our wool, particularly with Russia, which has stopped buying it because of a shortage of funds. This is an ideal opportunity where we can barter trade with that country, to our advantage and to theirs.

With that short background, I will continue my remarks about some shortcomings in the tendering process for the charter of the second vessel. On 14 August 1990 Anderson Hughes Australia invited expressions of interest and firm proposals for providing a ship to the Antarctic Division for three seasons, 1991-92. The closing date for response was 7 September 1990. The matter is now under scrutiny. Several aspects of the actions of Anderson Hughes are a little unusual, to say the least. The first is that it is usual for an expression of interest to be sought first on the basis of an outline specification in order to establish a pre-qualified short list of interested bidders. When this process is complete, proposals are then sought from the short list to whom a more detailed specification and, just as importantly, a proposed charter party are provided.

My understanding is that the specification and details of the charterer's requirements provided in the invitation were sketchy, and there have been concerns as to whether they were sufficient to make the required firm proposal. As an example, the details provided did not mention the maximum operating draught of the vessel, which is normally 7.7 metres so that the ship can navigate the approaches to Australian stations.

My most serious concern is that, with no visible time constraints apparent, for some reason Anderson Hughes-one can only presume that it was at the behest of the Antarctic Division-allowed only three weeks to make firm proposals for a charter worth in excess of $10m which will not commence until mid-October 1991. It is very difficult to see how such a minimal amount of time can in any way serve Australia's best interests. I believe that such a time frame may have had the contrary effect and worked against our interests. The process by which proposals will be evaluated has not been divulged. However, Anderson Hughes has indicated that the Antarctic Division may seek tenders from specific vessels or owners, or may go out to open tender with the specific requirement. The whole process appears very vague and the material provided does not befit a $10m charter.

As I said earlier, when recently in Russia I spoke with the governors and politicians in the Khavarovsk and Primorsky prefectures. Because they face the Pacific, they are very interested in joint venturing and joint operations with Australia-not only in regard to vessels in the Antarctic but in terms of fishing. If we were to avail ourselves of the very generous offer that seems to have been made by the Soviets, there would be benefits not only to Australia but I believe to my own State of Tasmania, particularly the port of Hobart. We would have an opportunity to show the Soviets and other foreign countries that we are quite capable of providing very good services in refuelling, provedoring and bunkering for the vessels that come to our port. We will be able to prove that Hobart is not only a good jumping off place for Antarctica, but is also one of the leading ports for any international ships that wish to use our port as a forward post to move to their stations in Antarctica.

There have been many moves by both the previous State Government and the current Government in Tasmania to set up an Antarctic Centre and research facilities in Hobart. We already have the Antarctic Division and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation with significant operations in Hobart. I believe that, by encouraging ships from other nations to use Hobart as a last port of call to Antarctica, the port of Hobart and Australia will benefit.

I am not suggesting that Russian vessels should be given any particular commercial advantages, as it is obviously prudent for the Antarctic Division to choose the most economical and suitable vessels for the purpose. However, I believe that, when there are considerable advantages to be gained from the use of Russian vessels, such as the Akademik Federov, we would do well to undertake a thorough examination of the issues involved. I do not believe that the given period of three weeks was sufficient. It is my understanding that the tendering arrangements which Anderson Hughes implemented in this instance caused some difficulty for the Russians. I am sure that honourable senators would agree that it is almost impossible for detailed proposals to be sent from Russia in three weeks, particularly when it involves such a large amount of money. From my experience on the recent parliamentary delegation to that country, I found that communications were almost non-existent; it was impossible to telephone from one side of the country to the other. For us in Australia to expect the Russians to come up with firm proposals suitable to our conditions in as short a time as three weeks is not only impossible but does not work in the interests of either the Soviets or ourselves.

In conclusion, I would reiterate that, given the fact that Mr Hawke and Prime Minister Ryzhkov entered into negotiations when Mr Ryzhkov visited our country, the fact that we even issued a set of stamps highlighting the cooperation between the Soviets and the Australians in Antarctica, and the fact that in the past the Soviets have been very cooperative and helpful to Australian expeditions in the Antarctic by flying out some of our injured people, we would do well to cooperate with them in any way we possibly can because who knows when the situation may again arise when we need their help. Frankly, I do not believe that there are any other vessels or any other countries, apart from the United States, which is a fair distance removed from our bases in the Antarctic, which could help us in a meaningful way. I call upon the Government to do what it can to put some pressure on those responsible to look again at the offer made by the Soviets. Who knows, perhaps an arrangement may be made between our two countries that can be of assistance to us all and for the good of us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The economy is still the centre of debate in Australia and is crucial to the way of life we are able to pursue. The nearer we come to getting it right, the closer we are to the standard of living that we want for all the community. Economists, as their very name suggests, ought to be the ones best equipped to guide the community to where its material welfare is most happily provided for. They should be the ones able to set out the steps to be taken and to give encouragement to economic recovery in the country.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, the economists try to cure the material ills of the nation. They are forever writing prescriptions for it. During the eighties they have called for deregulation, for the floating of the dollar, for privatisation, for freedom of entry into the financial sector, for less government expenditure, for Budget surpluses, for unfettered buying and selling of companies, for uninhibited market forces, and for lower wages. As one mechanism is tried without returning the promised result, another is urged upon us as the ultimate answer to our economic woes. The latest is the deregulation of the labour market: if only that were done, all would be well.

Too many economists seem to see the world as a piece of machinery which can be happily controlled if the right lever is pulled. The Petty cartoons in the Age capture their thinking with exquisite accuracy: press the right button, push the correct pedal, find the appropriate gear, pull the steering wheel in the proper direction and all will be well. The only thing is that reliance simply on mechanical formulas never quite works. Though easy to proclaim, economics by rote falls short of success. It often requires mightily little evidence to satisfy proponents of ideologies, theories and intuitive insights of their validity.

There is need for a realistic and empirical appraisal of what would best advance Australia's prosperity. That involves more than working out the best way to operate economic levers. Changing interest rates, extending privatisation, impugning unionism, deregulating the labour market, lowering tariffs, selling equity overseas, increasing Budget surpluses, or reducing public expenditure will not by themselves bring about the happy state that we all want. Yet experts have an unhappy tendency to advocate that the economy be run on such robotic principles alone. The result of doing so will fall short of the one promised.

The best outcome will be gained where directors, management and the work force generally adopt common goals, readily undertake their tasks in cooperation, and are all dedicated to producing quality as well as quantity. For this to be achieved, a development is needed in our industrial culture. That involves matters of the heart and soul. It will not be achieved by resorting solely to economic levers. Japan and Germany have the strongest currencies in the world. They produce and export vast quantities of quality goods. They have the industrial culture that enables them to do so. A central dimension of that culture is the sound relationship that exists between those involved in the workplace.

It would be for everyone's good if industrial productivity could be improved in Australia. Any attempt to do so by employing identical processes to those used in Japan and Germany will be flawed. The social histories and cultures of the three countries are different, and trying to achieve reform here by employing means simply because they have been successful elsewhere is acting at odds with reality.

Media cover of the economy is prolific. Prescriptions for its cure come thick and fast. The common message is that Australia should produce more, particularly for sale overseas, and consume less in foreign goods and services. This is an easy strategy to proclaim, but a hard one to carry through.

Industrial gains are best obtained by enlisting the goodwill and dedication of directors, management and workers. This is unlikely to happen where force, fear, blame and censure are used as the primary impetus for change. Yet there is an unhappy tendency to employ one or more of these to improve Australia's production. Management berates the workers and their unions; workers berate management and their organisations. All censure the Government, and it can be moved to reply in kind.

Hostile criticism is apt to damage the spirit of cooperation and dedication that might otherwise exist between the groups needed to ensure Australia a sound economy. The adversarial climate in the workplace throughout the country does it harm. The events engendered by the procedures used for the handling of dichlorobenzidine at the Hoechst plant in Melbourne are evidence of this.

The accord, in its various stages, has sought to calm the turbulent course Australian industrial history has taken. It has striven to allay conflict, to encourage shared commitment and to increase productivity. It has successes to its credit, prominent among which is the improved climate in the workplace. It has achieved this while keeping to Australian culture and traditions. If it is abandoned, whatever is put in its place should preserve the gains it has made. Adopting a program that provokes conflict will serve the country badly.

Where each of the various groups involved in Australia's economy blames one or more of the others for its present state, there is danger that the endeavour needed for its improvement will not be undertaken by any. All the groups fall short at times of producing the best of which they are capable. Accordingly, each is susceptible to criticism by the others. But where those others concentrate on that criticism to the exclusion of a proper examination of their own shortcomings economic progress will be sadly hampered. While managers see workers as the sole brake to better productivity, while workers see managers in the same light, while private enterprise attributes all its problems to government, and while none feel moved to change their own conduct, reform will lag.

For one group to impugn the efforts of the others while avoiding any self-criticism may show a lack of confidence in its own abilities. Had it faith in those abilities, it might well exercise them to gain the success desired rather than seeking to excuse a feared failure to do so by laying the blame at the door of others. Where there is a fear of responsibility there is a readiness to displace it elsewhere.

Economists are apt to be delators. They admonish government for its policies, managers for their administration and workers for their industry. If their own prescriptions do not work it is usually because some group of people other than themselves has failed to act as it should: companies have invested unwisely, employees have received too much or governments have pursued wrong policies. People, unhappily, deviate from the fiscal and monetary path laid out by economic experts. They allow spiritual, social, cultural and political values to lead them astray. If only these things could be suppressed things would be better. Yet it is these values which are needed to assure Australia's future.

Long term prosperity will not come solely through the operations of fiscal and monetary levers, nor will it come by looking only to self-interest or greed. Without people generally having a commitment to high values, a sense of propriety, a generosity of purpose, a wide expanse of vision and a proper degree of tolerance, any lasting gains will be confined. These attitudes do not spring from economic theories but from values inherent in the spiritual, social and cultural convictions of a community. It would pay us to be more attentive to them.

In today's Melbourne Herald-Sun on pages 12 and 13 is the headline, `What our future holds'. Comments are set out by various people, including Barry Jones; the Archbishop of Brisbane, Peter Hollingworth; and Robert de Castella, Director of the Australian Institute of Sport. There is a photograph of Janine Haines, who formerly led the Australian Democrats in this place. The economy was commented on by Neville Norman, reader in economics at Melbourne University. There is a contribution by Professor Sir Gustav Nossal, the Director of the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research. There are also articles by Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, and Hugh Morgan, the Managing Director of the Western Mining Corporation.

The layout of the contributions these people make illustrates what Australia needs to do; that is, to face the problems that it presently has on a variety of fronts. It is not simply a matter of looking to economic principles alone to get us out of our present problems. The principles espoused by Archbishop Peter Hollingworth and other religious leaders, including people such as Archbishop Sir Frank Little in Melbourne, will lead us on to a sense of nationhood-if I can use that concept-and will lead us forward. I think it is time that we started to talk in those terms.

One of the great problems of economic hardship and economic downturn is that they tend to produce unhappy reactions. It is said that the first casualty in war is truth. As Mr Justice Vincent in Melbourne has said, one of the first casualties in hard economic times often is a proper sense of social morality. There is some danger that, where we do have an economic downturn, as is presently the position, the more lofty concepts that we would like to attach to ourselves as human beings tend to be diminished. Instead of looking to the future-this article in the Herald-Sun does that; it looks forward to the year 2040-we tend to look to our immediate problems.

The economic downturn that we are going through arose as a result of actions that were needed to stop an overheated economy that, had it not been slowed down, would have brought us to an unneeded disaster and a much greater struggle than we are presently going through to recover from. We had economic problems in Australia during the 1980s which had their origin, as has often been said, in previous decades, and those problems must be faced. This Government has taken steps, included in which is its high interest rate policy, to slow down the economy, not as a means of inflicting pain and distress on people-because the very statement of that proposition indicates that it is wrong, and no government of any colour would do that-but as a means of making Australia a prosperous, happy and well adjusted country in the future.

There are many things in Australia which this Government has contributed to producing which ought to be looked at in favourable terms and preserved. For example, Australia is among the most tolerant nation in the world. It has had a successful immigration program. Governments of both colours have contributed mightily to the nation. That is something that we should be more than proud of not only here but also in international circles. Australia has had, by and large, a very good judiciary which has inculcated a sense of fairness into the system. Again under governments of both colours, an administrative system has been developed which has reined in excesses that the Executive might otherwise have perpetrated. Through bodies such as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Commonwealth Ombudsman's office and the Social Security Appeals Tribunals, much has been done to bring fairness and justice into the system. That is something that we as Australians can be very proud of.

Our record on the environment has been quite outstanding by world standards. Again, that is something that we can be very proud of. The efforts that we have made to bring Aboriginals into the human circle have been quite outstanding. Senator Collins, who is sitting in front of me, has played a magnificent part in that. I am sure that Senator Collins will not be embarrassed by my saying that he has also been part of bringing structural adjustment to Australia and to its industry in a humane and civilised manner. The way he has gone about obtaining reforms on the waterfront is the way that we all, as Australians, should follow. He has attempted to do that not with a big stick and an aggression that must invoke one side to act against another, but in a way which will lead to lasting reform on the basis of agreement and where each side concedes what ought to be conceded and a lasting culture that will lead to productivity will develop.

I conclude by saying that in our debates in this chamber, and indeed in Australia, our problems should not be seen simply in economic terms and nor should they be answered purely in the principles of a sterile economic theory. When I say `sterile', I do not mean that the theories are necessarily wrong but that unless they are informed by some sort of spiritual, social or cultural dimension they are doomed to failure.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the assurances regarding the Tasmania Bank given by the Tasmanian Premier, Mr Field, the Tasmania Bank Board and the new Acting Managing Director of the bank, Mr Norman Holder. Given that the Tasmania Bank comes under the auspices of the Reserve Bank of Australia and meets all the prudential requirements of the Reserve Bank, could the Minister confirm that, in the unlikely event that the Tasmania Bank faced a solvency problem, assistance would be forthcoming from the Reserve Bank?

—On the basis of statements made by the Governor of the Reserve Bank and the Treasurer in relation to other banking situations, I think that the answer to the question is yes. But I would like to obtain a more detailed answer and I will try to do it by the end of Question Time.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS CONVENTION ON THE RIGHTS OF THE CHILD

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs aware that Mr and Mrs Stephen and Helen Bakker of Lavington have distributed a pamphlet in the Albury area making a number of allegations about the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child including claims that the Convention will become part of the law of Australia, that the signing of the Convention will dramatically alter the relationship between parents and child, that the proposals in the Convention will have the effect of taking away a large measure of control that parents now have over their children and that parents will have to give up their rights as parents? Is this typical of the false and misleading information that is being spread about Australia's being a signatory to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child? Can the Minister comment on the accuracy of these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Childs has kindly drawn my attention to a particular pamphlet apparently circulated by Mr and Mrs Bakker at Lavington. I must say that on reading the pamphlet I was shocked at its clearly misleading nature which will only upset and cause grave misgivings amongst otherwise good-intentioned people who will have, as I say, grave misgivings aroused by this pamphlet. For example, I notice that it says, amongst other things, that the effect of backing the Convention will be as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Parents are NOT ALLOWED to influence in any way a child's view on morality or religion-Article 14.
Article 14 in respect of the right of the child to freedom of thought, conscience and religion quite clearly states:
States Parties shall respect the rights and duties of the parents and, when applicable, legal guardians, to provide direction to the child in the exercise of his or her right-
that is, in relation to freedom of thought, conscience and religion-
in a manner consistent with the evolving capacities of the child.
Nothing could be clearer.
It is quite evident that Stephen and Helen Bakker have decided to arouse these misgivings in the community either because they are invincibly ignorant and illiterate or because of a malicious intent.

It would be incredible, would it not, for the Holy See to be amongst the first of the States parties to ratify this Convention were it to have the effect claimed in this particular pamphlet that children are to be torn from the bosom of their parents and subjected to the totalitarian regime of some nation state. The Holy See said:

The Holy See regards the convention as a proper and laudable instrument for protecting the rights and interests of children. By choosing to be among the first in acceding to the convention, the Holy See would like to encourage all countries and peoples to join in assuring legal protection and effective support to the well being of all the children of the world.

One may add to that that many organisations in Australia, including of course the Uniting Church in Australia and Mrs Rosemary Sinclair, who heads a nationwide organisation most concerned about the abuse of children in our community, have given their support to this particular Convention and Australia's role in relation to it.

Of course, Australia's role in relation to this Convention has been one that has particularly ensured that the rights and responsibilities of parents are acknowledged. Indeed, an article was inserted into the Convention precisely to achieve that particular effect. Article 5 of the Convention was inserted at Australia's initiative. It requires States parties to respect the responsibilities, rights and duties of parents or others legally responsible for the child to provide, in a manner consistent with the evolving capacities of the child, appropriate direction and guidance in the child's exercise of the rights recognised in the Convention.

When one looks at the totality of the Convention one certainly sees that we have an international benchmark against which nations that sign and then ratify the Convention can be judged in the international community. By itself, even ratification-and Australia has not yet ratified the Convention but has signed it-does not make the Convention part of the law of Australia; action is still required by the elected parliaments of this nation responsible to the electorate before the Convention can become part of the laws of Australia or any of the States.

I noted that the Liberal Federal Council dealt with this matter. I do not want to arouse any partisan issue, but it is important to note that contributors to the debate at that national council meeting of the Liberal Party, such as Senator Robert Hill, played a very outstanding role in explaining to delegates the true significance of this particular Convention. Senator Hill has dealt very honourably with this particular debate.

This pamphlet that is circulating will only unsettle people. I hope that they will take some reassurance from the support, from major organisations which are much concerned with the welfare of children in Australia, for the signing of this particular Convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It arises from the call by the parliamentary Left, under the hand of Senator Childs and Senator McKiernan representing 31 members of the Australian Labor Party Caucus, for the United Nations Security Council to sponsor an international peace conference on the Gulf. Would not the setting up of such a conference whilst Iraq continues to occupy Kuwait give comfort to Saddam Hussein in his invasion and occupation of another sovereign nation?

—I have to say, with all due regard to my colleagues, that not only on that issue but on a number of other matters raised in that particular document, the contribution of the parliamentary Left does not reflect Government policy and does not reflect our judgment as to what would be helpful or desirable in the resolution of the current Iraqi crisis.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the murder in New York of the founder of the Jewish Defence League, Rabbi Meir Kahane. Does the Australian Government have any information about the likely social and political ramifications in Israel and the Middle East in general of the Rabbi's death?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.
