TALK.START.PARA: —I and the Government, as I am sure is the case elsewhere in the chamber, deplore the murder in New York yesterday of the Jewish activist, Rabbi Meir Kahane, just as we deplore the use of senseless violence anywhere. In saying this, I naturally do not in any way endorse the views and activities of the late Rabbi Kahane, which were extreme, unpalatable and incompatible with peaceful resolution of the Arab-Israeli dispute and which themselves, it has to be said, did tragically contribute to the cycle of violence in Israel. I also make the point that Rabbi Kahane, who advocated the expulsion of the Palestinian population from Israel and the occupied territories, was not representative of mainstream Israeli opinion.

ANSWER.PARA: He became a member of the Israeli Knesset in the 1984 elections with one-eightieth of the popular vote and his movement was in fact banned in 1988 on the grounds that it was racist and undemocratic. Despite his limited appeal to Israelis, his murder nonetheless could obviously provoke retributive acts of violence in the occupied territories and Israel in the current tense climate. In fact, it is the case that two Palestinians are reported to have been murdered in the occupied territories overnight, possibly in response to Rabbi Kahane's death. We of course deplore those deaths as well.

I say again that I hope that both Israelis and Palestinians will realise that further violence on top of what is now more than 30 deaths on both sides in the past month cannot possibly help the situation in Israel and the occupied territories and will only make the task of achieving a peaceful settlement more difficult. The Australian Government calls again on both sides to refrain from actions that will worsen the situation. I urge Israeli authorities, in particular, to ensure the protection of Palestinians from any possible acts of revenge in response to Rabbi Kahane's murder.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONFERENCE ON SECURITY AND COOPERATION IN ASIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to his recent proposal for a Conference on Security and Cooperation in Asia (CSCA). I ask: Does the Minister share the view of many specialists in international relations that a regional security forum such as this should allow all nations around the Pacific Basin to be represented? Does the Minister accept that the establishment of such a forum is made more necessary by the prospect of increased arms spending in the region and more possible by unprecedented advances in regional conflict resolution, especially in Cambodia and Korea? Given that the establishment of such a forum would require substantial resources, what resources would the Minister intend to commit on behalf of the Australian Government to the development and promotion of this proposal? Finally, what response has the concept of a Conference on Security and Cooperation in Asia had from regional states and, in particular, the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Japan, Indonesia and Vietnam?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I have been, as Senator Bourne said, one of those people who have been generating discussion about a possible Asian equivalent to the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE), I do not think it is appropriate to jump too quickly to conclusions as to what, if any, particular institutional structure might be appropriate in the Asian region in order to advance the cause of regional security. It is my view that countries in this region, including Australia, need to look ahead to the kind of new institutional processes that might evolve over time as an appropriate framework for the discussion and handling of security issues. It is obvious that if such a regional security forum or structure does evolve it would be very desirable, to answer the honourable senator's first question, that all countries in the Asia-Pacific region be represented there.

ANSWER.PARA: I agree that the rapid changes that are occurring in the global and regional strategic environments, including recent advances in conflict resolution, have important implications for the region as a whole and these changes reinforce the view that current arrangements, or indeed the absence of any integrated regional security arrangements as distinct from a multiplicity of bilateral ones, will not equip us as well as we could be equipped to handle what is likely to become a very much more fluid strategic environment in our region over the next few years. It is in that context that I and others in the region have been suggesting that perhaps it is time for some new thinking about all of this.

The response so far to suggestions of a CSCA-type concept has been mixed, but there is a growing recognition by countries in the region of the need for enhanced processes of dialogue on security issues-which is, after all, what this is all about. Nobody, least of all me, assumed that there was any easy translation possible between the CSCE and the CSCA, simply because of the totally different strategic environments-a single frontier in Europe versus multiple frontiers and multiple ideological conflicts and so on in our part of the world. The Association of South East Asian Nations member countries have been emphasising the primacy of the concept of a zone of peace, freedom and neutrality, or ZOPFAN, in South East Asia. The Soviet Union has put forward a proposal for a meeting of all regional Foreign Ministers in 1993 with a lead-up process to that. The United States has had a somewhat more reserved approach to these issues but it is indicating that it is open to discussion. Japan has particular security concerns which again we need to take into account. A number of countries have taken the view-not totally unreasonably-that it is better to develop these processes of dialogue at bilateral and subregional levels and then evolve something out of that.

I think the common thread in all of this, and a view which I think we all ought to endorse, is that the priority at the moment is the development in the region of a shared sense of strategic and security interests and the development of new patterns of cooperation, including the development of confidence-building measures of various kinds in the region from which greater confidence in the regional security environment will grow and perhaps lead ultimately to a wider regional structure. With regard to resources, obviously it is premature to be committing financial resources to something which is in this early stage of evolution, although we have committed significant diplomatic resources to the task of determining how Australia might best participate in strengthened dialogues in regional issues in the way in which I have been describing, and how it might most effectively promote the development of a sense of regional community and shared security interests. These will remain important priorities for us in this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to a statement made yesterday by the parliamentary Left of his own Party. Given that the Minister himself also said yesterday that `the military strike option must remain available' and that `the stakes are such . . . that war simply cannot be ruled out', is the Minister concerned that this position, so clearly stated yesterday, is undermined by the statement of his own colleagues that they were `emphatically opposed to a first strike by US forces'? Will the Minister also affirm that, contrary to the demands of the parliamentary Left, the Government has not ruled out further military involvement by Australia in the event of war breaking out in the Gulf? I also ask: If the Government cannot maintain solidarity within its own Party on this subject, how can it expect to maintain international solidarity?
—I do not honestly think that the position of the Government is likely to be undermined by this particular contribution to the debate by the parliamentary Left.
—You simply ignore them.

—No, I say that with the authority of somebody from the parliamentary Left who told me that I should not really take too much notice of it because nobody else will-which shows a significant advance in the analytical capacity of my colleagues, if nothing else. With regard to the remaining elements of the question, I think they are essentially hypothetical and there is nothing more I can add to what I said yesterday on that subject.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister made a very firm statement yesterday that, despite the hopes and qualifications he expressed, the stakes were such that war simply could not be ruled out. I ask the Minister whether he has the same view in relation to further Australian military involvement in the event of that occurring? It is not a hypothetical question.

—I have not changed the view that I have expressed on record. Any question about the nature of an Australian response, both with existing resources in the Gulf region or any conceivable additional resources, is entirely hypothetical. It is not a matter about which it is appropriate to speculate in advance of any of those conditions being satisfied which would give rise to the issue as a real one.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of the manoeuvres in the upper House of the Western Australian Parliament by the National and Liberal parties to block legislation for daylight saving which would bring Western Australia into line with eastern States? What is the effect on labour costs in the finance, communications and aviation industries which are required to alter their hours of work to fit in with the whims of the Western Australian Nationals and Liberals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October all of the States of Australia except Western Australia advanced their clocks by one hour to introduce daylight saving. Western Australia did not do that. There is now a three-hour time gap between Western Australia and all the other eastern States in Australia, and a 2 1/2-hour time gap between South Australia and Western Australia. It means that at 9 a.m. in Perth it is midday here, and at 5 p.m. here it is 2 p.m. there, meaning that there is a five-hour working day, effectively, because of the refusal of Western Australia to join the rest of Australia in introducing daylight saving.

ANSWER.PARA: I should report that the Lawrence Government proposed a Bill to the Western Australian Legislative Council, which is a body that has a National Party and Liberal majority, and that Bill was not given a first reading. A response to the position of the coalition in Western Australia is best illustrated by my quoting an article from the West Australian of 17 October as follows:
Big business has vowed to step up its fight for daylight saving in WA after the Liberal Party yesterday rejected a proposal to put clocks forward in summer to match the eastern states.
The WA Chamber of Commerce and the Confederation of WA Industry warned that the issue was not dead and foreshadowed a stronger public campaign next year to win support.
It goes on to say:
Confederation executive director Lyndon Rowe said WA's main trading partner, Japan, was an hour ahead of WA and daylight saving would put the Japanese on the same time.

He was thus refuting the key argument advanced by Mr McKinnon, the Leader of the Opposition, that Western Australia moved more with the Asian time zone than it did with the eastern States of Australia.

The Confederation of Western Australian Industry, representing all of the major employers in Western Australia, and the Chamber of Commerce and the Stock Exchange in Western Australia have supported daylight saving and supported the Australian Government in seeking to introduce it into Western Australia. In opposing the actions of the Legislative Council in that State I think most Federal members, who have to put up with the jet lag induced by the three-hour time difference, also would support daylight saving. I should also mention that on popular radio, particularly 6PR and the Howard Sattler show, there has been a stream of calls in support of daylight saving in Western Australia.

The effect on industry is quite profound, particularly industries associated with transport and communications, where new shift rosters have to be reworked to fit Western Australia into the rest of the civilised States of Australia. In particular, given Western Australia's hot summer, opportunities for workers to start earlier in the cooler part of the day and not work through the hotter part of the day have been passed up by this refusal by the Western Australian upper House. I add that, of course, daylight saving is a positive feature in reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

No better example of the impact on Western Australian industry and business of refusing to move to daylight saving can be given than in the sporting field. Over the last few months Western Australians have been proud of the performance of the West Coast Eagles in the Victorian Football League, but they all recognised that the distances the team had to travel and the time zones it had to traverse affected its performance. They are also proud of the performance of the Perth Wildcats, who won the National Basketball League title, but recognise that in the three-round play-offs it lost its first matches in the semi-final in Melbourne and the Grand Final in Brisbane, but won its concluding matches--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Cook, I really think you are straying too far outside the question that you were asked.

—On a point of order, Mr President: I have to agree with you and support you. Senator Cook is a Minister in the Federal Government, not a Minister for the Western Australian Government. The points that he is making at the moment have no relevance for this Parliament whatsoever, and would you please pull him to order?
—I have already done that, Senator Boswell.

—I will conclude by saying that I was merely illustrating the impact that time zones can have on sporting performance, and saying that that is an impact that it could have, too, on business performance, whereby Western Australian businessmen are expected to labour under the handicap of the unchanged time zones. I hope that the Legislative Council in Western Australia will come to its senses and do the right thing by the State.

—I have a further question for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade in view of the seriousness of the matters raised yesterday by his colleagues. The aspect that I want to refer to is that the document stated that there should be no alteration to the clearly stated purpose for which the Australian naval capacity is employed in the Gulf conflict. I ask the Minister: in the event of a first strike by the opposing forces-which, of course, has not been ruled out-do the clearly stated purposes include Australian participation in that deployment? Secondly, is it true, as the document said, that the Prime Minister has agreed to first consult with the Left before any further involvement is contemplated by the Government?

—The stated purpose of the deployment at the moment is no more and no less than assisting in the enforcement of sanctions. It does not extend to any wider conflict. That is why a decision would need to be made by the Australian Government as to how we would react to any such wider conflict, in the first instance, as I said, with our own resources already there, and, as a subsidiary question which might conceivably arise, what other wider reaction we might have. But all those questions are entirely hypothetical and entirely contingent on circumstances which have not yet occurred, and I do not propose to speculate as to what our policy response might be. I have nothing further to add on the latter part of the question.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question which I will ask anyway. Accepting what the Minister has just said, before a further decision is made, has the Prime Minister agreed that he would first consult with the Left?

—No, he has not agreed to consult with the Left about that particular decision. He simply said -and this was a commitment clearly and publicly made to the Party and everyone else-that before there was any change in the nature of the deployment we would engage in such consultations as are appropriate and possible in all the circumstances. That is true, and that would continue to apply. But what might be possible in a very fast moving situation is very difficult to anticipate. Equally, of course, we would hope, in this sort of situation, to be able to consult with the Leader of the Opposition.
—He didn't last time.

—We would hope to be able to do so. It may not prove either appropriate or possible in the particular circumstances. One cannot speculate about any of these contingencies at this stage, and it is mischievous to invite me to do that.

—My question is for the Minister for Social Security. Can the Minister indicate whether there have been any positive outcomes in respect of indexation of British pensions in Australia? Are there prospects for reciprocal social security agreements with Greece and Turkey? Are these developments a consequence of the Minister's recent talks with his European counterparts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I am sure honourable senators would be aware, there are something like 130,000 British pensioners in this country who do not have any indexation of British pensions, which is a little disturbing, given that Great Britain has signed agreements agreeing to indexation with a whole range of countries around the world including, most recently, the Philippines. That we do not rank with them is a source of some ire. It means, of course, that British pensioners who came here many years ago stay on the same level of pension that they brought into the country on the day they arrived. That brings about inequities and, of course, extra costs for the Australian Government in supplementing the often meagre amount that some of these pensioners receive.

ANSWER.PARA: When I was in London a few weeks ago I signed a new agreement between Australia and Great Britain. While it does not bring about indexation, it was an advance in that at least it removes from the agreement between the two countries the underwriting of the British refusal to index those pensions. The fact that Great Britain agreed to remove that clause does, I think, give us some hope for the future.

I did discuss with the Minister for Social Security in Great Britain, Mr Newton-at least he was then; there has been a reshuffle in the last few days and I am not sure whether he is still the Minister-a number of options which the British Government might like to undertake short of granting full indexation, which would cost it $250m in a full year and which it says it cannot agree to do in one hit now.

I did discuss with him a number of options short of that which would at least give an indication to British pensioners in Australia that the British Government is moving in that direction. While I received no undertaking that my suggestions would be taken up, they were certainly to be considered and I hope that in the course of the next few months we will get some positive response. I also put them to the Opposition spokesman in Great Britain, Mr Meacher.

In respect of Greece and Turkey, which I also visited, the Greek Minister, Mrs Giannakou, was very encouraging in the way that she conducted our discussions. There will be a delegation coming from Greece in the next few weeks. Mrs Giannakou is very confident that a reciprocal agreement between the two countries can be negotiated and signed prior to 1 July next year. She believes that the hurdles which we were previously unable to jump-namely, those which restricted the movement of currency out of Greece-have been removed and that her Government will be moving very quickly to sign the reciprocal agreement, which Australia has indicated it would seek to sign.

The indications in respect of Turkey were also good-probably not as hopeful as those from Greece, but hopeful nonetheless. While the Turkish Minister, Dr Aykut, suggested that there may be some hurdles still to jump, negotiations will be conducted in February and she is also keen that we proceed. I made it very clear that no negotiations would take place with either Greece or Turkey until our Government had received a concrete undertaking in writing from each of their governments that the currency restrictions which applied in both countries had been removed. I am confident that those assurances will be received and I believe we can look forward with hope to signing agreements with those two countries at some stage in the next 12 months.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to his answer to a question from Senator Michael Baume on 13 September 1990, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The decision to commit Commonwealth funds to the Melbourne Olympic Games bid in terms of the Albert Park project was subject to an interdepartmental committee decision . . .

I repeat, `was subject to an interdepartmental committee decision'. In light of the Cabinet decision of 23 January 1990, which I tabled in the Senate on 19 October and which shows that the funding decision was not in any way `subject to' decision by an interdepartmental committee, will the Minister now acknowledge that he has misled the Parliament and apologise to the Senate?

TALK.START.PARA: —I was brought up in the tradition that one never resigns or apologises. I will look at the decision to which the honourable senator refers and the answer which I gave. Let me say that the decision made by the Cabinet-and I answered the question here on the basis of my recollection-is simply this: Cabinet was very clearly of a mind to make a commitment to support the Melbourne Olympic Games bid, and that the amount to be made available for the purpose of supporting that Olympic Games bid should be the subject of examination by an interdepartmental committee to make sure it was appropriate and not exceeded. That is the basis of the answer I gave. The honourable senator can table all the documents he likes, but I will not change that answer.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer, but as to his statement that he will not change that answer, I understand from the earlier part of his answer to me that he will in fact check the record not only of what he said but also of the Cabinet decision. I expect, and I am sure the Senate expects, that if in fact what the Minister said in response on 13 September, based on his understanding at the time, did not accord with the facts, he will acknowledge that he misled Parliament and apologise accordingly.
—I think we are descending into a game of verbal tootsies here as to what the expression `subject to' in fact means. I would have thought--
—It is pretty clear to me.
—It may be clear to Senator Short, but let me come back with an answer: I think it is pretty clear to me too.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, and it concerns cervical cancer screening. I draw the Minister's attention to a recent unpublished Government report publicised in the Adelaide evening newspaper, the News, on 2 November, in which it was stated that pap smear screening has `major shortcomings' and only half the preventable cases are being stopped. My question is simply this: Does the Minister believe that a problem exists? Secondly, if the answer is yes, what is the Government planning to do to prevent this problem from worsening?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Quite clearly, the Federal Government gives a high priority to the prevention of cervical cancer. Of course, it is susceptible to prevention strategies. I know that senators from all sides of the chamber have taken an interest in this matter, particularly in Estimates committees. My good friend and colleague Senator Walters, for example, understands this to be a major matter.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1987 the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council (AHMAC) commissioned the cervical cancer screening evaluation committee to oversee a $2.5m Commonwealth-funded evaluation of existing cervical cancer screening programs and services and to develop strategies to encourage greater participation in screening programs by those women most at risk of the disease. The report prepared by that evaluation committee was considered by AHMAC at the end of October. It identified, and Senator Foreman has alluded to this, a number of problems with the present screening arrangements and made a number of recommendations about how to improve their effectiveness.

Problems identified include the fact that, despite the fact that pap smears have been available to Australian women since the 1960s on a fee for service basis and at negligible cost to women since 1984 as a consequence of the availability of Medicare rebates, only 50 per cent of lives threatened by cervical cancer are being saved when 90 per cent is an achievable figure. Many of the 350 women who die of cervical cancer every year have never had a smear test. Tragically, over three-quarters of all deaths from cervical cancer occur in women over 50, the group with the lowest rate of pap smears. There are other problems also in the program.

The evaluation committee believes that a much better directed and efficient cervical cancer screening effort could be achieved by addressing the issues of recruitment, recall and follow-up, quality control, management of abnormal smears, laboratory costs and monitoring data collection and evaluation. Such an organised approach would not only save double the number of lives, it is estimated, but cost less than current government expenditure, which is extensive- I think some $125m a year.

The Government as a result will undertake extensive consultations on proposals outlined in the report to improve Australia's cervical cancer screening efforts. Implementation of such a coherent strategy is regarded as an absolute priority, and I believe that by next March, when all health Ministers meet to consider this matter, the Federal Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Brian Howe, will be in a position to inform them of a better directed strategy which will help prevent the needless loss of the lives of so many Australian women.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In light of the fact that Australia's new Antarctic vessel, Aurora Australis, is now limping its way around the Antarctic continent powered by its smaller No.2 engine, I ask the Minister to provide details as to the nature and cause of the mechanical problems which have delayed the Aurora Australia and the reasons why the vessel was not carrying a spare coupling between the main engine and the gearbox, a procedure which I believe is considered standard practice on such a vessel. Further, is it not a fact that this problem would have been averted if the Aurora Australis had been fitted with a skeg and ice knives to protect the propeller and rudder, a design feature which was recommended by some of P and O Polar's specialist technical advisers and apparently rejected by P and O and the Antarctic Division? Finally, can the Minister give an assurance that the Aurora Australis will be modified to have these features with a view to protecting the safety of Australian expeditioners and the viability of our ongoing Antarctic research programs?
—I am not aware of the details of the mechanical problems or of what design suggestions may have been made about protective skin. I will find out and try to let the honourable senator know tomorrow.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. It relates to executive salary levels. What support and results has the Government had in its efforts to encourage executive salary increases to reflect the restraint that workers have been exercising in the past seven years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the comments now made by Mr Howard and Mr Hewson in identifying as an area of excessive growth the area of executive salaries. I hope that it is a salutary lesson to them that before they knee jerk out of prejudice into calling for restraint from the sector of the work force that has exercised restraint they should in future review the evidence impartially of where restraint has been practised and where it has not.

ANSWER.PARA: I quoted yesterday from a Cullen Egan Dell Australia Pty Ltd survey of the percentages of increase in executive level remuneration compared with that of wages. I wish now to table in the Senate some tables of further evidence of problems with excessive executive level salary growth. This is evidence culled from 23 annual reports of the largest companies in Australia. They show that the total directors' remuneration for this group of companies, comparing performance in 1988 and 1989, was $245m all told, which was 16.5 per cent more than the previous year. This compares to a growth in average weekly earnings of 7.4 per cent for the same period.

This establishes that an average increase for directors of holding companies in 1989 was more than 22 per cent. It shows that four of the 23 companies reduced executive remuneration in the period, three were at the same level as for ordinary workers or less, but 16 of the companies were higher than the rates paid to the ordinary work force. In four of the 23 companies, directors' remuneration rose by 50 per cent; in 12 of the 23 companies directors got increases of more than 20 per cent; and the total remuneration for the 10 highest paid executives of the 23 companies rose by more than 17 per cent, to nearly $110m all up, between the years, as I have said, 1988 and l989.

I have heard Mr Howard talk about the need to restrain executive level incomes, but some of the reports are quite confusing. It is not clear whether he is proposing to do that by wrapping it into the national wage case when it is held and therefore obtain some ruling, if he is able to, to do away with the leave loading compulsorily. But if he is proposing that, we would be looking at, on the one hand, a compulsory removal of the benefit for workers while, on the other hand, whispering sweetly into the ears of executives that they should volunteer to forgo executive remuneration. I do not think that is a level of equal treatment. But I am not quite sure whether Mr Howard is saying that because, in other interviews that I have heard from him, he seems to be saying that this should be negotiated on a plant by plant basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The Minister is not entitled to use Question Time for the purposes of making a statement. Clearly, he attempted yesterday to put material on the record and he is trying to do it again today. If he has got something he wishes to make by way of a statement he should choose the appropriate time or table the document. Let us get on with Question Time.
—Order! There is no point of order. It is clearly within the Minister's area of responsibility.

—If it was a plant by plant negotiation certainly it would be fairer because obviously the workers would want to know what the remuneration of their employers was. However, I point out that section 115 of the Act enables this procedure to be conducted for certified agreements based on a plant basis. Mr Howard does not seem to understand that.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prices Surveillance Authority is a body in which there can be some scrutiny of the impact of excessive executive remuneration. The idea is that when price increases are applied for the Surveillance Authority should inquire to see whether companies are observing national wage fixing guidelines and to see what the level of executive remuneration might be before granting a price increase. If the executive remuneration were excessive, obviously it would consider docking the price increase to penalise the company for excessive salary increases.

I intend to speak to Mr Crean, the Minister responsible in this area, to see whether there can be, in the Prices Surveillance Authority reports, a clearer setting out of information on exactly what is occurring in executive remuneration-particularly in those companies that apply for price increases-and to see whether there are ways in which we can penalise companies who rip off on executive salaries while expecting their workers to abide by the wage fixing guidelines. In view of what Mr Howard and Mr Hewson have said, I hope they will support me in this endeavour and renounce--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The Minister clearly takes Question Time as a time to abuse the privilege of the Parliament. The Standing Orders clearly say that he is not entitled to debate the question and that at all times the answer must be relevant to the question only and be succinctly put. Clearly, he is out of order and I ask you, Mr President, to ask him to wind up his dialogue.
—Order! The Minister's answer is in order but I do take the point that, again, he is making a very long answer and I ask him to conclude.

—I will conclude with one sentence, or maybe two, or perhaps a short paragraph. I hope Mr Hewson and Mr Howard will now support me and that the coalition will drop its claim to abolish the Prices Surveillance Authority and remove one of the ways in which executive remuneration can be regulated.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and concerns the proposal to increase the tax on Australia's livestock industries to 100 per cent of the cost of abattoir inspection services in contrast to the 60 per cent the industry currently pays. I remind the Minister that this decision will be borne by the sheep and cattle industries, which are already experiencing severely depressed returns. Is the Minister aware of the May 1988 statement `Primary industries and resources: Policies for growth', where it was stated:

QUESTION.PARA: In recognition of the national benefit attained through inspection of both export and domestic products the Government will continue to meet a proportion of the costs.

I also ask the Minister, in light of the already financially struggling primary industry sector, and in light of its previous commitment: will the Government reconsider the introduction of this tax and honour its policy by maintaining at least the current contribution of 40 per cent of the cost base of abattoir inspection services?

TALK.START.PARA: —What I understand Senator Bjelke-Petersen--
—Mr Cook.
—It is Senator Cook.
—Then Dr Hewson.

—I apologise to Dr Hewson if I called him Mr Hewson. I am sure that that is not a monumental offence, but I apologise. What I understand Senator Bjelke-Petersen to be asking is that ordinary Australian taxpayers should pay for an inspectorial service at abattoirs to guarantee the quality to export level of carcasses that are being exported there for the purposes of returning a dividend to the agents or to the farmers. The question being addressed therefore is: Is it right that those who receive an income from the inspectorial service because of their ability to sell at higher quality or higher levels into other markets should pay, or should taxpayers pay part of what Senator Bjelke-Petersen calls a tax? In the circumstances the Australian Government has decided to phase in full cost recovery to the users of the service, so that the users pay rather than the broader Australian electorate. I think that that is a reasonable thing to do and in the circumstances I do not have anything else to add to the answer.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In other words, the Government is going back on what it said in May 1988 that, in recognition of the national benefit obtained through the inspection of both domestic and export products, the Government will continue to meet a proportion of the cost. Is that correct?

—As I said, we have been phasing in cost recovery and in 1988 it was appropriate to take those steps. We think in the circumstances now, given the notice of this, that it is appropriate for primary producers and not taxpayers to take the cost of inspectorial services.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery on my left of a parliamentary delegation from the Republic of the Marshall Islands, led by the Speaker of the Congress, Senator the Honourable Kessai Note. On behalf of all honourable senators I welcome you to the Senate and trust that your visit to Australia is both enjoyable and informative.

—I address my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer him to the aircraft accident report of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation on 5 January 1990 involving a Qantas 747 jet flying from Sydney to Singapore on 1 June 1989 in which 65 people were injured. I ask the Minister: Firstly, is it true that the aircraft was out of control for two to three minutes before the captain and the first officer regained control? Secondly, is it true that the incident was primarily due to a chronic fault in the plane's autopilot system which had not been repaired despite having malfunctioned on several previous occasions? Thirdly, is it true that the flight crew were not aware of these previous malfunctions despite a common practice for flight crews to acquaint themselves with an aircraft's history? Fourthly, is it true that the situation was worsened by a delayed and inappropriate response by the aircraft's flight crew? Finally, in light of this, what action has the Civil Aviation Authority taken to ensure that a similar combination of error and fault will not again threaten the lives of passengers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer each one of those five questions in order. The answer to the first part of the question is no, it is not true that the aircraft was out of control for two to three minutes. I will explain that by answering part 4 in a minute which in fact is a repeat of that question whether the incident was worsened by an inappropriate response from the captain and first officer. The aircraft was not out of control for two to three minutes.

ANSWER.PARA: Was it true that the incident was caused by a chronic fault in the autopilot that had not been repaired? No, that assertion is not true, either. It is a fact that the autopilot on board the 747, which is an extremely complex piece of equipment, had had an intermittent fault in it previously, but it is not true that it had not been repaired. The autopilot had in fact been checked out as serviceable before the flight. I might add that these autopilots on board these aircraft are incredibly complex pieces of equipment which is why 747s carry three autopilot systems, that is, one system and two backup systems, because of their complexity and because they do fault from time to time.

Is it true that the flight crew were not aware that the equipment had malfunctioned despite a common practice of air crew making themselves familiar with the maintenance history of aircraft? Frankly, I do not understand that question because air crew, particularly in companies with large flights, routinely move from shift to shift from aircraft to aircraft. There is absolutely no requirement on the flight crew to have any knowledge at all of an aircraft's maintenance history. Before the flight the air crew accept an aircraft with an engineering clearance which in fact certifies that that aircraft is in every respect airworthy and ready for flight. There is no responsibility on the flight crew to be aware of any malfunction on any aircraft.

The fourth part of the question was in fact a repeat of the first one-whether the incident was exacerbated by a delayed and an inappropriate response by the captain and first officer. The answer to that question is also that that is untrue. The flight crew in fact behaved very promptly and with the proper action. What they did when the autopilot malfunctioned was to immediately transfer the aircraft to manual control. When the aircraft was under control they then switched in a second autopilot system.

The fifth part of the question was whether the Civil Aviation Authority has taken appropriate action to ensure that this does not happen again. The answer to that question is that I do not know. It is obvious from my answer that I have received the initial report on this incident from the Bureau of Air Safety Investigations. But I have not had time yet to speak to the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) about what action they have taken but I will. I would expect to find out, as I have on previous occasions, that the CAA on this occasion, and because of the seriousness of the incident and the injuries that occurred, has done what it normally does, that is, taken whatever action is appropriate. But I will, of course, personally check that and advise the senator of the answer to it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask the Minister about a press conference he gave in Islamabad on Sunday, 5 August-three months ago. Did he not directly address the question of the Australian sale of 50 Mirage aircraft to Pakistan? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the Pakistan newspaper Dawn the next day which states:

QUESTION.PARA: Australian Foreign Minister Gareth Evans admitted on Sunday that the 50 mothballed Mirages that were to be delivered to Pakistan by Canberra within six months from April 1990 when the contract was signed by the two countries would now be supplied sometime early next year.

Answering a question at a Press conference here on Sunday, the Australian Foreign Minister clearly attempted to play down the reasons for the delay in the delivery, but could not completely satisfy those who thought the slippage was somehow linked to the Indian objections to the deal.

Having alienated India one week he was alienating Pakistan the next. Will the Minister explain how both the Indian External Affairs Minister and the press of Pakistan came to understand the same matter, that is, the matter denied yesterday by the Minister in Senate Question Time that he communicated to the Indian Government that the supply of Mirage aircraft would be delayed until 1991?

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess all I can say is that what I said at the press conference did not translate too well into Urdu, because I certainly did not say in those terms that the aircraft would now be supplied next year. In fact, because it was drawn to my attention, I did see that report in the Dawn newspaper a day or so later, and it led to me to remark that the newspaper ought be renamed the `False Dawn' in light of that particular report. It just misunderstood the point that I made, which was exactly the same point that I made in India publicly and privately and that I retailed yesterday, namely, that there was no question of any new agreement to have delivery delayed until early in the new year. There was no question of any undertaking or assurance that the delivery be delayed until early 1991. It was just a question of it being assumed by me and by the Australian Government that it would be likely that the delivery would be delayed until then because of the absence of movement until that point on behalf of the Pakistani Government. People do get things wrong, as I think even Senator Teague in his least charitable moments would acknowledge. The detail of that particular position was simply not accurately reported.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS CONVENTION ON THE RIGHTS OF THE CHILD

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer to his answer to Senator Childs's question on the Convention on the Rights of the Child when he used in support of the Government's position the accession of the Holy See to the convention. However, when acceding to the convention, the Holy See actually made several reservations, one of which in respect of parental rights was:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . that it-
that is the Holy See-

interprets the articles of the Convention in a way that safeguards the primary and inalienable rights of parents, in particular insofar as these rights concern education, religion, association with others and privacy.

In view of that, is it fair for the Government to go around quoting the Holy See in support of its position, unless the Government intends to make those reservations? Is the Minister aware that, aside from some outlandish reasons given both for support and opposition to the treaty, there have been valid questions raised by informed critics of the convention which do require Government consideration, clarification and action? Would the Minister agree that tabling the Rights of the Child Convention in this Parliament almost a year after it was made in New York is not a satisfactory situation, particularly when at present there is no opportunity for this Parliament to debate it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter point, to my knowledge the Convention on the Rights of the Child has been subject to exhaustive discussion within Estimates committees over several years. It seems to me that there honourable senators have had more than adequate opportunity to acquaint themselves with the terms of the convention and with the process which led to it being formulated in the way in which it was finally put forward for signature and ratification.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the role of the Holy See and its note accompanying the accession of the Holy See to the convention, it is true that it indicated its understanding of the convention as requiring the pre-eminent role of the family to be properly recognised. That accords very much with the Australian Government's position. I anticipate that when the Australian Government ratifies the convention, should it do so, one would find that those same understandings as to the pre-eminent role of the family would be acknowledged. It would be surprising were that not the case, given the fact that Australia inserted article 5, meaning that for the first time in the international community a document was open to ratification which recognised that pre-eminent role of the family, parents or legal guardians in giving guidance and direction to children in accordance with their evolving capacities.

Senator Harradine is correct to say that there are those who support the convention, such as the Catholic Bishops in Australia, who nevertheless say that it requires certain action to be undertaken by governments. If it is to be more than a sham or a public relations exercise, certain steps need to be taken, in particular in relation to the care of homeless children in our community. For example, it would be quite wrong for the Australian Government to ratify this convention and not follow up the Burdekin report, the report of the national inquiry into homeless children, which brings to the attention of all of us the plight of the homeless and destitute children in our society who are without the care and protection, the nurture and security, of a normal family household. I acknowledge Senator Harradine's point. There are those of goodwill in the community who support the convention but see it as a challenge to the community, and one which I hope the Australian and State governments, community organisations, voluntary groups and individuals will take up.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time earlier today, Senator Watson asked me a question about the Tasmania Bank. I gave an answer but I would like to elaborate on it. The Tasmania Bank is owned and fully guaranteed by the State of Tasmania. The Reserve Bank of Australia is aware of the present situation and has informed me that there is no reason to believe that the depositors' interests are imperilled. All of the prudential requirements are comfortably met by the Tasmania Bank. The Reserve Bank will continue to use its best endeavours to protect the interests of depositors so that the State Government's guarantee will not need to be called on. In the event that liquidity assistance is necessary, the Reserve Bank will be prepared to provide it.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON THE ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION AND THE ARTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Richardson, I table the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts on its inquiry into drugs in sport and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Somewhere amongst this mass of papers I have sighted the Government's response to the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts inquiry into drugs in sport. From the outset, while there are matters in the report with which I disagree-and I propose to do so in the most gentle way possible, by way of modest chiding-from my superficial reading this document appears to be a serious attempt by the Government to respond to a very important report which has had a substantial and perhaps profound effect on the drug taking ethos in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a refreshing change from the first blush of frivolous irresponsibility, uttered by presumably an inexperienced and new Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) who, in pursuit of seeking to attract votes from the sporting sector, claimed in a most disgracefully irresponsible way that we had rather gone over the top in our concern about drugs in sport in Australia. It did not matter that just some weeks before she made that grossly irresponsible statement a young man by the name of Ferranti had died an agonising death by taking the sorts of drugs about which Mrs Kelly was claiming our concerns had gone over the top.

She compounded that by making some other crass comments suggesting that 20 of the athletes who had tested positive were appealing. I rang the Minister's office, curious to know the names of these 20 athletes, to be told that they were not available, least of all to me so that I could pour a bucket on them. The Minister hardly understands the processes of parliament, nor does she understand the propriety with which I deal with these matters. I put that statement in writing to confirm what had been said and as events transpired, none of those cases were subject to appeal; she had just got that muddled up like everything else. I can only hope that the Minister is now getting better advice. I rather think that the Minister, Mrs Kelly, suffers from an acute sense of inability and a lack of knowledge of her portfolio, which seems to be seeping through to all the other portfolios which she dares touch.

I was equally disappointed by the comments made during the inquiry by Mr John Brown, who, as I recall, was at one stage the Minister in charge of sport and who, as Minister, was responsible for the appointment of some people to senior positions in the Australian Institute of Sport. He was outrageous enough to claim that the inquiry had done great damage to sport in Australia. The report, of course, had highlighted the problem, highlighted the fact, that Australia was not immune to the conduct that was taking place in the international arena of sport.

I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the actions of relevance known to have been taken since the inception of the Committee's inquiry into drugs in sport. It is documentation of action taken since the interim report was brought down, and primarily as a result of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether this document has been shown to anyone on the Government side. If it has not, I would say that leave is not granted until somebody from the Government side has had the opportunity to look at it.
—Has that happened?
—It has not, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I will hand it to somebody who will know how to read it, and perhaps the Minister might like to look at it.
—Would you care to continue your remarks, Senator Crichton-Browne?

— Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Let me go to the heart of the response by the Australian Sports Commission (ASC). It seems to me to be very much a self-serving document which is designed to justify its previous presumptuous and inadequately researched recommendations. It responds, for instance, to some specific matters, not the least being-and I am sad to have to say this-the matter of young Jane Flemming. It is a matter which is becoming a continuing saga, not because of the actions of Miss Jane Flemming but because of the inaction of the ASC to objectively, responsibly, properly and in some depth examine the matters and circumstances surrounding that incident.
—Particularly the role of officials.

—Yes, the role of the officials. When the first interim response was made by the Commission, even the Minister was sufficiently concerned when he read what he judged to be a very superficial and totally inadequate response that he wrote back to the Commission and said:

SPEECH.PARA: Ultimately, I will be called upon to respond to the final report when it is tabled in Parliament. Because of the intense publicity and community interest in the findings of the Black Committee, its conclusions and recommendations will be closely scrutinised. I may well be called upon to defend the actions of the Committee in response to the interim report and I would appreciate your assistance in ensuring that I am able to do so convincingly.

He said that following the first inadequate effort of the ASC to respond to the findings. That demonstrates that Senator Richardson had great anxiety about having to come into this place to defend the Australian Sports Commission.

The Commission's findings were based on the most remarkable premises, one of which was that Miss Jane Flemming provided her evidence in camera. I find these the most unrelated, irrelevant premises on which to make a recommendation, but it is alleged quite improperly that she came before the Committee voluntarily to provide this information. She provided it in camera, which was at her request. She considered that the Committee's attitude was to treat her as guilty until proved innocent. In fact, she came before us ultimately when she knew that Mr Merv Kemp, a coach from the AIS, was to appear before us the next day to tell us what he knew. He had bothered to tell her that he was to tell us what he knew. This prompted her to come rushing to us to make sure that she told us what she thought she knew. That was her reason for appearing before us, and not an unreasonable one, I might say. She went on to say that we treated her as guilty rather than innocent. I have to say that we made no judgment. The facts were given to us and we contemplated and reflected upon them at a later date.

Finally, by way of mitigation, she was greatly disturbed by her appearance before the Committee. I have no doubt she was. I have to say that I was pretty disturbed when I heard what she had to say. But none of those matters, in my view, lead to the response of the Australian Sports Commission. The truth of the matter is that Miss Flemming did not volunteer her evidence. In fact, she was particularly reluctant to give her evidence and in the circumstances, given what the evidence was to be, we could all understand her reluctance to provide it. For instance, she said, when talking about Maurie Plant, the man who asked her to make the substitution:
Maurie Plant . . . is a friend of mine, too, so I would not have said anything about this but I know that Merv was going to say something tomorrow.

In other words, she was not going to say anything because Maurie Plant was a friend of hers. This was the man who was supposed to have coerced her, stood over her, intimidated her and reduced her to a nervous wreck, which compelled her then to give a urine sample. She was talking about him as a dear friend whose activities she was concerned to have made public.

Subsequently, when she was asked what she had done when she was contacted by the Australian Athletic Union, she said that she did nothing about it-`They wrote to me once and did nothing about it'. I asked whether that was because she did not respond, and she said, `Yes, that is right'. I asked, `What is their attitude?'. She said, `I do not know what it is'. But I give her credit for saying that in this evidence, as distinct from what she said publicly. The Chairman commented:
I do not see any differences between cheating and providing the wherewithal to allow someone else to do it, so you are in the same boat . . .
She said:
No, neither do I, but you have to understand the situation that I was in.

I raise those points because I think that it is important to understand that Jane Flemming came to us with a great deal of reluctance. Primarily she appeared because, as she said in her evidence, she knew that Merv Kemp was to appear the next day. I asked what was the reason for telling us. She said, `Merv Kemp is going to say something and I just wanted to be able to tell you what the story was from first-hand knowledge'. Any suggestion she came to us voluntarily is quite untrue. In fact, when she was asked in public about her knowledge of urine substitution, she said that she did not have any first-hand knowledge at all. The only reason that the matter came to light was that Merv Kemp, a coach at the Institute, learning second-hand and accidentally of the activities, wrote to the Australian Athletic Union; and one might well ask what it did about it. That is a pretty simple but sorry story, too. The union wrote to us and explained how Mr Kemp's letter was discussed at length. This is its response in respect to the inquiry:
Miss Flemming declined to comment on the matter other than to say that she had produced a sample.
Miss Flemming advised that she would not put anything in writing regarding this matter.

The fact that Miss Flemming was not prepared to make any further statement and the British Board categorically stated that the identity of athletes at all testings under their jurisdiction was never in doubt, the Board of Management of the Australian Athletic Union at its 17th meeting in June, 1987 resolved not to proceed with the matter.

As a consequence of the problems that arose with Miss Flemming not prepared to make a written statement, a mail vote of the Associations conducted at the time amended the law regarding investigations to read:

``If the person or club or association concerned fails to respond to the request for a Statutory Declaration within the specified time, the person, club or association shall be suspended forthwith until such time as a response is received''.

That was the action that the Australian Athletic Union had to take because Jane Flemming refused to cooperate, refused to give it evidence. So let us not have it any other way. That is where the matter rested.

The attitude of the Australian Sports Commission seems to be more concerned with justifying its position than with anything else. It says that we treated Miss Flemming in an unkind way. It went on to say:
The ASC questions the purpose of the Committee's recommendations that the ASC considers its response to Miss Jane Flemming's part in the alleged urine substitution incident.

It went on to say that a very senior member of the Australian Institute of Sport-in fact, the head coach of track and field-had written to us and had said that the evidence that Jane Flemming gave us in respect of himself was thoroughly untrue.

The head coach in the track and field area had written to us. He said that the evidence Jane Flemming gave us in respect of him was thoroughly untrue. He alleged that she had told lies before the Committee. I do not have a view about that; I do not have the knowledge. What I do have is conflicting evidence. We suggested to the ASC that it might inquire into that matter because it is germane to Miss Flemming's integrity, the integrity of Mr Rice and the integrity of the investigation. Finally, the ASC notes that there was no urine substitution. It is my guess that that is the case, but I have to say that that is not a mitigation for Miss Flemming because on the very day she appeared before us she still understood that the substitution had taken place, notwithstanding the fact that her best mate, Plant, was alleged to have poured the urine down the drain. He just had not told her for two years that he had done it, which really begs the question, does it not?

Another matter was raised by the Australian Sports Commission. It stated that it noted the alleged incident did not breach any IOC or IAAF regulations; that is, the International Olympic Commission or the International Amateur Athletic Federation. It went on to say that the Commission has expressed that it is appalled at the findings of the Committee towards Miss Flemming.

That to me sums up the attitude of the Australian Sports Commission. What it does not go on to say, and what it is silent about, is that every scholarship holder at the Australian Institute of Sport is required to sign a code of ethics wherein, inter alia, they agree to abide by both the rules and the spirit of the sport. I would have thought at least it might have said that Miss Flemming's conduct was deficient in terms of her moral obligation to the taxpayers and to the good name of the Australian Institute of Sport, notwithstanding that at the time it was not an offence.

That begs the question: Why was an attempt to substitute urine not an offence? The reason was that it had never occurred to any official that it would ever happen. The athletes have adopted much more sophisticated techniques since Miss Flemming's day. Now they directly inject somebody else's urine into the bladder; they do not do the sloppy stuff and the risky stuff of substituting samples. That is the reason it was not an offence. As soon as it became known, as soon as it was a revelation, the rules were changed. Frankly, simply to cry out that a person had not committed an offence sums up the Commission's attitude.

Miss Flemming had done nothing illegal, but there was no contemplation about whether it had been immoral. That was further highlighted by Brian Roe, the Chairman of Athletics Australia's Doping Control Commission. He stated that Jane Flemming had committed no offence, had done nothing wrong and should not suffer any penalty. Technically he is right, but surely morals have something to do with sport in Australia as has sportsmanship, goodwill, fairness, and not cheating. That is where the matter really rested.

Like all of us, I regret that Miss Flemming responded to the public findings of the report in the way she did. I put it down to very poor advice by people she ought not to turn to in future. To put it the way she did, to suggest that she had done nothing wrong, to suggest that she was innocent, and to suggest that the Committee had done badly by her, did her no credit whatsoever. If she had responded differently and the Australian Sports Commission had responded properly, my view is that this matter would have died a very long time ago and Miss Flemming would not have found herself subject to unfortunate and ongoing publicity.

I find it outrageous that Mr Plant concedes a potential error of judgment. It was not an error of judgment to go to an Australian athlete and ask her to help him to cheat, to help him to conspire with another athlete for the purpose of allowing her to cheat! According to Mr Plant, that was not an error; it was simply a potential error of judgment. It seems to me that an error is never committed until the fix is properly on. I was pretty disappointed again with Mr Roe, when he stated:
Maurie was placed in a situation where he could only see athletics and Australia being damaged and he panicked. It was not premeditated. It was a knee-jerk reaction which was properly reversed.

I find it absolutely remarkable that any official who thinks one of our athletes will get caught for cheating, testing positive, immediately rushes off to try to fix the test to ensure it does not happen because he is worried about Australia's reputation. That is a remarkable attitude to morality, particularly coming from a very senior sports official in this country.

I find it regrettable that that matter has been compounded by Neil King, the General Manager of Athletics Australia. He said that because Plant had indicated that he did not subvert the collection or testing process it was probably reasonable to classify this as a potential error of judgment. I do not think it is helpful to sport in Australia to have the General Manager of Athletics Australia agree, because he had not actually got away with the cheating, that it was only a potential error of judgment. I rather wonder what would happen to a bank thief who botched the job. I suppose he would get off because it was only a potential error of judgment-he had not actually got the money. I find that very sad.

I understand that Plant is no longer to be an official of the Australian teams, but he is now the International Amateur Athletic Federation's delegate on the circuit, so he has very close and ongoing contact with Australian officials, whether that be right or wrong.
There are a number of other matters which time, regrettably, will not allow me to pursue on this occasion. By and large, with some exceptions, I think that the report is objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your incorporation?
—Has the Minister seen the incorporation?
—Yes. Is the honourable senator still seeking leave to have the document incorporated?
—Yes, Mr Acting Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ACTIONS OF RELEVANCE KNOWN TO HAVE BEEN TAKEN SINCE THE INCEPTION OF THE COMMITTEE'S INQUIRY INTO DRUGS IN SPORT
All Governments

A meeting of the Federal and State Sports ministers was held in Canberra on 10 March 1989 which unanimously agreed to take decisive action to tackle the problem of drugs in sport. The ministers agreed to work towards establishing a uniform anti-drugs policy as well as a co-ordinated national testing program. (see schedule 1 attached for details)
Commonwealth Government
* Funding of Australian Government Analytical Laboratory to International Olympic Committee-accreditation level
* Increased support for Australian Sports Commission's Anti-Drugs Campaign-see schedule 2 attached
* Australian Institute of Sport-see schedule 3 attached
WA Government
22 February 1989-

the supply or sale of steroids was made an indictable offence carrying a maximum fine of $100,000 or a maximum jail sentence of 25 years. This shifted the policing of steroid use and distribution from health inspectors to WA Police narcotics investigators. (comparable to heroin)
Queensland Government
22 February 1989-
established an interdepartmental working party to examine the use of anabolics and other drugs by athletes pending the Committee's report.
27 February 1989 -
Queensland Government adopted a policy supporting random testing, and funding tied to compliance with random testing. Support of the Anti-Drugs Campaign's education program also expressed.
NSW Government
8 December -
Minister for Police, Mr Pickering, ordered an urgent inquiry into allegations of police providing drugs at Police and Citizens Clubs in the 1970s.
NSW Police have sought from the National Program on Drugs in Sport Education Officer an education program for the force.
Announcement of International Conference on `Drugs in Sport' to be held in Newcastle during August 1989.
Australian Customs Service

Regions have been alerted to the possibility of illegal performance enhancing drugs entering Australia as veterinary products, so that clearance of suspect items would be withheld pending Department of Community Services and Health approval.
Australian Olympic Federation

The Federation's Executive Board in February 1989 gave permanent status to a provision adopted in November 1987 involving drug testing of all aspiring Olympians in and out of competition and throughout the four years preceding each Games.
The revised doping policy also introduced an appeal system. Alex Watson was the first successful appellant.
Victorian Football League
November 1988-Formed drugs advisory committee with:
* Dr Tony Capes, former Footscray President
* Mr Barry Richardson, former Richmond player and coach
* Professor Ken Hardy, Austin Hospital
* Dr Shane Conway, Collingwood's club doctor
* Mr Ross Oakley, VFL Commission Chairman
Discussions held with the Anti-Drugs Campaign
New South Wales Rugby League
Assistance requested from the Anti-Drugs Campaign.
NSW Amateur Swimming Association
Adopted random drug testing from 1 January 1989
Australian Rugby Football Union
Established a policy committee on drugs, headed by Dr Ken Donald, Queensland's Deputy Director General of Health.
SCHEDULE 1
Meeting of the Sports and Recreation Ministers Council, Canberra, 10 March 1989.

The Ministers unanimously agreed that the Commonwealth, States and Territories work toward establishing a uniform anti-drugs policy as well as a co-ordinated national testing program in the following areas:
* Federal and State Government funded programs
* international sports events held in Australia in association with international sporting organisations
* national and State sporting associations events organised by these bodies
* random testing program for the Australian Olympic Federation and the Commonwealth Games Association

* random testing of athletes involved in assistance programs conducted by Federal and State Governments, the Australian Institute of Sport, State Institutes of Sport and State Regional Academies of Sport

The Ministers said that Government funding of sporting organisations and/or individuals would be subject to the observance of the above guidelines. They also agreed to meet later this year to further consider the matter and to review the progress of their actions.
SCHEDULE 2
Australian Sports Commission's Anti-Drugs Campaign

Appointment of
(1) Drug Testing Co-ordinator
(2) Education Co-ordinator (Supported by National Campaign Against Drug Abuse)
(3) Information/Research consultant.

Invitation to the Anti-Drugs Campaign and to the Senate Committee's Chairman to speak at the 2nd World Anti-Drugs Conference in Moscow in October 1989.
300 drug tests completed January-March 1989. Represents an increase of 250 per cent over the same period in 1988.
First preliminary positive drug test recorded as a direct result of cooperative testing between a National Sporting Organisation and the Anti-Drugs Campaign.
Co-operative drug test initiatives developed between the South Australian Institute of Sport and the West Australian Institute of Sport.
Joint information network established between the Anti-Drugs Campaign and the Melbourne Olympic Park Sports Medicine Department.
Anti-Drugs Campaign inundated with requests from schools, community and sporting groups for assistance in education initiatives.
SCHEDULE 3
Australian Institute of Sport
Program of drug testing at the AIS has been expanded to include:
* facility pass-holders;
* overseas athletes;
* hirers of facilities;
* national sporting organisations.
This, in effect, is approximately a 66 per cent increase in the potential number of athletes eligible for testing.
Drug testing at the AIS has been put into the hands of the independent Anti-Drugs Campaign.
Internal audit of weightlifting at the AIS conducted. Recommendations are being implemented.
Internal audit undertaken on the overseas travel expenditures incurred by Mr Merv Kemp.
Review of the AIS's policy on doctor/patient confidentiality commenced.
Review of policy on purchase and use of vitamins, minerals and food supplements completed. Procedures have been altered and implemented.
Consultant scheduled to review sports medicine operations by June 1989.
Foreshadowed that National Sporting Organisations funded under the Australian Sports Commission's Sports Development Program will be required to abide by the AIS Doping Policy.

Proposed move of weightlifting unit to Hawthorn deferred.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In my view, the report tries to apologise for the Australian Sports Commission for the way in which it handled this matter. No doubt there will be another letter to the President by Mr Harris saying that he has been defamed and he wants to recommit his own words to Hansard. Frankly, his attitude has been thoroughly unhelpful to the Committee, thoroughly unhelpful to the ASC, and thoroughly unhelpful to the athletes for whom he has to carry some responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of matters that I would quickly like to go to. I congratulate the Government on its response, even if it is almost derelict in the time it is taking to introduce legislation to set up the Australian Sports Drug Agency as an independent statutory body with its own Board divorced and removed from the clutches of the Australian Sports Commission. A number of recommendations have not been taken up in terms of its wider terms of reference, but I will discuss those on another day.

I congratulate Mr Haynes and I congratulate that body which has played a very important role in cleaning up drugs in Australia and has given decent, honest, drug-free athletes in this nation an opportunity to run on their merits and to be found to be running on their merits, because they are tested now and they are found to be innocent of any drug use.

One other quick matter I want to touch on is the question of the Privacy Act concerns. It was our recommendation that athletes who are found positive and are subject to funding, particularly by the Commonwealth, should have their names made public in an annual report. It was not to punish them, but it suggested that that will breach the Privacy Act. I will be interested to look at that.

What happens now apparently is that the Australian Sports Drug Agency tells the various sporting clubs and officials the penalties imposed but nobody is allowed to know about it. I wonder what happens if half a rugby team is found guilty of drug taking and does not appear on the field one day. I suppose there would be markers in their places saying, `Bill used to be here', but nobody needs to know why he is not allowed to be there. I am not certain what the mechanics of that will be, but no doubt it will be cleared up in due course.

I feel that professional sport in Australia has responded effectively, enthusiastically and genuinely to the Committee's recommendations. It is not without significance to note the way in which the Australian Rugby League dealt with the problems it had. It knew it had a problem with one particular club with the amount of marijuana being smoked and it fixed it. It was good to see the family of the young man who got caught for using I think cocaine which in the end, rather than going on with the facade of lawyers, appeals and court cases, stood up and said, `Enough is enough. We know that he has a drug problem. Let's fix it'. That ought to be the attitude of more people. In the case of the Australian Football League, we brought one matter to its attention. It did not procrastinate. It did not try to justify or deny it. With a phone call the man was gone and the matter fixed. It quietly got on with the job with no offence or difficulty; just a great deal of smooth, professional administration.

I wish to raise another matter and that is the question of an appeals mechanism. In my view, Alex Watson would not have been dragged through the trauma and drama that he was dragged through if there had been a proper mechanism for sports men and women to adjudicate, look through the evidence and call witnesses. That recommendation has not been accepted by the Government. It suggests that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is the appropriate body to deal with such things. Frankly, I think it is reasonable, given the unique nature of sport and the activities that are carried on, to have some sort of appeals mechanism. Such mechanisms are divorced from sports per se.

The great difficulty-and I say this in perhaps the kindest way I can-is that sport in Australia, perhaps because of our small population, is so incestuous. The officials have either been coaches, they are coaches or they have close relationships with the athletes. If they are not their sons or daughters, their best mate is coaching them. There is a great temptation to feel sympathy for an athlete who finds himself in trouble. Therefore, there is a temptation to be subjective about how we deal with these athletes. If we have an independent body quite divorced and quite removed from the emotions of knowing athletes, training them, working with them, cheering for them and helping them, we are better able to make the right decisions in their interests.

I am pleased to say that a number of matters relating to State responsibilities have been taken up, not least the control, supply and administration of anabolic steroids. I found it rather cute when we first started the inquiry that it was an offence to give a racehorse a veterinary anabolic steroid but it was quite legal to give one to an athlete. However, I suspect that that has now been overcome by State legislation.

I see that the recommendation on weight-lifting is to be looked at by a committee of the Australian Sports Commission. I hope that it will be looked at because, quite frankly, I think the administration of weight-lifting in Australia absolutely stinks. It claims proudly that it has had no positive results because the moment it thinks it is going to get a positive it pulls the athlete out; he either goes bush or he does not go to the contest for which he has been trained. So by and large it can be claimed, in a rather perverse way, that the athlete has not been found positive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise an issue that occurred to me as I listened to Senator Crichton-Browne's speech which, as usual, was made in an entertaining and thoughtful way. I have heard, both in the chamber and in my room, discussions about the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts and, as often as not, the name of Jane Flemming has been mentioned.
—Sadly.

—Sadly. But her name has been mentioned again and again. As I understand it, she gave evidence in camera which has now been made public. It seems to me that raises the question for the Senate and the committees as to what should happen when evidence is given in camera. As I understand it, it is quite clear that it is a matter for the committee and indeed the Senate to use evidence and release evidence whether it is given in camera or not.
