SPEECH.PARA: I am very reluctant to take in camera evidence for two reasons: firstly, if it is not used because it is heard in camera, I am not sure what good the evidence does for the committee or for the senator; and, secondly, if it is used, why was it taken in camera? It seems to me that one way over this might be that if anybody does give evidence in camera it should be made quite clear to that person that the evidence is likely to be used in public. If a committee, or indeed any member of the Senate, allows people to give evidence in camera, leaving them with the impression that the evidence will not be used, or alternatively failing to tell them that the evidence may be used, it would be fair for that person-if the evidence is used-to feel that an injustice has been done. Things ought to be made quite clear to any witness who comes before the Senate or a Senate committee. In other words, the Senate has the right to use that evidence, whether it is given in camera or not.

I do not dispute that but I do say that, as a matter of fairness to any witness, the rights of the Senate and the entitlement of the Senate to use that evidence should be made clear to everyone. Simply because a person has committed an offence, or is alleged to have committed an offence, should not make any difference as to the process used in respect of the evidence that he or she gives. If the process of warning people is to be used only because we think a person is beautiful, lovely and entitled to some sympathy, it is not much of a process. The real test of the validity of any process is whether it is used in respect of not only the good and the beautiful but also the allegedly bad and the ugly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! Everybody should be treated absolutely equally.

—Let me put Senator Crichton-Browne's interjection on the record. He said that everybody should be treated absolutely equally. I entirely agree with him. The case of Jane Flemming is an example we can use to discuss the issues that I have raised. Senator Crichton-Browne has quite rightly debated the issue of drugs in sport in Australia. He has done so on a number of occasions now and on each occasion with sincerity and cogency.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not confine this to the statements that Senator Crichton-Browne has made but one of the problems we face in this chamber-and this may not be soluble-is that people's reputations can suffer and suffer quite severely because of the need for free and open debate. We ought to keep that in mind. We have tremendous power. We are able to speak without the laws of slander confining us or any other form of restraint except those we put upon ourselves. In those circumstances we should, as I think we do on most occasions, act responsibly.

As Senator Crichton-Browne said quite fairly, Jane Flemming committed no offence but the morality of the act perhaps was not as high as it might have been. Also, that happened some time ago. Fortunately, even criminals have a limit put on the penalty that they suffer. No matter what the degree of the crime, they usually have a limit put on the length of the sentence. At some time we must say, `All right. He or she-whoever has been accused-has expiated the offence or the moral turpitude that he or she has committed and we ought to look at the other side of the coin and see what contributions he or she has made'. Certainly, Jane Flemming has made great contributions not only to Australian sport but also to Australian life as a whole. I add that-and no doubt Senator Crichton-Browne will be very happy that I put that in-to balance any of the unintended effects that any speeches made in this chamber may have had on her character.

Of course, it is difficult for Jane Flemming to put a view in this chamber. I suppose she could apply under the proceedings that we now have to have some statement put into Hansard. But in my view that is not the appropriate course to follow. If Jane Flemming has suffered any unearned damage to her character, it was certainly not the intention of anybody in this chamber. They are the points I wanted to raise. I will now let, as I understand it, Senator Michael Baume make another fine contribution to the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order 191 I would like to make an explanation about what has been said by Senator Cooney, who referred to what I said. I believe that he-I was going to say `accidentally' but there is a more sophisticated word-misunderstood what I was saying.

SPEECH.PARA: I was not freely using in camera evidence. Implicit in what Senator Cooney was saying was that I was introducing a whole range of new in camera evidence and there was some concern about that. That is not the case. The in camera evidence that was used, with two or three very modest exceptions and just a few lines, was contained in the report. The reason it was taken in camera was that Miss Flemming had a great deal of very damaging hearsay evidence about other people. I have a golden rule about that, and that is that if we are going to hear it at all it must be heard in camera and it ought not ever be reported in a report whether it is in camera or on the public record. That is why it was taken in camera.

As there was a clear misunderstanding of what I said, I should also say that the witnesses who came before the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts were advised that it was not possible for the Committee to guarantee that the evidence that was given in camera would remain in camera, and that it was within the capacity of the Committee or the Parliament to so make it available.

There was no selective application of criteria in respect of those matters; it was more concern for other people and not the witness, who had, by her own admission, told at least, I think, a dozen people of the events. The information that Miss Flemming gave to us in camera was subsequently given to us by another witness in the first place or subsequently. I would not want it thought that I had misled the Senate. I would not want it thought that in my presentation I was giving the impression of having a view about Miss Flemming's conduct.

As I said from the outset, this is a matter of concern to me not because of Miss Flemming's conduct but because of the incompetence and the mismanagement of the Australian Sports Commission and its failure to deal with the problems. To the extent that it did what it did, it is inevitably, sadly and, to some extent shameful--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne, I do believe you are beginning to debate the subject. I thank you for your explanation.
—Let me restrict myself to standing order 191.
—You should be allowed to reply.

— Thank you, Senator Cooney. It was not my intention-and I do not believe that Senator Cooney meant to imply it-to make any value judgments about Miss Flemming. Senator Cooney made the point that everybody should be treated equally. I said that with some passion. I have to say, because it has been misunderstood, that the very lowest 15 second 100 metre runner deserves no better or no worse treatment than a very attractive blonde and blue-eyed lady who flashes across the line and wins herself a gold medal. Surely, before the judges, all athletes are equal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the shadow Minister for sport, I commend the Government response to the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts Inquiry Drugs in Sport. It is a detailed and conscientious response to the interim and final reports of the Black Committee. However, I have some problems with some of the report. Some of those problems emerge out of the state of tension that appears to have developed between the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and former Senator Black as Chairman of this Committee. I hope that those personal problems or perhaps they are factional problems-I am not quite certain which-that seem to have emerged have not damaged the prospect of the greatest possible use being made of this very significant report into drugs in sport. The reason I raise this is that--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. With the greatest respect, I feel that the honourable senator was straying fairly close to assumptions and implications about the motives of, first, the Minister and, secondly, a past senator in this place. You might remind him that that does not contribute anything to the debate. I seek your ruling on that.
—I do not think there is a point of order, but I ask Senator Baume to avoid making personal reflections on the Minister.

—I am making no personal reflection; I am saying that there is clearly a refusal by the Government in this response to accept recommendations made by the report and I am expressing concern that, in the absence of a satisfactorily argued case for rejecting those recommendations, there may well be other reasons-I hope that there are not-and that those other reasons may well be an evident, clear and publicly noted set of disagreements between the Minister and the Chairman of this Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: This has been reported in the press. I am not doing any more than reflecting exactly that. It shows an extraordinary sensitivity on the part of Senator Crowley that she jumps to the protection of her colleague in the Ministry. I do not know whether Senator Crowley has any special reasons for wanting to protect the Minister from the public revelation of the fact that there is a disagreement between the Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I would have thought that the honourable senator might like to withdraw that crack at me. If he is going to speak to this issue, could he please refrain from attributing all sorts of motives and meanness of spirit to me?
—I do not think there is any real point of order.

—I am quite prepared to have Senator Crowley bounce up and down like a yoyo every time I make some kind of remark about the Labor Party and the way it has conducted itself within its own ranks on this very important matter of drugs in sport. If the Labor Party wants to have internecine wars and if Senator Crowley wants to take up the cudgels here on behalf of the Labor Party, that is fine; that is her business. But there is a very important report before this chamber. I started my remarks by saying that I congratulate the Government on its response. I am saying that, however, there are some elements of that response which require examination because they do not fit in with what I believe is the otherwise generally high level of response by the Government in this report. These areas need examination.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne pointed to one of them, concerning the question of a tribunal. I think the Government really should re-examine its outright rejection of the Black Committee's recommendations. Quite frankly, it seemed to me that had the Government taken a different view there might have been a prospect of Senator Black becoming the chairman of such a tribunal. He certainly would have had a depth of knowledge and a competence in the area that may have made him a suitable appointee. But the fact simply is that the Government has proposed not to give the powers to the Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA), which will be doing drug testing. This is revealed on page 4 of the Government's response. It states:
It is proposed not to give ASDA certain functions specified in Interim 4, namely:
* developing sports drugs policies;
* liaising with law enforcement agencies, customs and health departments;
* adjudicating on penalties imposed by sporting federations; and
* conducting investigations.
It states that it is not to be, in effect, a tribunal. I think all of these matters should be re-examined by the Government. I do not think the argument advanced in this response is adequate.

Why on earth has the Government decided not to allow the ASDA-the organisation which will actually do the drug testing, which will be collecting all of the information and which will have a mine of information which will be unavailable to any other organisation in Australia-to participate in an operational way in developing sports drug policies? No-one in Australia will have the same depth of knowledge on this matter as the ASDA. Yet it is not to be allowed to develop sports drug policies. That strikes me as extraordinary. The reason for that is contained in the Government's response to the report. It states:

The Government believes drug policy at Federal level is better handled by the Australian Sports Commission and liaison with other Federal, State and Territory authorities by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. National Sporting Organisations also have a role to play in imposing penalties and giving athletes a fair hearing.

I simply cannot agree with the Government's conclusion that in taking this position the Government is conscious of the need to separate the testing process from the broader issue of the policy of drugs in sport. I do not know why there is a need to separate those two functions. It is not established in the response. The Government response goes on to state:
It was decided to provide ASDA with a relatively narrow and virtually nondiscretionary role . . .

That is, as if there is some merit in giving it a non-discretionary role. This body, with the potential for having the greatest volume of information, knowledge and potential advice concerning drugs in Australia, is to be given a non-discretionary role and a very narrow role. I do not believe that is in the best interests of the athletes of Australia or of the sporting public of Australia-or, in fact, of those people who have a genuine concern to remove drugs from sport. The Government response continues:

The issues of `guilt' or `innocence', inadvertent or deliberate use, length of sanction, Commonwealth view of the appropriateness of the sanction and so on are therefore issues for government and non-government authorities other than ASDA.
It continues:
This does not mean that ASDA will isolate itself from these broader issues.

But it is being prevented from playing an effective role in them. The ASDA, our drug testing agency, is to be a eunuch in a harem of drug takers. I find that to be absolutely extraordinary. I hope that the Government will re-examine that matter.

The Government has not accepted recommendation 48, which is contained in the Committee's second report, that the ASDA should include in its annual report the names of athletes tested and results recorded, on the basis that it would infringe on the privacy principles in the Privacy Act. The legislation will provide that only those with a genuine need to know the results of positive tests will be informed; namely, the athlete, his or her national sporting organisation and the Australian Sports Commission in those cases where government funding is involved. It is an interesting change of morality. If a person is knocked off under the consumer affairs legislation that person will get his or her name in the paper, but if a person is knocked off for cheating on his or her opponents by taking drugs, under this arrangement that person will not get his or her name in the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do sports commentators explain the absence from the field of three prominent athletes for 12 months?

—As Senator Crichton-Browne interjects, if such a secret situation developed where an athlete was in fact suspended by his organisation but no information about that was revealed, it would be interesting to see how the sports commentators would explain why some high profile athlete was magically absent for a year. The fact is unless there are very strong sanctions-and the greatest sanction in this area is publicity-I believe the Government is not doing all it can to stop this insidious, awful, destructive and murderous trade in performance enhancing drugs. I regret that the Government has not taken what I believe to be appropriate action in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point that I note in the Government's response to the report is that funds are to be provided to ensure that the international accreditation that our local drug testing operation has received is maintained. That accreditation is now assured of being maintained by our permitting the purchase of sophisticated equipment and training and participation in relevant International Olympic Committee (IOC) activities. As I have said, I commend the Government for its support for that. On behalf of the Opposition, I reiterate that our support for the war against drugs in sport would lead us to the view that we should support a similar situation, and we would be keen to ensure that such accreditation would be retained by the Australian drugs mechanism.
On the question of an appeals tribunal, the Drugs in Sport report recommendation, as contained in the Government's response, is as follows:
. . . that such a tribunal be established ``to adjudicate on disputed drug tests and the penalties imposed by sporting federations on athletes testing positive for banned substances''.

It goes on to say that the tribunal should `have authority to investigate all sports drug matters' and `have access to all evidence presented to the Senate Drugs in Sport Inquiry, both public and in camera' and `should have powers approximating those of a Senate Committee to ensure that it can collect evidence, protect witnesses and inform the public'.

As the Government says, the Committee clearly formed the view that an expanded tribunal was necessary and should have investigatory as well as appeals functions. The Government says, in response, that there is, of course, a conflict in one body having both an appeals and an investigatory role. I must say that that logic escapes me. It says that these matters are better handled by the sports themselves, where, in fact, there is often a genuine conflict between the desire and the need for maximum performance from the people representing that sport- particularly in international competition-and the desire to ensure that the sport is entirely drug free.

I must say that in the great bulk of Australian sports that conflict has been satisfactorily resolved. It is only in a handful-and we have seen examples of them-that that conflict has not been satisfactorily resolved. Nonetheless, there is clearly a far greater potential for conflict of interest in the area where the Government has now decided this matter should reside than in the proposal of the Black Committee. I think the Government's response on that matter is not adequate.

There is no doubt that, as we look through the situation, there appears to be some need for an overall Federal authority of some kind to provide some sort of supervisory position to look at the way in which sporting bodies administer their anti-drug activities. I agree with the Government that it is basically up to the sporting bodies-particularly, of course, those linked with the International Olympic Committee, which has very strict rules on drug taking-to administer their own sports. But I believe there must be an ultimate authority to which people who are dissatisfied or concerned about the level of enthusiasm and the competence with which those inquiries by the sports are conducted can go if there are additional concerns. It is wrong for the Government to imply in its response that having a tribunal somehow precludes the other supervisory bodies within the sports themselves from proceeding. All it would do is ensure their good performance. There is also a question about the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, but I do not have time to go into that at great length.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are clearly ill-equipped.

—As Senator Crichton-Browne says, in his view as a member of the Committee, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is not appropriately equipped to pursue it. The other matter that concerns me is that, if matters of ultimate penalty are left entirely to the sports concerned, there may well be a range of different penalties which may well not suit the Australian situation. Page 17, paragraph 69, of the Government's response states:

SPEECH.PARA: While there are still some differences between sports at the international level, the Government agrees with Australian peak sporting bodies that these sanctions are appropriate. DASETT together with ASDA will work through international agencies to endeavour to achieve uniformity in these sanctions internationally.

They have not got them. There is no uniformity. If we have not got that uniformity, how irrelevant is the Government's response in paragraph 72, where it rejects the recommendation of the drugs in sport Committee that an independent tribunal should adjudicate on the penalties imposed by sporting federations on athletes testing positive for banned substances? The Government's response says:
National Sporting Organisations will assess individual cases but will not impose a suspension for a lesser period than that imposed by the sport's international body.

If we do not have uniformity, if we are still only endeavouring to reach it, it seems to me to be an irrational response to deny the recommendation of the drugs in sport Committee on this basis. The Government says not to worry about that because, as the report states:
Sports will be required to abide by the ASC Doping Policy, which incorporates the mandatory sanctions.
A breach will automatically bring into question the continued Commonwealth funding of that sporting body.
`Bring into question' does not necessarily involve an automatic or substantial sanction. I think there is scope for a more effective response from the Government.

Then there is the question of to whom does one make an allegation if one believes a sporting body has not acted effectively. We have heard the problems of people coming before the Black Committee. I believe they did not have an opportunity of going anywhere, basically, until the Black Committee started up. They often would not go to the sporting body concerned because it might involve an attack on, say, a sporting official of that body or there could be legal implications in their allegations. It seems to me that the Government's response on this score is not very good at all. At paragraph 79 the Government says:
The absence of a Tribunal mechanism will not stop athletes making accusations against fellow athletes. They will simply-
how is this for chaos and disorganisation-
address these accusations to different bodies-ASDA, ASC, AOC, ACGA or the relevant national sporting organisation.

And Uncle Tom Cobbleigh and all. Unless there was a simple body where people knew they could go, where they could make their allegations and would not be subjected to the risks of response-particularly if they were complaining about someone who may well be a selector in the sport in which they are seeking to represent their country or State-then, obviously, they would be very reluctant to rock the boat. It is an unsatisfactory response of the Government to this report on that score. The Government's response goes on as follows:
Action that peak sporting bodies or National Sporting Organisations choose to take on allegations reported directly to them is entirely a matter for them.

I believe that is simply not satisfactory. I make no suggestion that the major sporting bodies are made up of anything other than people of total propriety, but we did notice in the report of the drugs in sport Committee that there were some sporting bodies which develop a reputation for a willingness to live with drugs in their sport. Under this arrangement action may not proceed if someone makes an allegation. Cover-ups are certainly not unknown and, as I said, were exposed by the Committee. Unless there is a tribunal people can go to, they have no guarantee-and the Government effectively admits that-that allegations soundly made will be properly looked at.
I believe we need some kind of body, particularly when one examines paragraph 80 in greater detail. Later on, it says:
They -
that is, the sporting bodies, and it is up to them what sort of decision they make-

would have to weigh up any proposed action, against their own constitution, agreements they have with the ASC, the peak sporting bodies and their international federations with respect to drugs, the reputation of their sport, and the possibility of legal action.

That is the serious problem. The sporting organisations may well not take action and may well not investigate allegations because of, as the Government admits, the possibility of legal action. Yet the Government will not agree with the report of the drugs in sport inquiry. The Government will not agree to institute a tribunal to give protection against the risk of legal action if one makes allegations in camera, if necessary; that is, private allegations which do not in fact publicly damage anyone. This Government has decided it will not provide that capacity to avoid the risks that matters may well not be properly examined, which the Government itself basically admits in paragraph 80.

A sport such as body building is not an International Olympic Committee (IOC) sport. It does not get government funding. What sort of supervision in terms of illegal and improper drug use will exist in that body-in that body in every sense-if there is no overall tribunal and, by the way, if the use of these drugs is to remain legal? I believe that is a major challenge for this Government which it has not yet accepted. The State Government of New South Wales is taking action, as I understand it, and I hope that this Government will proceed down that path. But it underlines the need for a more effective response to this section of the report. The Government says, `Oh, look, never mind. Don't you worry about that', as someone else might have said; it says in paragraph 81:
The Australian Sports Commission and ASDA are to hold a national seminar of National Executive Officers of all National Sporting Organisations and peak sporting bodies to address these issues.

So just as we did not have to worry about the economy of this nation because there was going to be an economic summit, and just as we did not have to worry about tax because there was going to be a tax summit, we are told not to worry about drugs in sport. We are told, `We have no structure that we can guarantee will mean allegations will be properly examined, but don't you worry about that; we will have another summit'. The Australian people are sick and tired of summits; they want action.

While I commend the goodwill and sincerity of the people who have recommended this course of action, I find it unacceptable. I am also concerned that one factor the Government has given as influencing its decision to reject the creation of a tribunal is its cost. A tribunal would consist of only four people, but the Government states:

With secretariat, office accommodation and other overheads this could be expected to add significant costs to the already considerable Commonwealth sports drug budget, particularly as other mechanisms (eg. administrative law) are in place and appeals can be greatly constrained through tight practices and procedures.

It seems to me that, in order to save a few dollars in a multimillion dollar campaign against drugs in sport, we will not get the result which I believe would make this process watertight. I commend the Government for its campaign against drugs in sport, but it is running the risk of damaging the effectiveness of that campaign for the want of a few dollars in a questionable decision.

I commend the Australian Sports Commission for its internal responses to the Drugs in Sport report. The great bulk-in fact, I think all-of the serious matters that the Drugs in Sport report looked into related to issues from some years ago. There is no doubt that, as the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS) and the Sports Commission have responded in paragraph 125, legitimate criticisms were raised by the Committee which were relevant to current policy and procedures, and those procedures have been reviewed and tightened. Of course, the basis on which the criticisms of some years ago were made is now no longer sustainable.

Other actions were taken by the ASC to reinforce procedures and policy already in place. For example, the drug testing program has been expanded and since 1988 has been administered independently. Another very important response has been that the Executive Director of the Australian Sports Commission now has the power directly to order blood tests on AIS athletes, and these tests are more specific and complete than those done by the ASDA on urine samples, for example. There has been an education program for all AIS athletes and procedures for purchase and prescription of medical supplies in the AIS have been strengthened.

There has been a useful and commendable response, but I am still concerned about other bodies-for example, those that do not get Federal funding-and the extent to which there can be effective control by any tribunal or any government over drug taking.

As Senator Crichton-Browne said, the Australian Rugby League has taken a very up-front and, I believe, correct approach to protecting its own sport and its own sportsmen, because they are the people basically being protected by an anti-drug policy. While I recognise that the Sports Commission is quite entitled to be concerned that the rights of the athletes undertaking drug testing are protected and that all sporting organisations have regard to due process in applying sanctions to athletes returning positive tests, I believe nonetheless that testing should not be done in such a way that it allows someone who appeals against a positive test to be able to compete until the appeal is settled. There is no need, when an appeal system exists, for innocence to be maintained until the tribunal determines.

In conclusion, I commend the Government. I believe that one reason we need a tribunal is that international bodies, particularly in the Commonwealth and developing countries, say they simply cannot afford proper testing procedures. I do not think it is right that Australia should compete against people who are not playing the game, but I think the fact that there is such a range of confusion about what is acceptable and what is not means that we have to take a positive response.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to contributions from my colleagues opposite and I have to say, before I actually get to the substance of them, that they are somewhat entertaining, of the Tweedledum and Tweedledee sort. Senator Crichton-Browne commends the Government for its decision to separate the Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA) and restrict its role. Senator Michael Baume made it quite clear that he deplores this. Later we find another point of disagreement between the two honourable senators opposite. I suppose one would say, `Well, each to their own in the Senate' and I suppose it also qualifies what kind of effect the Opposition is having in terms of reviewing this Government's response. There are points of considerable difference in the contributions of my colleagues opposite in their assessment of this report. It might be a reasonable preamble to my contribution to say that this report has barely been on our desk for half an hour or so, and quite clearly we have not had time to properly analyse it.
—There was no disagreement. You must have misheard.

—I suggest that if Senator Michael Baume reads the Hansard he will find it curious that some of the remarks of Senator Crichton-Browne-I ask Senator Crichton-Browne not to get up and explain to me again that I have probably misunderstood this-seem to suggest that there was something to recommend the ASDA being restricted in its role and separate in some of its functions. If it is possible that I have misunderstood Senator Crichton-Browne, of course I hope he knows that I did not intend to do that. But as I listened it seemed to me there was some disagreement between the two honourable senators opposite in terms of their assessment of this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also true that many of us dealing with this Government response are handicapped by the fact that very few of us had the opportunity to hear the evidence of a very extensive and very effectual inquiry. Whatever else one might want to say about the drugs in sport inquiry it is quite clear that it put that headline on to the agenda for the Australian people and made it quite clear that drugs in sport were not acceptable. I think that is now a well understood and well held view by the Australian community-sporting and non-sporting. But I have to say that it is very difficult for us at this time to appreciate what it was like in the sporting arena, whether we go back to 1980 or to 1985, when, as honourable senators opposite have said, there were no clear definitions. Indeed, in some areas those definitions are still lacking.

I find it of some concern that Senator Crichton-Browne wanted to suggest that it was not an offence, that it was not illegal, and that there was no law about it; however, we would want to get them under some kind of moral code. Certainly, there are times when people's actions quite clearly flout what is a commonly held standard which we might want to call a moral or ethic value held by the community. But one should not stand in this place and say that an athlete or official should stand condemned because he or she can conclude that no action can take place, that nothing illegal was done, and that there was not an offence.

I think we should hasten very cautiously into practising moral judgment on people when the law is not defined, when what is meant by a drug is not defined, when what is meant by an offence of action is not defined and when all the other things that I will come to in a minute are not defined either. I simply say to Senator Crichton-Browne that we should hasten slowly before we leap to judgment, particularly when there is no law to offend against. That was one of the problems and one of the great challenges of the inquiry. To the extent that it has produced those two reports it has handled it splendidly.

The report pointed out that those definitions were needed. It needed to make clear the community standard that this sort of practice is not acceptable any more. But saying that means that we then have to proceed to what those definitions are. What is an illegal practice? What is an offence? What is punishable? What are the punishments? A lot of that work remains to be done and I certainly want to go on the record as saying that I think we should hasten slowly in these areas. Let us have the definitions.

Senator Michael Baume referred to the rugby team in New South Wales. As I understand it from Senator CrichtonBrowne's contribution-I do not understand the full examination of it-the drugs in question turned out to be marijuana and cocaine. As far as I know, there is very little evidence to say whether they are performance enhancing or performance reducing drugs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Detracting.
—Yes, detracting. I thank the Minister. To what extent would anybody want to interfere in the private lives of people about those sorts of drugs?
—They are on the IOC list.

—Well, if that is the case, I thank Senator Baume. That is why they would want to do it. But I think that what we are very confused about here is whether we are going to a general moral standard about the use of drugs in the community or whether we are talking about the unfair practices in sport when people are using performance enhancing drugs. One of the other appalling things is that lots of drugs have never been documented as performance enhancing. There is a sort of sucking-in of breath and then a gasping at how wicked people are to use drugs and yet there is no evidence that they have actually enhanced performance.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not quite understand what people are wanting to get upset about here, but I prefer to work on data and evidence and hasten slowly into judgment. In fact, many people are flying on moral outrage. I think it is a very dangerous background from which to start suggesting codes of behaviour. There is no evidence at all whether some of these drugs are actually performance enhancing. `It's a good idea, everybody else is doing it, let's have a shot'. Did it improve performances? Did we see any times drop?

What we have, as I understand it-Senator Crichton-Browne could no doubt help me on this-is clear evidence that some of the steroid drugs in particular have been performance enhancing and that is not in doubt. I do not know whether that has been very accurately or very properly documented. I think we conclude that people on these drugs were putting themselves at an advantage which in the sporting arena is called unfair. As Senator Michael Baume said, it is not playing the game. In colloquial language it is cheating. It is sailing against the wind of commonly understood practice. On the other hand, if we were in the field of athletics and it was said that everybody was doing it, where would we stand if we did not then put ourselves in an equal opportunity situation?

TALK.START.PARA: —A real dilemma. That is the dilemma.

—Absolutely, that is the dilemma. Let us define the dilemmas before we leap in to judge the people who had to deal with those dilemmas. They are very significant dilemmas. Those dilemmas went to matters of privacy for people, their livelihood and their good names on which much of their livelihood hung. It seemed to me that they also created terrible challenges, particularly for athletes, for example, who might need the support of officials, coaches or administrators who were the people, in some cases, involved in the supply of the drugs in question. If they were not they were then appreciating that their athletes or sporting personnel were relatively disadvantaged. What do you say? Do you say, `Do your best, you will come tenth'?
—I have made that point on a number of occasions.
—I think it needs to be made.
—Order! Senator Crowley, please address your remarks through the Chair and do not encourage interjections from those opposite.

—I beg your pardon, Mr Acting Deputy President. I feel that in looking at this Government response what we have is a point that Senator Crichton-Browne, as I understood it, wanted to endorse, that is, a clear move to establish the Australian Sports Drug Agency as a separate clear entity, relocated away from the Bruce campus of the Australian Institute of Sport, as well as the creation of an advisory group having broad representation including one Australian Sports Commission board member. In particular, it will be able to conduct research, select sports people for drug testing, collect samples, dispatch samples to an International Olympic Commission (IOC) accredited laboratory, receive results and report the results to the appropriate sporting federation and the ASC where Commonwealth funding is provided to the person concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: It was proposed that it should not have the following functions: developing sports drugs policy; liaising with law enforcement agencies, Customs and health departments; adjudicating on penalties imposed by sporting federations; and conducting investigations. This did not mean, according to the Government's response, that the Government had failed to address these issues, but it made decisions about where those functions were more appropriately addressed. The Government, in its report, says that drug policy at the Federal level is better handled by the Australian Sports Commission. I do not think that anyone would deny that that is a very appropriate role for the Australian Sports Commission.

The point needs to be made that that kind of separation and clear outline of what ASDA's task is and what its task is not allows for more appropriate, specific and accurate functioning of such bodies. I think it is particularly necessary in this time because of the history in this arena over the last decade-certainly it is near enough to a decade. Those are the very points to which I was alluding before in terms of definitions. The definitions may go to what is a drug, when is a medication a drug and how far before or after a performance can a medication or a drug be used without offending or contravening the drug laws. Those definitions all need to be made very clear. That will be an ongoing process as new medications, new procedures and new techniques emerge.

If I understood what Senator Crichton-Browne said, athletes have already found ways to circumvent the collection of urine for testing. I suppose that is a very good example of why there needs to be an organisation charged with not only the ongoing `keeping an eye out' role but also increasing and extending the definition role. There are other things that need to be defined. What is the sports drugs policy, what are the arrangements with law enforcement agencies and what are the appropriate penalties? All of those things need to be appropriately defined and the responsibility of the Australian Sports Commission and not ASDA. I do not think that would contravene the intent of the drugs in sport report at all.

Another area that concerns me greatly is the problem of in camera evidence, which has been raised both in this Committee and in a number of other places. I think Senator Crichton-Browne would appreciate that from time to time I have been very concerned at remarks made about this report precisely because I think they sail very close to contravening the respect and rights of people's privacy. I have had the experience, on various Senate committees I have been on, of the value of being able to take in camera evidence which I might say applies very infrequently. An example was hearing in camera evidence from the Australian Federal Police in the inquiry into Australian Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals, which was clearly an appropriate use of the in camera provision to take evidence.

I do not have much dispute with what Senator Cooney had to say, but I do feel that evidence once taken in camera-even if properly advised to the witness that it may indeed be ordered to be released at some later time-should be regarded with the greatest respect, and orders to release that evidence or to make it public ought to be done only under the most serious of circumstances and with considerable justification.

TALK.START.PARA: —By the chamber, perhaps, rather than the Committee.

—It is a matter of such concern or such gravity that you are suggesting, Minister, that it would be perhaps more properly the matter for the full Senate, and indeed it may well be. I take that interjection and thank the Minister. Certainly, the problem for the Committee which I now chair is that evidence taken in camera and ordered to be released is now ordered on a subsequent motion not to be further released by the Committee. We more than understand that the bird once flown cannot be brought back; that evidence out in the public record is not able to be made not public. That is not the question of dispute. The Committee's intent is to say what we regard is the status of in camera evidence. Other people may have access to that information now it is out there. The Committee still wants to indicate how seriously it regards in camera evidence and how infrequently it would want to order that release. So it has made that clear statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased to have the Government's response to this drugs in sport inquiry because I hope the debate and emphasis to this point will shift away from what Senator Crichton-Browne called `the unfortunate and ongoing publicity being attached to certain athletes'. I would very much support the cessation, certainly in this place, of unfortunate and ongoing publicity. I would hope that we could move to addressing what is contained in the Government's response to this matter, that is, addressing the issues rather than individual athletes in this place and that the processes can be set up following that report and its recommendations in the Government's response. The Senate inquiry ought not confuse its role with proceeding to carry on as though we were in danger of becoming an executive arm of government because that is not the appropriate role for a Senate committee. It is for the Committee to take the evidence and to put the issues on the public record. Indeed, I think the drugs in sport inquiry did that splendidly, and that is not in dispute. But I think the history of that whole thing now is overtaken by the Government's response to the report. We should be focusing on this report and whether or not we feel the Government's response is sufficient to the task.

In response to some of the things Senator Michael Baume said, I would have thought that there will be a need to review the processes into the next year or two to see whether indeed the best response by Government to that report and its recommendations is sufficient, more than sufficient, or will need modification. I would not think it unusual-particularly in this area where so much is still awaiting clear definition-that an ongoing monitoring role will be the only appropriate response by Government further to its response here. But having set mechanisms in place, it is going to be very concerned-as I understand the Minister and the Government-to see that those mechanisms do what is expected of them.

I take some issue with the honourable senators opposite in their complaining about the Government's failure to respond to recommendation for the setting up of a tribunal to take appeals. Paragraph 74 in the Government's response reads:

The final category of potential investigations is perhaps the most difficult of all. Advocating drug usage or alleging drug usage has no relationship to a positive drug test. It therefore does not fall within the tight procedures that have been developed for testing and for the application of sanctions resulting from positive tests.

In other words, there are lots of areas for if not illegal then certainly harassing or intimidatory behaviour that athletes, sports people, coaches or whoever would properly want an appeal against, but they would not want to go through the appeal mechanism that pertains properly and appropriately to drug testing. The questions concern different issues and they do not in any way deal with the mechanisms and the methodology for the drug testing procedure.

I do think that the Government's response has actually picked up the need for different mechanisms to deal with the different nature of complaints. These need to be understood as very serious complaints, particularly in the light of what I said earlier that so many athletes and sports people do actually make a considerable contribution to their lifetime's earning by their performances as sports people. We are particularly addressing here elite sports people. While I know that there is concern about drug usage amongst community sports people and at the recreational level, this report and the whole thrust of the inquiry were to concentrate on the drug usage by sports people at the elite level. Those sports people can expect a considerable financial return from their performances. So one would have to appreciate the very significant consequences to them if their good name was smeared by accusations that they were using drugs or providing or promoting them. They are matters of the gravest concern.

In other areas of endeavour in our society, and in this place over time, I am sure that many senators have stood up to defend the rights of people to be protected under the law by having a clear definition of law and, as Senator Michael Baume said, to be presumed innocent. What I understood the honourable senator to say was that if a person were found guilty and then actually went through some kind of appeal mechanism, he or she should not be allowed to compete while guilty but under appeal. Again, we are into a very difficult and challenging area here, but certainly people who are found guilty in other courts of law and proceed to appeal do not in most cases serve that time between a guilty finding and appeal in gaol. They are judged to be citizens still able to use the law and have access to appeal mechanisms to further clear their name. It would be very unusual and indeed a very dangerous precedent to be setting different kinds of standards for practice in this arena where, until very recently and perhaps even still, some of these things are not defined as illegal offences or not even defined as offences.

We need to appreciate that in its response the Government has appreciated a whole series of levels of differences of appeal, of the different prospect of offences and in setting these mechanisms in place I think it is challenging the bodies with those responsibilities to make clear very quickly what the definitions are so that all the people in this arena will be clearer about how to proceed. None of it takes away from the clear commitment by Government and the community of Australia to abhor the use of drugs in sport.

`Drugs in sport' is a lovely set of words but it is very very difficult to know exactly what it means. What is a drug? When is it a drug? I have made that point before but I think we have to continue to make it. In particular, we might actually risk working out whether or not these things called drugs have any effect `positive or negative' on performance, and we might have to work out whether we are more outraged or whether it is more illegal if a person uses a performance enhancing drug that does enhance performance and at the same time creates a terrible risk against the good health of that person. What would we also say about drugs that, properly measured, do not enhance performance but do put a good person's health at risk?

In the area of health and good medical practice, we rarely forbid people to make choices even though those choices may be injurious to their own health, and in this area we should exercise the same proper caution about interfering too directly in the choices of people's lives. If, as I say, there were no measured performance enhancement but clearly there was medical damage, how do we recommend-that this person is not guilty of illegal behaviour, just foolish choice? In fact, there has been great confusion between what is legal and what is moral, so-called-it is undefined.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some simple rules. The IOC has set some simple rules.

—We do not have similar rules; that is my point entirely. We need to make clear what these orders are. In some of these areas I note that we have even allowed the rights of privacy of patients under usual medical practice to be circumvented so as to make sure that the restricted people who need to know about the use of drugs will have access to that information. For me, being in the medical profession, and for anybody concerned about the protection of privacy, that is a very serious step. If it is judged to be necessary within the proper constraints I am sure that in monitoring it we will see that it works well. But we have to hasten very slowly in providing a different set of rules in this area, whether legal or moral, from those we have in other areas in our community.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of points have been raised in this debate in times past that should not be canvassed over and over again. I sincerely hope that we can move away from what seems to be practising judgment on individual athletes and talk more to the principles on which we can allow the more appropriate other people, whether newly established committees or existing sporting organisations, to make those judgments about individual or team athletes or sports people.

In concluding my contribution I simply say that there is much grey in this area. While there is such a lot of grey, we should not be making black and white judgments. Senator Crichton-Browne alluded to the difficulties of sports people circumventing the testing procedure and, therefore, not being found guilty. Unable to be found guilty may have been a more accurate way of describing some of them, if I understood Senator Crichton-Browne's contribution. We have a clear example that a negative score does not equate with innocence. We also have evidence that positive scores do not necessarily equate with guilt.

While those two claims can be made in this area, we should look very closely at this Government response. We should appreciate that it has been a thoughtful response to an excellent inquiry. It is thoughtful because it has canvassed all the recommendations made by the Committee. It has taken account of them. It has not dismissed those recommendations; but it has said that it judges that the principle of those recommendations is better employed through different mechanisms or through a different committee. As I commented earlier, I am absolutely sure that our Committee will be interested to keep an eye on how the procedures set up under this Government response do achieve the intent of the drugs in sport inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some brief remarks about the Government response to the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts inquiry into drugs in sport. On my brief reading of this document-as Senator Crowley and other honourable senators have said, the time we have had to look at the response has been short, even though the time which has been dedicated to it this afternoon is dragging on-the Government has clearly recognised the great contribution that this Committee made to the whole area of sports and the nasty aspects of drugs in sport.

SPEECH.PARA: This sort of inquiry is not a pleasant thing; it is not something that people enjoy participating in. We saw the incredible spectacle of the 100-metre sprint final in the Olympics, the sight of which raised the adrenalin level of people all over the world, and which was destroyed so soon after by the winner of the race being disqualified. That same feeling occurs when we see on television football teams dragged off in paddy-wagons with some of the team being found to have taken cocaine or marijuana. The same can be said of pentathletes and other athletes. It takes the gloss off a spectacle which is part of the Australian culture, where we look to our athletes-no matter in which sport they have their endeavours-and many of us aspire to have the same athleticism as they do. Those athletes encourage young people. They have a positive impact on Australian life, particularly on the lives of young people. The insidious drug problem in sport is not a popular subject and a committee does not enjoy looking into it. There is much controversy about this. When we bring prominent Australian athletes into the fray and they have their names mentioned so often in parliament, in public and across the newspapers, there is not a lot of good politics or friendliness about it. It is not a fun business.

As a new member of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, our new reference on the effects of tourism on the environment will be much more enjoyable, much less contentious and not as nasty as having to look into drugs in sport. However, the bipartisanship that was shown during the drugs in sport inquiry was unique and something to be aspired to. Some of that bipartisanship rubbed off on some of the members of that Committee. Senator Crichton-Browne's remarks that the conflict between the then Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) and the Chairman of that inquiry, former Senator John Black, was an unfortunate byproduct of the Committee's excellent work were correct. I repeat: this work has been recognised by the Government having picked out so many of its recommendations.

Senator Crowley has stated that the report raised many issues about the legality and illegality of drugs. She said that there are many grey areas about what is punishable and what is not punishable within the area of drugs and sport. She also said that our Committee should be keeping an eye on this problem of drugs in sport, how the Government handles it and how the Government's response is implemented. As a new member of the Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee, I argued that we should retain that reference on drugs in sport. Senator Crowley has really supported the arguments in the Senate today, even though she did not support the plea of the Liberal senators on that Committee, to maintain the drugs in sport reference as we watch the Government's efforts to respond to the report and to implement many of the points in this response that has been tabled. It is very unfortunate.

Clearly, when we have a Prime Minister who has made it part of his political game to be seen wherever there is a winner-and even a Treasurer who goes to football games-it is not difficult to see why the Government, at the first meeting of the Committee in this new Parliament, got rid of the reference into the nasty stench over drugs in sport in Australia. That is unfortunate, but I am sure that the members of the Committee will keep an eye on this problem. I would have thought that with the drugs in sport reference maintained, we would be able to do that far more effectively. If we were able to keep that reference, we may have been able to clear up some of the grey areas and do more work in proceeding with the problems that Senator Crowley has raised about drugs in sport.

The other issues that have been raised this afternoon by some of my colleagues and some honourable senators on the other side of the chamber related to whether in camera evidence should be released. As Senator Crichton-Browne said, people giving in camera evidence are advised that the evidence may be released at some stage. Senator Crowley does not think that is a fair covenant to put on it and that no in camera evidence should be released. But that was the case and it is not unusual for in camera evidence to be released.

The other point that should be made in relation to Jane Flemming's involvement and the unfortunate publicity that has surrounded her involvement in this inquiry is that there were implications of Senator Crichton-Browne having other than impeccable motives in relation to his treatment of the Jane Flemming incident. I think that Senator Cooney specifically referred to that. I think that it should be made a matter of public record, and should be widely understood by senators and members of the public, that Senator Crichton-Browne was specifically responsible for influencing the decision-the quite absurd and outrageous decision-of the Commonwealth Games Association to exclude Miss Flemming, and indeed many other Australian athletes, from attending the Commonwealth Games. We all remember that taking place before those games. Indeed, without Senator Crichton-Browne's efforts, it may well be that she would not have gone to New Zealand and represented Australia and would not have won two gold medals for Australia at those games. It should be made clear that there is no good politics in taking famous Australian athletes through this sort of process, but the important point to make is that, if this whole issue had been dealt with properly from the outset, the matter would not be alive today. It would be well dead and buried.

That brings me to another point of the Committee's behaviour in relation to this issue: its haste to get rid of it. Currently there is a need for some of the in camera evidence to be given to the Australian Sports Commission; indeed, that Commission has requested some of that evidence. Labor Party members on that Committee have refused that request. As Senator Crowley said, that evidence was published. She and her colleagues on our Committee have sought to unpublish that evidence, which I think is a contradiction in terms. As she said, one cannot let a bird fly away and then fly it back in again. But in a very real way the Labor Party members of the Environment, Recreation and Arts Committee are stopping the further investigation and the finalising of the matter by refusing to accede to the Australian Sports Commission's request. Therefore, this matter is not dead and the Labor Party members of the Committee have it within their power to see a hasty conclusion to it. I suggest that at our next Committee meeting we should reconsider the matter.

I make those points for the record. I think that the Government's response will see much more consideration. It is a fairly hefty response, and again I reiterate that the depth of the response reflects the very good work of what was a very powerful, public and contentious committee. It is work that, I guess, has only just begun and I suggest that all honourable senators should take an interest in continuing it. In that vein I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This report before the Senate is the first report by the present Inspector-General, Mr Holdich, who was appointed on 28 September 1989. It is a very important matter from a parliamentary point of view because the post of Inspector-General reports on how the Australian security and intelligence organisations are operating with respect to their charter. I would expect the Parliament to take a great interest in this because it is the most effective way it has of looking at how the intelligence organisations operate.

The post of Inspector-General was set up under the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act of 1986. Basically, the function of the Inspector-General is to be a watchdog of the four agencies that we have-the Australian Security and Intelligence Organisation (ASIO), the Australian Security and Intelligence Service, the Defence Signals Directorate, and the Joint Intelligence Organisation, which has now become the Defence Intelligence Organisation.

The approach that has been taken by this Parliament to make the agencies answerable and accountable has been to set up the Inspector-General's post. The whole matter of accountability of security agencies is a very difficult question. We must have these intelligence organisations because we have got to know about matters relating to internal security. They are directed principally towards politically motivated violence. The two common forms of that are racial violence or racially inspired violence within the community and, more likely in this country, terrorism. We can see from the relative freedom that Australia has had from both of those afflictions that the intelligence supplied by the internal security organisations has been quite good. In relation to external security, national security and matters of national interest are involved.

Security agencies by their very nature are secretive and the whole question of accountability is very vexed. We cannot take time in the five minutes allowed to discuss this report to go into its ramifications. One of the approaches that this Parliament has taken has been to set up the position of Inspector-General. Those powers have been defined and they are quite extensive. The other move that the Parliament took to get some insight into the operations of one of the agencies was to set up the Joint Committee on Australian Security Intelligence Organisation to look at the operations, again under very closely defined powers, of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.

Most of the Inspector-General's report deals with ASIO. It is comforting to find that he saw no evidence at all of any malpractices or any actions by ASIO during the past 12 months that caused him any concern at all. He comments on the public issue of the matter of the Queensland special police files. It will be remembered that a large number of allegations were made by Australian Labor Party members and Labor Party civil liberties organisations in the community that certain malpractices had occurred-namely, that there had been a wholesale transfer of files from the Queensland Special Branch to ASIO before the December election and that information with respect to politicians, both State and Federal, had been provided to ASIO. In essence, it was alleged that a great number of files and a great deal of information had been passed at the end of 1989 or early 1990 to `subvert the intentions'-and I quote the words of the Inspector-General-`of the new Government'. On all those points he unambiguously comes down with the recommendation that no malpractices in any way at all took place. Not only that, but he found that these events simply did not take place.

I have only a limited knowledge of Mr Holdich, but I have found him to be a mature, intelligent and extremely conscientious Inspector-General. I have every confidence in his integrity and ability to discharge the post. I am also the Liberal representative on the Joint ASIO Committee and I have found the members of ASIO that I have met to be extremely knowledgeable of what the Act defines as their terms of duties and responsibilities. My very limited experience of ASIO supports the findings of the Inspector-General that it is a body working very closely within the letter of the law and for the good of the country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document

I congratulate the Australian Wool Corporation on its annual report and on the work it has done to try to increase the commercial returns to woolgrowers through marketing, promoting the use of wool, funding and administering research and development, and owning and managing the wool stores. As I read the report, I noted that the Corporation's operating loss for the year was $336.1m. According to the report:

This was incurred after allowing for abnormal losses totalling $613m caused by the write-down of stock and trading losses due to the lowering of the floor price; and redemption of investments to pay for the stockpiling of wool.
The Chairman, Mr Hugh Beggs, states in his report:

. . . the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy on 31 May directed the AWC Board, against its commercial judgment and advice, to lower the minimum reserve price for the 1990/91 season from 870 cents a kg to 700 cents.
I hope honourable senators noted that this action was taken against the commercial judgment and advice of the Board. Mr Beggs continues:
This Government intervention raised fundamental questions about the management of the wool industry.

As I told the Senate earlier this year, that action should not have been decided by a group of economists sitting back in Canberra with some flawed economic theories. Economists have a very good track record of getting it wrong. In this case they got it very wrong. Unfortunately, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, and the Labor Government followed their wrong advice.

Australia has ridden on the sheep's back for years. The wool industry has over time provided much of our export earnings. It is Australia's greatest earner of export dollars. Ninety-nine per cent of Australian wool is Australian-owned and 97 per cent of wool is exported. Wool has always helped Australia pay its way. The situation that has occurred during last year is regrettable.

I noted in the report that in 1986-87 and 1987-88 sales of wool from Australia exceeded production by one million bales. Just two years later demand at auction was three million bales below the amount presented for sale. This situation was made worse by the large quantity of wool held over from the previous year and the amount of early shorn wool offered towards the end of the year to avoid the lower price in 1990-91.

The Government may think it helped the industry by its action of dropping the floor price, but I say to honourable senators that all it did was to help destroy the industry-an industry in which we now daily read of farmers who have to shoot their flocks because it is not even profitable to ship these worthless animals to market; an industry where, as one newspaper headline said, `$1.80 will buy you one beer or 18 sheep'.

Senators from my own State of Queensland would have read in the last few days of a plan by a Brisbane Catholic priest, Father John McKeon, to use some of those worthless flocks for the hungry and needy. I believe that in Western Australia the same thing has happened. Mr Geoffrey Mountjoy, a grazier at Amby Hills near Mitchell, west of Roma, said he would rather donate the sheep to help others than shoot them or lose money transporting them to market. So Father John McKeon organised transport companies-Frasers, McIvors and W. and M. Meat Transport Pty Ltd-to handle the sheep, workers at Ipswich regional abattoirs to slaughter them and Woolworths Brismeat to cut and package the meat.

This was all done at no charge. Many people were able to share in the 30,000 kilograms of lamb and mutton distributed to hungry Queenslanders by the St Vincent de Paul Society. I think that is excellent. I compliment Mr Mountjoy, Father John McKeon and all who had anything to do with it because I believe that it is very worth while indeed. It is dreadful that this once great industry has been reduced to such circumstances. It is certainly very worrying for Australia and for its export earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a very traumatic year for the Australian Wool Corporation, as it has been for the entire Australian wool industry. I take the opportunity to address a number of matters raised in the annual report for 1989-90. The first thing I noticed when I read the report was the value of the wool industry to this country. In 1988-89, wool exports were worth $6 billion to this country-at a time when the market indicator was 980c a kilo. In the following financial year-1989-90-wool exports were worth only $3.8 billion to this country with a market indicator of 870c a kilo. I am gravely concerned that the reductions in the floor price that occurred this year will have further market effects upon the value of Australia's premier export earner.

SPEECH.PARA: Admittedly, we did have a problem with supply. The report highlights the fact that, whereas supply was expected to increase only 8 per cent in the preceding year, it in fact increased 17 per cent. But I believe that a number of facts are very important when we look at the vexed question of the floor price. The Australian market produces some 1,049 million kilos. The five major wool exporting countries together produce only 1,665 million kilos, so Australia represents approximately 60 per cent of that large segment of the market. We also note the fact that, just prior to the intervention by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in this matter, the market indicator was rising.

The report makes it very clear that at the opening of the season the indicator price was 889c a kilo clean. On 15 December the indicator price had sunk to 879c a kilo clean, but on 6 April it had hit 900c a kilo clean. Clearly, the indicator price fell not because of a change in demand so much as a change of confidence in the industry, prompted by the unnecessary intervention of the Minister in the floor price.

I have said before, and I say again: when we control such a large segment of the market, as the Australian wool industry does, we do not increase the amount of wool, or whatever produce we have to sell, if we cut the price. All we succeed in doing is cutting the amount of money earned. When we are in a monopolist situation, as Australia is when it comes to wool, we run a further risk in that, by cutting the price, we drive buyers out of the market rather than keep them in it. This has unfortunately been proved to be the case.

Buyers have been driven out of the market for two reasons: first, a general lack of confidence in the Australian wool industry now as a result of the Minister's intervention and a desire to teach the industry a lesson; and, secondly, a belief that the price can be driven down further. I believe that it is wholly appropriate that the floor price be maintained and that at every opportunity we all extend our support for the floor price and, in so doing, extend our support for Australia's premier export earner.

I believe that in the long term wool will once again become our premier export earner. I believe that it is necessary for us in the difficult months ahead to have foremost in our sights the obligation upon all of us to support the industry and give it whatever assistance is necessary to get through the tough times so that it can start earning the massive export income for Australia that it did in 1988-89 and will do in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a couple of points concerning the annual report of the Australian Wool Corporation. I draw the Senate's attention initially to page 43 with regard to sources of International Wool Secretariat (IWS) funds. Senator O'Chee in his comments made the point that Australia produces 60 per cent or thereabouts of the wool which is traded on world markets. It has been consistently a concern of mine in terms of IWS funding that Australia has paid a significant percentage more than what should be its fair share for an internationally funded operation such as the IWS.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important in these troubled times in the wool industry that the Australian Wool Corporation and the negotiators do everything in their power to get the percentage lifted by the other contributing countries and also identify those countries which produce wool but perhaps do not export a large amount of it but benefit enormously from the work that is done by the IWS in promoting it. It is very important in the current situation that more effort be made to target middle range consumers rather than the top of the market. In the long term, if the wool industry is to recover and continue to grow, it is very important for it to expand its market base or market opportunity.

If we turn to page 45 of the report we see the consumption figures for the period in question. Unfortunately, they are not reflected in what is occurring in the marketplace at present. I strongly urge that strenuous efforts be made by the Wool Corporation to come to some arrangement to get wool moving through the pipeline again, particularly in Russia, eastern Europe and China. While I recognise that this is going to be difficult, I note that for each two years that a bale of wool is in the stockpile it costs just over $300 a bale when interest, rental on buildings, et cetera, are added. It would seem to me that there is scope for some investment of that $300, rather than its being utilised and in effect going down the drain, to get that into the pipeline and maybe pulling some of it back later on in the processing line.

The other point in the report that I would like to bring to the Senate's attention relates to training. I want to place on the record that the wool industry was one of the leaders, if not the leader, in putting in place an industry plan for training. I have correspondence with the appropriate Ministers on this point. Currently there is some concern in the industry because it looks like copping a double whammy with the industry training levy. I think that provision should be made to exempt those industries that have taken the initiative to put their own training requirements in place, and conduct them on what I term an industry driven level, from the necessity to be levied compulsorily through the industry, because that is collected through the mechanism of the wool levy fund.
