SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The annual report of the Wool Research and Development Council is presented in a most entertaining way. As Senator O'Chee remarked to me when we were looking through the document, there are some most attractive photographs which give a very good idea of the breadth of concerns that the Wool Research and Development Council has. There is also an attractive presentation of the various programs in which the Council involves itself.

I want to home in on a particular program that is mentioned in the report. I commend page 46 of the report to all honourable senators, and anybody else who happens to be listening. Page 46 highlights the Council's research work in an area which is often neglected. The section is headed `Earthworms: the Neglected Allies'. A lot of people could derive great benefit from reading this very short, succinct but most informative section. Without reading every word of it, I will highlight a couple of parts. At the beginning there is a little history on why earthworms have been neglected over the decades. The Council suggests that earthworms have been overlooked in the burgeoning of agricultural research since the 1940s. The report states:

Now, as the idea of sustainability becomes a central theme of modern agriculture, the earthworms beneath pastures and broadacre crops are again receiving the kind of attention that many would say they have always deserved.

I would agree with that. I wish to quote further from this section and highlight the fact that the research that has been conducted by the Council has shown that earthworms cycle organic matter and prevent accumulation of undecomposed organic matter on the soil surface; increase soil porosity and water infiltration rate; increase the activity of microbes; improve soil structure; increase pasture production; and incorporate lime and fertiliser into the soil.

Lest anybody thinks that that is the totality of it, the further research that has been conducted by the Council, and in particular in Tasmania, has shown that there is a close link between earthworm populations and pasture productivity. Again I say that if anybody is really interested in pasture productivity across all aspects of agriculture in Australia, they would be wise to refer to pages 46, 47 and 48 of the report which tell us something of the research that has been conducted in Tasmania.

I must mention in passing that a very successful farmer who has been involved with the development of his property at Rushy Lagoon, Mr Bert Farquhar, has been a great advocate for the use of earthworms in agriculture. There are photographs of the property in the report and the sorts of pasture improvements being brought about by earthworms. Obviously the Council has worked well with this and has found out some very interesting information. I got to my feet to mention this only to make sure that it did not pass unnoticed. I feel sure that if we can only see more of this research, we may have a little bit of hope that indicates we do not have to throw money and chemicals onto our farms to increase productivity.

Another section of the report refers to the possibility of seeking alternative marketing strategies. A section on page 90 mentions what is happening in China. I commend that part of the report to anyone who is interested in reading how we might improve our agricultural situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bell is quite right: this report of the Wool Research and Development Council is particularly interesting. In addition to the very interesting matter on earthworms, I note the efforts of the Development Council in attempting to find a vaccine to protect against blowfly. Many people in the cities may not appreciate the problem that blowflies are to sheep production. Anybody who has seen a flyblown sheep carcass knows what a particularly gruesome thing it is and what a major threat it is to the Australian wool industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take this opportunity to talk about the economic research that the Development Council has done, particularly with respect to China. Until the recent wool crisis, China was a major buyer of Australian wool. Ultimately it will be countries such as China and Japan coming back into the market that will lead the way for the recovery of the Australian wool industry. I take note of some of the observations made in the report on the Chinese economy and the consequences for Australia's export earnings in wool. One of the comments made is that China presently has a greatly overvalued currency. The report goes to say:
This makes its export goods expensive, discouraging exports, and so limiting earnings of foreign exchange.

Reading that, one could almost think that Australia was being spoken about. China has to earn hard currency and, until it can earn that hard currency, it is difficult for us to sell our wool to China unless we do it through trade lines and lending by Australian institutions to China to enable it to take our exports of wool. China has a great demand for wool. Some 85 per cent of woollen garments produced in China are sold into the domestic market. Only 15 per cent of the garments are actually sold overseas.

There is, I believe, great potential for improvements in sales of wool to China as China becomes more prosperous. People in that country will be looking for higher standards of garments than they currently receive. I believe also that, as the Chinese market gains expertise in fashion and fashion design, the products that come out of there will be sold elsewhere into international markets. Ultimately, that will benefit Australia.

The report goes on to say that China is not currently a signatory to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) and that is a problem. It makes it harder for China to export its manufactured woollen garments. I hope that China will soon become a signatory to GATT. Ultimately, increases in Chinese exports of garments translate into increases in Australian wool sales to China and ultimately to increases in the prosperity of all Australians.

We have a major problem in the international market. Whilst China and Japan remain out of the market there is, some would argue, an oversupply of wool. I am a little concerned that the current sheep culling that is going on in Australia alone and not elsewhere in other wool producing countries may in the long term disadvantage this nation by reducing its share of wool production around the world and its share, therefore, of the total earnings of the market. This bothers me greatly.

While some people believe that a slaughter scheme is absolutely essential, we have to look at means of increasing the sale of wool and promoting woollen garments, both at home and overseas, in order to increase the demand. We do not solve the problem by attacking supply; we must also increase demand. Some of the things being done to promote wool and woollen products are absolutely outstanding. I am sure that if sufficient funds are devoted to them in the long term sales of woollen garments will improve. Therefore, so will the fortunes of the wool industry. I take this opportunity to say that whilst other people may be running down the wool industry and prophesying doom and gloom we in the National Party will do whatever is necessary to keep fighting for the wool industry and for its survival. When others go to water on this issue, we stand firm. We are totally behind the wool industry. Therefore, we are totally behind Australia's export earnings.

It is my understanding that the Whips will consider when debate on these treaties will take place. Therefore, I do not intend to move my motion for the suspension of Standing Orders.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Senator Vanstone:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report entitled Operation Ark of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority contains a majority report. Immediately behind that there is a qualifying statement, sometimes referred to as a dissenting report. I need to make a few remarks about those two documents which form the one report from the whole Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: This report raises some very serious questions about the operation of the National Crime Authority (NCA), especially in South Australia. True it may be that under Justice Phillips things in the National Crime Authority will change. Things will be different, very different. But none of that discharges this Committee from its responsibility to report to Parliament on what has already happened in that Authority.

Over the past two weeks the Government has been strangely silent on the substantive matters raised in the qualifying statement. I, for one, would be interested in hearing from Government senators and other honourable senators this evening as to why the Committee, charged with the task of reviewing the performance and the effectiveness of the Authority, should not be making inquiries to resolve, in its mind, the many inconsistencies in the evidence before the Committee.

As I say, I would be very interested in hearing what honourable senators, particularly Government senators, have to say about the substantive issues raised in the qualifying statement. For example, I would like to hear whether Government senators believe that the Committee has ever been misled. I would like to hear from them whether they believe the Stewart report really was completed by 30 June. I would like to hear what the former chairman, Mr Faris, has to say about this matter, and what the Chairman before him, Mr Stewart, has to say about this matter. I would like to be able to make an assessment about whether this whole fiasco is simply a function of personality disputes. I would like to know whether the Labor network around Australia has something to hide. I would like to know how inconvenient it would have been for the South Australian Government had the Stewart report-as it was then-been delivered given the impending South Australian State election.

I look to what the majority report tells us about these matters-and it does not tell us anything. I see that the majority report tells Parliament very little-almost nothing that you and I, Mr Acting Deputy President, could not have read in the local papers. That begs the question: why have a joint parliamentary committee to oversee the operations of a national crime authority if all it is prepared to tell Parliament is about the fiasco of the NCA in South Australia, which all Australians have known about for several months. It is a question that Government senators might like to address their minds to.

Senator Loosely says that in camera evidence has been inappropriately revealed. He says, `How can people make a judgment on snippets of evidence here and there?'. I wonder what judgment he thinks can be made when what has been reported is simply what the media has reported. I invite Senator Loosely to come into the chamber and tell us how he thinks Parliament can make a sensible assessment of these matters on the basis of the majority report. As I say, Government members have avoided the real issue.

The Chairman is reported to have said that the evaluation inquiry, that is, the inquiry of this Committee into the effectiveness and efficiency of the NCA has now been severely constrained. That is what is reported in the Adelaide Advertiser with a heading, `MP fears NCA inquiry may be hamstrung'. The Chairman says that he is now forced to warn people that evidence may be made public. I trust that those remarks were not made by the Chairman as a means of frightening off potential witnesses from coming forward. Surely that would not be the case.

I quite agree that people should be warned that evidence may be revealed. It has not been done in the past on this Committee and it should be done in the future. I am very concerned that potential witnesses reading the remarks of the Chairman may feel that they have something to fear in coming before this Committee, which is unmitigated rubbish because they have nothing to fear.

I have other concerns about the Chairman's reported remarks. He is reported as saying that he knows that the NCA was concerned about the use of in camera evidence in the dissenting report. I have two reasons for being concerned about that. Firstly, the NCA has not expressed that concern to me or, to my knowledge, to any other member of the Committee who signed the qualifying statement. Nor, for that matter, has it expressed that concern to the Committee as a whole. I hesitate to think that the NCA is so weak as to seek to make press statements via the conduit of private conversations with the Chairman of the Committee. I am very loath to come to that conclusion.

The second concern I have is that for the public to have confidence that this Committee is doing its job properly in reviewing the NCA, the public must see at least an arm's length distance between this Committee and the NCA itself. One cannot review something that one is going to bed with at night. One has to maintain an arm's length distance in these matters. It is my view that the Chairman's reporting of what he says is the view of the NCA does not encourage confidence that that arm's length distance is there.

I turn to the use of in camera evidence. I heard earlier today in the chamber Senator Crowley giving her views on when it should and should not be released. I found that, by and large, I substantially agreed with what she said. She said that in camera evidence should be used only in the most serious circumstances. Prior to that I think she said that there was a process to go through in order to decide what evidence one would take in camera and what one would not. I quite agree that when the decision to take in camera evidence has been taken in light of the nature of the evidence to be given then, yes, use of it must be very carefully considered.

But, of course, that is not the situation with this Committee. Just about every meeting that it has with the NCA is in camera, whether witnesses from the NCA simply tell us what they had for breakfast or what they are actually doing-and the latter would be the more rare occasion. It is my view that one should look at the use of evidence that is put into dissenting reports, or into majority reports for that matter, not with regard to the name that may be attached to it-that is the procedural form-but with regard to the importance and relevance of the information to Parliament and the consequence of that evidence being made public. I can assure the Senate that every member of the Committee who signed that qualifying statement asked themselves again and again, `What have we put into this report that we would not ask at a public meeting and we would not expect an answer to at a public meeting?'. There is not one piece of evidence in that report that I would not have been happy to seek at a public hearing and I would have been very unhappy if the questions had not been answered.

What are the serious circumstances that Parliament needs to know about? There are serious inconsistencies in the evidence which was put before the Committee. Parliament needs to know that, not only because of what it says about the NCA but also because of what it says about the functioning of the Committee. The evidence reveals enormous tension in the operation of the NCA in South Australia and, in my view, the Committee should be able to make some assessment of the impact of that tension on its operating effectiveness. Its administrative efficiency is obviously related to its operating efficiency. The other night Senator Loosley made some very serious charges, to which I say let him put up or shut up. He said that there is a determined plan to wreck this Committee-by inference, a determined plan by coalition members. Parliament is no place for the games of the New South Wales Labor Party-those games with which Mr Loosley is so familiar. When one makes an allegation in this place one should back it up or back off. I invite Senator Loosley to come into the chamber and back up his allegation. It is my view that his allegation is a case of the pot calling the kettle black-it is an attack mechanism as a means of defence.

I conclude by saying that it is an absolute shame that Government members in this chamber seem to have given away the very significant attempts made by former Labor senators, such as Senator Mulvihill, Senator Keeffe and Senator Cavanagh, to protect the rights of individual senators. Senator Cavanagh made a very substantial contribution to this chamber, part of which we heard revealed by Government members as a consequence of his death recently. I invite Government senators to turn back to the likes of Senator Cavanagh, Senator Keeffe and Senator Mulvihill and read what they had to say about the very important need to protect the rights of individual senators. Once we get to the stage where an individual senator cannot come in here and, on the basis of his or her own decision- making powers, put a view before Parliament; when this chamber is run by the executive of either the Labor Party or the Liberal Party, we are finished as an effective chamber. That is what Government members need to consider.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority (NCA) I wish to address some of the issues of substance which have given rise to the conflict that was described by Senator Vanstone. The Ark report deals with Operation Ark which, in turn, arose out of Operation Noah, carried out in South Australia in 1989, which was concerned with issues related to drug trafficking. Thirteen complaints were listed which implicated, to some extent, South Australian police, suggesting that they were either aiding or hiding or were in some way involved in drug trafficking in South Australia. These complaints did not reach the proper channels; in particular, they did not at that time reach the Commissioner of Police in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of that the Ark inquiry was conducted and hearings were held by the then Commissioner of the Authority for South Australia, Mr Mark Le Grand. He arrived at a report which was highly critical of a number of South Australian police officers in the context of the Ark operation and the Noah operation, as well as the procedures that were used by police in that State. He worked on his report, virtually until the day when the chairmanship of the NCA changed from Mr Justice Stewart to Mr Faris. There is some dispute as to whether his report was completely finished and whether Mr Justice Stewart was justified in issuing a note of transmittal for this report. As it was, the report was intercepted-I think that is the right word to use-by Mr Faris who had then commenced his duties as Chairman. The report was judged to have been incomplete. It was held back and, ultimately, a different completed report was presented to the Government.

It is fair to say that the second report was very much a sanitised version of the first report, to the extent that it omitted a number of names of police officers which were mentioned and the descriptions of a number of specific occurrences and operations, and it did not deal in any great detail with any of the 13 complaints that had been lodged as a result of Operation Noah. The report-the so-called Stewart report, if I may call it that-was not publicly available but it had come into the possession of the South Australian police and I obtained a copy of it following its tabling by Mr Le Grand at a hearing of the NCA Committee. In comparing the two reports, I formed the opinion that at least six of the 13 complaints which were originally listed required further attention and investigation and at a hearing with the South Australian police in Adelaide I ascertained that they in fact were using both reports for their continuing investigations.

Therefore, to some extent, the issue of whether the first report should have been published in substance does not matter any more. The police are continuing their inquiries. They have also stated that they have had contact with the National Crime Authority on the conduct of these investigations and that they have received cooperation. Whether or not that report should have been published-and there is some argument, justified I believe, that it should not have been on the basis that it was publishing the names of officers who were still subject to investigation as to the allegations that were raised against them-it is now a question of pursuing whether or not these issues have been followed up adequately either by the South Australian police or by the National Crime Authority.

At the last meeting of the Committee with the Authority I notified the Chairman that I would continue to pursue this matter with the National Crime Authority, and I have been advised that this would not be resisted by the National Crime Authority. In that sense, we can say that the parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority is continuing its work of assessing and supervising the work of the National Crime Authority. I express some concerns that echo the statements made by Senator Vanstone that this role of the Committee must be protected and must be expanded from its present role in the sense that the secrecy provisions which currently operate as a result of section 51 and section 55 of the National Crime Authority Act hamper its work.

I believe that Mr Justice Phillips, the new Chairman of the Crime Authority, is prepared to cooperate with the Committee. However, that obligation of the Committee to supervise the work of the Crime Authority cannot depend on the goodwill of the respective chairmen or membership of either the Authority or the Committee. It is necessary, in my view, to look at the Act, to review it and to amend it to ensure that even this current review of the effectiveness of the process that is intended to supervise the National Crime Authority can be effective. To that extent the Australian Democrats will certainly continue urgently to pursue amendments to the Crime Authority Act to ensure that the Committee can fulfil the task it has been set.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Senator Aulich:
That the Senate take note of the report.
upon which Senator Patterson had moved by way of amendment:

At end of motion, add ``, and the Senate supports the recommendations of the Committee's report and deplores the attack by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training on the Chairman of the Committee, witnesses who made submissions to the Committee and the role of Senate committees''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I joined the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training very late in the inquiry when it was completing its report. I would have liked to have been involved in the whole inquiry because I regard it as an extremely important area not only for those who are involved in the higher education field, but also for the wider community, who deserve to have quality service from those who have had the benefit of a tertiary education. Everyone deserves to have the benefit of well-educated teachers, doctors, dentists, engineers, et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee covered a wide range of issues relating to the quality of higher education, broadly grouped under the headings of curriculum, communication skills, quality of teaching, continuing education, access and equity, and efficiency and effectiveness. Of course, these are all interrelated.

For example, under communication skills the Committee drew attention to the needs of many students to have the opportunity to increase communication skills, both oral and written. This is directly related to the need for better communication by tertiary teachers, some of whom have little skill in communication and most of whom have no training in teaching-that is, in communicating with their students.

I would like to spend most of the short time I have on quality of teaching as I believe that students, and therefore the wider community, have a right to expect academics to be skilled teachers. A short quote from the report states:

. . . the promotion of good teaching within higher education institutions be designated a national priority area and that, in the context of the development of profiles, institutions be requested to provide information on policies and programs which they have adopted to achieve this aim.

I agree that teaching should be given greater importance, since the future quality of the professions, the trades and the occupations depends on quality teaching and training as well, of course, as the other benefits of a tertiary education.

An emphasis on research can, in fact, militate against good teaching. Teaching can suffer from a lack of commitment and a lack of reading and preparation time if it is sharing the time available in a limited cake with research, when the teacher knows that his or her future progress and promotion may depend largely on the volume of research and even the volume of publication.

During three tertiary courses which I have completed I can count on only a few fingers more than one hand the number of really good teachers I studied under. Only one, to my knowledge, ever became a professor; and that may be significant. Others may well have sacrificed promotion to a wish to be quality teachers. Indeed, I know some academics who consciously have done this. Many enjoy teaching and regard it as their primary occupation.

There is also the matter of an emphasis on research and publication being an encouragement to less ethical academics to engage in the sort of questionable practice which surfaces from time to time in research and the publication of research. I am talking not just about high profile research which has received publicity when it is found to be invalid or to be untruthfully reported, but about the use by some academics of others' research to boost their chances of promotion.

I had the experience myself of an academic who offered to provide a computer program to analyse the data from a piece of research I had conducted in educational psychology. He later published the results of my research under his name, adding my name as one does a minor contributor or an assistant. This practice is not uncommon, unfortunately, even at senior levels of academia.

Some tertiary institutions do have good programs to increase the teaching skills of their academic staff, but I know of none in which participation in such a program is a requirement for employment and/or promotion. Indeed, some of the former colleges of advanced education tended to offer better teaching than universities, perhaps because there was not the same emphasis on research-not that I condone the lack of research in those institutions-but also because they tended to attract staff who had taught formally or informally in their previous positions and were motivated primarily to teach.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you were promoted for teaching.
—That is right. I would like to spend the few minutes left on access and equity, a question which is fundamental to the existence of a just and democratic society. The Committee concluded as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: A higher education system which in any way resembles an enclave for a select socio-economic group is unlikely to be a useful foundation for a society faced with the widespread consequences of social and technological change.

For anyone who is concerned about this question I recommend reading chapter 5 of the report, which refers to the variety of barriers which exist to access. I was horrified to learn just a few years ago, when I was part of a task force considering the introduction of the higher education contribution scheme, that many of the large tertiary institutions did not know the gender proportion of their own students, let alone the number of students seeking admission who might be disadvantaged on a range of grounds. Of course, many of these barriers must be addressed years before a student is thinking about access to higher education.

Not only what children study at school and what access they have to a good secondary education, but also factors such as parental expectations for, say, a child with a disability or, indeed, a daughter, must be considered. My experience when I was a student counsellor in a high school was that it was often fathers who discouraged their daughters from continuing their education, considering it a waste of time.

In the conclusion to its chapter on access and equity, the Committee said that it regarded `the attack on unequal participation rates as a priority goal for higher education in the coming years'. It continued:

This is important not just in terms of social justice considerations but also to ensure the background and life experiences of graduates are increasingly in tune with those of the whole Australian community.

From my own experience both as a teacher and as a student, I would say that this is particularly important for graduates in education, whether they teach at primary, secondary or tertiary level, as, indeed, I believe it is very important for parliamentarians.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

—On behalf of Senator Beahan, Chairman of Estimates Committee F, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee F.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1990-91[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No.1) 1990-91APPROPRIATION BILL (No.2) 1990-91]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The three Bills we are debating are Appropriation Bill (No. 1), Appropriation Bill (No. 2) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill. With the passage of these Bills the Government will, with the consent of the Parliament, appropriate from Consolidated Revenue a total of $17,263,029,800. I suppose that if one says that quickly enough it does not sound so much, but we need to remember that all of this money comes from the taxpayers of this country. Government of itself does not grow money.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought it appropriate as we consider these requests for appropriations to see what an appropriation is. The Macquarie Dictionary gives several definitions, which include the following:
to set apart for some specific purpose or use: . . . to take to or for oneself; . . . to filch; annex; steal . . .

Most of us know that we are acting under the first definition, but I cannot help but wonder whether the many hard-pressed businesses and individuals in the community at present struggling to survive and to pay taxes may not perhaps identify with the third of those definitions.

However, the amounts appropriated are both very large and in some cases very small. Today I want to refer to some of the very small items, because they deal with matters that are of great significance to individuals. In fact, the amounts, though very small, mean a great deal to some people, who may have difficulty in finding them.

The money is used for a wide variety of purposes and everybody is affected. It is either a benefit or it has some impact. It is difficult to relate to very large figures such as the total amount I read out at the beginning of my speech, but all of us in dealing with constituents come across people who are affected by the appropriations of a department, the way the Government raises this money in the first place and the way it then hands it out or spends it.

I want to mention some of the concerns I have. The first one relates to use of appropriated funds by the Attorney- General's Department at the request of the Department of Finance-in effect, the Attorney-General acting as the solicitor for the Department of Finance. It relates to the tardy payment by the Department of Finance of superannuation money due to a person who has retired from the Australian Public Service. I am referring to the case of Mr Milton, a former Commonwealth public servant who retired in 1988. He subsequently sued the Commonwealth for compensation for lost interest.

I have raised this matter in Parliament before and at the Estimates Committee. When I first questioned the then Minister for Finance about it, he indicated that a number of late payments were a consequence of people not giving the Department adequate information and that in a sense those people were responsible for late payments being made. He implied that that was frequently the case, but I believe that is not so and certainly was not the case in this instance.

Mr Milton took his case to the Small Claims Court and successfully sued for $929.49, being lost interest, and $20 for his court fee. As I said, within the scheme of things the amount we are talking about in these Bills might seem so little as to be of no consequence. However, to most Australians it is an amount which is very significant indeed. The magistrate said that it was quite clear that Mr Milton, who had retired on 30 June 1988, had been entitled to his money on 4 August but he did not receive it until 13 days later.

A representative of the Commissioner for Superannuation indicated that his office had heavy workloads and was busy. If that be the case, it is not properly served with staff to see that the job it is required to do is in fact done properly. The magistrate indicated that he could not see any way in which Mr Milton's claim could be defeated. The money had been withheld for 13 days without any authority and he was therefore entitled to the interest. I quote specifically from the magistrate's judgment:
By way of comparison, no commercial financial institution engaged in the superannuation industry could withhold investors funds beyond the due date without payment of interest on those funds.

We can all imagine the outrage of a Minister answering a question from one of his own senators had a private superannuation company done this. Honourable senators can imagine the question being put in this place-`Is the Minister aware . . .?' and all the rest-and the Minister being absolutely indignant that any private company would withhold money in this fashion.

Honourable senators might think that the story would end there, and so it should have. It is astonishing to find that the Department then planned to appeal against the decision of the magistrate. There are two aspects of the matter that flow from that. As I said, I raised the matter in the Estimates Committee, and the written response I received was that the matter was still being pursued. I would ask: At what cost to taxpayers is this matter being pursued?

The might of the Commonwealth, with all its resources, is pursuing legal action over this small amount of just over $900 against an individual retired public servant when it is quite clear that he ought to have this money and it was withheld quite wrongly. The might of the Commonwealth is being used to crush an individual and other taxpayers' money is being used to fund this, taxpayers who, as I said, are having difficulty finding the money to pay for it at the present time.

It is interesting to note that since this came up, and I read this in the Canberra Times, the Commissioner for Superannuation has recognised that there is a problem with delays in payments and has agreed that he should, and will, pay interest on delayed payments in the future. Notwithstanding that fact, he is still pursuing Mr Milton in the courts at a cost which will probably drive Mr Milton bankrupt because the Commonwealth has the resources to do it. But I want to look at the legal costs and see where we stand.

I was told at the Estimates Committee hearing that no department pays legal costs for such action. So no matter what the cost to the taxpayers of this country, the Department of Finance can instruct the Commonwealth solicitors to take this action for an amount of just over $900 to the High Court, no matter what the cost, because the Attorney-General's Department does not render an account to its client as is the normal case in any other legal action that any of the rest of us would be involved in.

I asked at the Estimates Committee what costs were incurred and what hours were involved. I am told it was 40 hours of the time of a principal legal officer (PLO) and eight hours of the time of a senior legal officer (SLO) at-this will astound anybody who has had dealings with legal matters-an estimated cost of $1,480. In addition, there are disbursements totalling $2,167.50 so far.

I took the trouble to look up the salary of a principal legal officer. It is in the range of just over $50,000 to just over $53,000, and the salary of a senior legal officer is just over $42,000 to over $45,000. Forty hours of a principal legal officer's work, taking it as a 38-hour week, would mean approximately $1,000 a week and eight hours at the senior legal officer rate of $826 a week is $165 a day. It is ludicrous that the Attorney-General then notionally costs out the time of these people at that price.

That is just the salaries. There is absolutely nothing in there for the cost of the accommodation of the solicitors and nothing in there for the superannuation or any of the other benefits that the employer has to pay for those employees. Forty hours of the PLO's time would be worth at least $2,800 and 8 hours of the SLO's time would be $460 and yet I am told the total amount is only $1,480.

If the Government uses taxpayers' funds to pursue this action, and if it wins against Mr Milton at the next hearing and gets an order for costs against him, will it then only ask for its costs at the rate it has told me, that is, $1,480, or will it seek to recover from Mr Milton at the rate which is the proper legal cost? I wonder. I find it absolutely astonishing that the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) and the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) allow a matter like this to proceed, wasting the money that they have taken from taxpayers and using it in this fashion.

I refer also to moneys appropriated by the Government for expenditure by the Department of Community Services and Health to assist people with disabilities. This is a purpose which is totally legitimate and totally necessary; but I am talking about the administration of some of this money. I have spoken before at some length about the case of the Multiple Sclerosis Society in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). I shall not deal in absolute detail with the story as it is. I set it out in considerable detail when I spoke on 31 May in this place. I have since had correspondence with the Minister, Mr Howe, in which he quoted to me the requirements of the Disability Services Act. I say to the Minister that if the Act is so ridiculous, why does he not do something about changing it and making it work in the interests of people who require respite care.

To recap briefly, in case anyone did not hear the story last time, the Multiple Sclerosis Society with the support of the people of Canberra and, in particular, Miss Gloria McKerrow, has built a splendid day care facility in Deakin where it obtained a block of land. It works extremely well. People with multiple sclerosis (MS) are able to go there during the day and I shall not go into detail on the benefits that flow from that. On the same site, which is a large block of land, but about half a kilometre from residential areas, they built a respite care centre so that people with multiple sclerosis could, for a short period of time, move to respite care, be looked after by the carers there, enjoy the day care centre during the day, and return to their homes in due course after a period of respite care.

For some reason, the regulations under the Disability Services Act require that a respite care facility must be in the general community. This, I have just told you Mr Acting Deputy President, is about half a kilometre from residential areas. It is placed precisely where it is of benefit and of use to those who have multiple sclerosis and who can be cared for a short period. Nobody is talking about taking multiple sclerosis sufferers out of the community and putting them in some artificial place. The action that this stubborn Minister is taking is clearly punitive in my view. The Society has been criticised by the Government for not approaching the Government before daring to establish this facility. It put it where experts advised it that it was most appropriate. Members of the Society talked locally and interstate to those experienced in the provision of these sorts of facilities for disabled people and they funded the entire capital cost from their own funds. They were entitled to seek expert advice, which they did, from the people who were most qualified to provide it.

It is absolutely incomprehensible that the Commonwealth Government still quibbles over the location. It has refused to fund any person going into the respite care centre so that the Society, having almost exhausted its resources, will have to close. The facility for respite care will not be available to MS sufferers in Canberra when this money runs out. I can only conclude that the Commonwealth could not care less about multiple sclerosis sufferers in the ACT and surrounding districts. The Minister says that he wants such facilities sanctioned by the Government and in a residential area. The simple fact is that there is not such a facility which is empty and waiting around to be such a place. Why can it not be where it is? If the regulations preclude it, the regulations are absolute nonsense and they should be changed. Just about everybody seems to know of this, but for some reason the Commonwealth Government refuses to look at what has occurred. As I said earlier, the sufferers are those who have multiple sclerosis and would benefit from this facility. I urge the Minister again to look personally at the merits of this case, to deal with it and resolve it as soon as possible.

I next turn to the matter of education and the funding of higher education. I was present when Senator Panizza in his speech dealt with the matter of Austudy. As I said earlier, all the matters that I am dealing with in this appropriation debate are of comparatively small amounts, but to individuals in this community the small amounts are frequently of more significance than the large amounts. It is individual taxpayers who provide the money which is then appropriated to government. They have to find it.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been talking about the clever country; a very easy use of words, the sort of little catch phrase that flows. But a look at the facts suggests that the Government is not really putting its money into education in the way that it would like everyone to believe it is. The Government is very keen to boast that enrolments in tertiary institutions have grown by 50 per cent since Labor came to power but funding has declined by 11 per cent. So what are we really achieving? It is fine to claim credit for a 50 per cent growth but then try to hide the fact of the real decline in the money being spent. As a proportion of our gross domestic product, Commonwealth expenditure on higher education was 1.05 per cent in 1980-81. In 1989-90 it was 0.85 per cent which is a highly significant drop.

A recent report of the Department of Employment, Education and Training on funding relativities in higher education has concluded that there is both under and over funding-on the basis of its formula-in a number of institutions. One of the institutions identified as under funded is the very new University of Canberra, formerly the Canberra College of Advanced Education. While the suggestion that certain institutions are under funded is a matter of concern; it is a question of the adequacy of funding available to the tertiary institutions. It is all very well for the Government to boast about growing student numbers and more people completing tertiary education, but it cannot be legitimately claimed as an indication of success if these students are being crammed into inadequate, overcrowded institutions becoming increasingly ill-equipped to cope with the demands which are being made upon them. How often do we hear about the facilities in science and engineering for teaching students falling behind modern standards? The Government is not able to replace what is needed in these laboratories.

We should also not overlook the fact that there have recently been unprecedented strikes by academics which should signal to the Government that there is a very real problem in higher education. The clever country strategy will not be well served if our tertiary institutions become run down and lose the best and brightest teachers to industry, government or overseas institutions. If the Government's bottom line is that it does not have the money in these tough economic times-and we all recognise that-to adequately fund higher education, then why is it not more imaginative? Why does it not cast off its ideological hang ups and look to encouraging and allowing the tertiary institutions to turn to other sources for some funding? No-one suggests that the money is readily available but let us at least find other ways of seeing that our students are being well served.

The fourth matter that I refer to is also one that comes into the category of taxation. Again, it is a very small matter but highly significant to many in the community. I have raised this before in a question and got an answer that I do not regard as satisfactory. I was contacted by a retired public servant of pensionable age in receipt of a very modest superannuation pension which totalled less than the amount of the age pension. She contacted me because she had learnt that she is liable to pay tax on her income above the threshold of $5,100, whereas a pensioner can earn income of $8,262 before having a tax liability; a discrepancy of about $3,000 against the person who has not claimed an age pension. As I said, I took the matter up in the Senate.

I understand from the answer that I have received that the Government is saying that any recipient of a full or part pension will be eligible for a tax exemption. But the question that remains is whether the Government is satisfied that the anomaly which is created whereby other retired people who for a range of reasons may not be eligible, or may simply choose not to take a government pension, is acceptable. How are we as taxpayers going to accept that this should be the case? I would like an unequivocal reply from the Government, because I believe that with all that the Government has said about encouraging people to make provision for their own retirement, and the need to lessen the automatic expectation of a government pension at the end of their working life, the Government should be removing such anomalies and should be encouraging people to think less of just taking the pension or a part pension to qualify for tax concessions.

Mr Acting Deputy President, it is bizarre. Persons may choose not to apply because they feel that basically they can live on their superannuation and their other income without the balance which they would be entitled to obtain for a part pension. They may choose to remain that way because of all the intimidating paperwork that anyone who applies for a pension gets caught up with on a regular basis. What we are really saying is that persons in this situation are virtually forced to ask the Government for a part pension of perhaps only a few dollars a week, which they might have otherwise chosen to forgo, to qualify for this tax exemption. Otherwise, they will be taxed on a threshold of just over $5,000 whereas the person receiving the pension has an exemption of over $8,000.

It is beyond belief that the Government's policy should be to force people to take a part pension in this situation. It is beyond belief that other taxpayers have to bear the burden of an anomaly such as this. I hope the Minister will clarify this matter and see that this anomaly is abolished. I say again in concluding that I have dealt with matters that deal with four quite small sums of money, but they are significant to those who pay tax and to those who are involved and are relevant to the Appropriation Bill debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments on those last two points raised by Senator Reid. Senator Reid fails to tell the Senate-and I do not think she did this with the intention of misleading the Senate in any way-that any recipient of superannuation has enjoyed enormous tax benefits throughout his or her working life. While I am not justifying anomalies for people in retirement there is no doubt a tax benefit has accrued to anybody who is in receipt of superannuation. Indeed, the figures show that the tax revenue forgone because of superannuation payouts each year is actually per year more in amount than the payment on pensions.
—She's entitled to the part pension. You have missed the point completely.
—I am not suggesting that we are promoting anomalies; I am simply suggesting that there are tax benefits that people who are in receipt of superannuation have enjoyed during their working life.
—Get your facts right. Tax exemption is $4.3 billion--
—Order! Senator Alston!

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I was just going to suggest that we should try to keep Senator Alston quiet but I think you are being quite successful in doing that on your own.
—There is no point of order but I would ask honourable senators on that side of the chamber to allow the honourable senator to be heard in silence.

—I simply want to add another fact that I think is important to the deliberations of people in receipt of superannuation. I understand what Senator Reid was saying and I appreciate very much her point and would not want to be seen as being in support of anomalies. But in considering the benefits of people in retirement, there are many who have not enjoyed the tax concessions throughout their working life while people in receipt of superannuation certainly have. I would certainly also appreciate that some receivers of superannuation have modest superannuation indeed and probably only enjoyed modest tax concessions, but they have had that over their working life and some kind of consideration of these issues should take that into account.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Reid also mentioned higher education and pointed out that the Government has dramatically increased the number of tertiary places. She suggested that it is a bit sad that the funding has fallen as a percentage of gross domestic product. I am not in a position, nor do I have the figures here, to say whether that has been a real increase. Presumably, there would be some difference if we looked at the figures. In providing those extra tertiary places, the Government has also changed the funding for tertiary institutions, taking, as I understand it, a large amount of money previously going to tertiary institutions and reallocating those funds to research funding. The amount of money that previously was paid to tertiary institutions directly for them to allocate for research is now differently directed, but perhaps it does not get to the education institutions under the same vote.

In mentioning education briefly, we cannot overlook the enormous benefits and contribution of this Government's policies over the past seven years in dramatically increasing the number of tertiary education places, and introducing the higher education charge that means that nobody is disadvantaged as they enter education but are able to return, through tax revenue, some modest contribution to the cost of their education. With the reallocation of research funding we have seen a dramatic increase in the way in which students-postgraduate students in particular-are able to continue their studies.

I want to make clear that I do not wish to fight with Senator Reid on this matter but I want to add the consideration that the scholarship payments to postgraduate students are now considerably increased and most postgraduate students are exempt from paying the higher education charge. The Government is more than aware of the importance of providing funding to assist not only the development of more research but also to encourage our fine young researchers to not flee this country. We do not want to see a brain drain from Australia. The Government's proposals have made quite clear the intention of its support for research. The way in which that has been taken up indicates that many young Australians are very pleased to partake of that assistance and to contribute to the pool of intelligence in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the Senate.
—I will not take that assessment of some of our abilities.
—Order! The honourable senator does not need assistance.

—I want to allude to some specific programs which are of an ongoing interest to me. They cannot be taken as standing alone from this Budget. This Budget continues, develops and extends existing programs as well as introducing new ones. Some of my colleagues have elaborated on the economic measures in the Budget; I want to concentrate on those programs dealing, as they do, more immediately with the community and with those people who frequently approach my office for information or assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk about, as I have in this place before, the dramatic increase in child-care funding and the benefits of that to Australian families. We have heard many claims, particularly from the Opposition, that this Government's policies are very damaging to families. The Government's child-care policies are exactly the opposite. The contribution to family income as a result of the extension of fee relief to public child-care centres, to non-profit child-care centres and, from 1 January, to private child-care centres means that those families currently paying for child-care will see a reduction in their fees. Fee relief has been extended to families with an income of up to $56,200, where previously the cut-off point had been $38,600. The fee relief has been extensively increased and that will contribute to family income by making child-care more affordable and more available.

Not only have we extended fee relief dramatically-as I have said in this place on behalf of the many of us who are committed to the public child-care arena and its standards of support, that has required a change in Labor Government policy-but we are prepared in the name of economic reasonableness to see that change implemented, and provided, and the only proviso we have put on it is that the minimum standards of care in the public child-care arena be extended to the private child-care arena. The private child-care centres in this country mostly do reach those standards of minimal care, and I do not believe that the users of many centres will be denied the fee relief. It is not improper for government to set standards of child-care and to require those minimum standards-with some plus and minus-to be the same across the nation. We have also had evidence in this place that the standards of child-care vary from State to State. If there are other differences, it is not unreasonable for the Government, with its introduction of fee relief and the introduction of the accreditation committee, to take responsibility for seeing an agreement or uniformity of minimum standards for child-care.

As I understand it, all child-care centres will be automatically deemed to be accredited from 1 January and all users will be entitled to the fee relief. Over time, as the accreditation standards are established and the necessary implementation is put in place, those centres will be visited and the subsequent ratification of the accreditation will be more formally established.

The benefit is not only as a result of the extension of fee relief but also from the dramatic increase in the number of places. Over five years, there will be an increase of 78,000 child-care places around Australia. It is estimated that up to 90,000 low to middle income families currently using Commonwealth subsidised child-care centres will benefit from the increase in fee relief. As I explained, that is through the extension of the cut-off for family income from $38,600 to $56,200. It is also estimated that up to 35,000 families with children in the not-for-profit centres will enjoy fee relief by 1 January 1991.

The rate at which fee relief is withdrawn for every dollar earned over $370 a week has been reduced so that it allows for the extension of fee relief to those with much higher family incomes. It is very important to remind the Senate again that these reforms not only go into a dramatic increase in child-care places, but a very dramatic increase in the extension of fee relief will be of huge benefit to families by providing them with the capacity to retain more of their family income. In effect, that will put money into their pockets-money that will no longer have to be outlaid on child-care.

The serious requirement of child-care cannot be overlooked. We have moved away from the language of dragging children from their mother's breast and forcing women into the work force. That is some kind of modest shift in debate; but I do not think it is too much of a modest shift in terms of understanding what women in Australian society are doing. Many of them are choosing to exercise their option to work, full time or part time, now that they have access to quality, affordable, child-care. I do not believe it is the Government's business to interfere with how people make choices. It is our business to provide facilities to allow them to make those choices. Women in Australia are using child-care centres for many reasons, the most important being so that they can enjoy employment. That contributes to family income, although for many people using child-care it contributes to a single parent income. Further, many women are using child-care centres to have the opportunity to study, to train, to get some tertiary accreditation. They are looking to longer term prospects for their own lives and the benefits for their families, including their children.

Women are using child-care centres for what is called occasional care-for all the numbers of things that women have to do, choose to do and want to do when it is not particularly helpful to have little children along at the same time. We have talked of the importance of hospital visits, and even such things as dental appointments and so on are often managed much more easily when one knows that one's children are happily catered for in a child-care centre. There are women in this country who exercise different options for their child-care. We are interested in ensuring that those provisions are looked after too, that is, women have opportunities and choices. Under the Budget allocation there have been dramatically increased amounts of money for fee relief and extra places in child-care, and I think that this Government deserves great credit for that and it should be acknowledged and appreciated.

That contribution in child-care does not stand without relationship to other initiatives taken by the Government for and on behalf of children. There has been a dramatic increase in payments for children or to parents for children. Benchmarks were set by Minister Brian Howe when he was Minister for Social Security. Those benchmarks, in terms of the cost of maintaining children or as assessed payments on behalf of children, are now enshrined in legislation and are indexed. That is the first time that has ever happened in this country. It is one of those benefits or landmark steps that do not get the acknowledgment that is due to them: because those payments are indexed, they will never fall without a change of legislation. I have never understood that it is the intention of the Opposition to reduce those payments. Indeed, I think that the Government has appreciated its support for those initiatives.

Family allowance supplement-a payment to families on low incomes, either not working or in the work force-has made a dramatic difference to low income families. It has been one way, though not the complete way, in which that poverty trap has been met. It enables people to move from being on a pension back into the work force so that they will not lose all the payments for and on behalf of their children.

When this is considered along with the two stages of the child support legislation that has been introduced into this place-in which the Government has appreciated that it requires or expects, as do most Australians, that parents have a responsibility to support their children, whether or not they have the custody of those children-there is shown a pattern of concern and regard for the values of fairness that Australian society so strongly endorses, particularly the targeting of that assistance to those on the lowest income. The payments for children cover family incomes up to $56,000 in respect of child-care, and beyond that for family allowance. The Government recognises the importance of assisting families with children in order to enable those families to exercise some choice in the way they provide for their children.

One other area which has not received much comment but which I believe is important is the contribution under the Community Services and Health portfolio of ongoing funding announced in last year's Budget-a figure of $6.4m over four years-to examine the best way to assist with home birthing in this country. There is a growing indication from the community-very strong in some areas-for a requirement for changes in the process of birth and a desire to move away from the interventionist hospital birthing processes. In some of our large hospitals considerable change is already happening so that `birthing centres' is the phrase that is used about the labour wards in those hospitals. As well as that, some babies are being delivered at home by qualified midwives or by doctors with the necessary qualifications, or both. At the moment, the Government is still looking with the States at the best ways to provide remuneration payments, in particular to those in attendance upon people who have home births.

Some very interesting figures released from a study in New South Wales this year give one considerable pause in terms of the number of women who would have either instrument births or caesarean sections. The figures are very much higher than the World Health Organisation standards that are reasonably set for a country such as Australia. In some pockets of this country the number of interventions in the child birth process is a cause for grave concern. Furthermore, it is a cause of great pain, suffering and anxiety for the women involved. The home birthing program which is funded by this Government to investigate the best ways in which to proceed from now on deserves our appreciation.

I wish to move on to make a few comments about another area of real interest to me, that is, the allocation of research moneys under two particular headings. One is the increase in the allocation to Australian medical research. It is a very considerable allocation of $45m for capital works for medical research institutes over the next five years. I think that is a clear indication of this Government's commitment to excellence in research at all levels, but in particular, in terms of this funding allocation, to medical research.

In some areas Australia is quite clearly a world leader in its medical research. Indeed, so good are some of our researchers that they are being poached by other countries-at a considerable loss to Australia. I think that we do have ways of patenting intelligence, but we need to look at how we can patent the people involved. I do not know that we can ever hope to do that. Indeed, the whole patenting of intelligence is a question of considerable aggravation. I would like to think that at some stage we could become a world where knowledge was valued for its own sake and not bought and sold, but at the moment the knowledge and the expertise of Australian research are being bought and sold. I am very pleased to see this commitment from the Government to further allocations for medical research so that we may see a continuation of the excellence of medical research.

I notice that Senator Peter Baume recently spoke to the annual report of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). If I had not been occupying the chair at the time, no doubt I, too, would have spoken to that report. I can only confirm, reiterate and support the remarks made by Senator Peter Baume about the excellence of medical research in this country.

I note that under this Government there is a specific allocation for medical research under the women's agenda. In 1990-91 the National Health and Medical Research Council is supporting nearly $8m worth of research into the area of women's health. I am delighted to see that, because for too long areas of women's health have not been main ticket items for the allocation of research dollars. It is important that new money has gone into that area of NHMRC research. I endorse that and I am delighted to see it there.

Another area of research allocation that has interested me-indeed, I asked a question about it yesterday-is the establishment of cooperative research centres in this country. It is an exciting initiative where we hope to see an optimal wedding of the groves of academe and the halls of industry, if that is the right phrase. This wedding will provide for the development of research targeted in a slightly different way. It will be targeted with a view to its application, but in no way doing away with or in any way denigrating the importance of pure research, so-called. Indeed, one of the important challenges for the cooperative research centres-I think that the Minister said that 120 people had applied for the funding of such centres, although I am not sure of the figure-is that 15 of them will be established in the near future. That funding over four years will reach a figure of $100m a year, in 1991 dollars, by 1994-95. That is a very significant commitment to implementing the new wedding of industry and science in research.

There are two areas of problem for those research centres. The first is the definition of intellectual property and patenting. Indeed, those people involved with the cooperative research centres, I believe, have established a committee-or one is about to be established-to deal with this thorny issue. To whom does the wealth that emerges from any of the research developments belong? Does it belong to the university, to the individuals or to industry? If it belongs to them all, on what kind of formula is it shared or divided among them? I know that this very important issue is receiving considerable thought and development. It is something like the challenge of patent law, but it is also a little different. I would be very interested to keep an eye on it to see the outcome of that, particularly as the benefit of that will accrue to Australia to further Australian research and to further development of industry.

The other side of the cooperative research centres is that in this country we have, again and again, invented and patented wonderful new systems, machines and mechanisms, but Australia suffers terribly from the challenge of having to find sufficient venture capital or risk capital to get many of those initiatives or inventions up and running. It is a question that I have raised on a number of occasions. Indeed, I believe that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other Ministers are seriously addressing the question of how we can urge our financial institutions to address the question of venture capital or risk capital in this country. It is a very big challenge.

I know that the previous Minister, Mr Barry Jones, would tell us that in America the large institutions would reckon a return of one in 10 of the research projects that industry adopted was a good return on their investment. That means that they must have some understanding and an expectation of writing off some of their investment. I do not think Australia has reached that stage yet, and if these cooperative research centres are to return to the country the benefits that are expected with their development, we will have to see not only an understanding of the apportionment of intellectual property and its returns but also the appropriate venture and risk capital to support the development of some of the initiatives and inventions in Australia.

Finally, I would like to make a few remarks about the very problematic and difficult debate that has been in the community in the last few days about the care of the aged folk in this country. I was a member of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes not too long after I came into the Senate. I believe that one of our recommendations suggesting that there should be a charter of residents' rights and responsibilities for people in nursing homes was supported by everybody on that Committee.

It has been very disappointing and somewhat shocking to see the way that debate has run in this community over the last few days. I am particularly disappointed for two reasons. Firstly, the opposition to this charter of residents' rights and responsibilities seems to have originally emerged from some representatives of the Catholic church, subsequently supported-as I read my newspapers-by some representatives of other religious organisations. I find it very disappointing because those organisations have been the standard setters for adequate, beautiful, dignified care in nursing homes.

When people in this country sought to find a place in a nursing home, it was very often as a highest priority with the religious or not for profit charitable nursing homes. Practised in those homes for many years was the sort of attention and care that took regard of treating people with dignity, of providing services and care for them, of their individual differences. The very sorts of things that have been written in this charter of residents' rights and responsibilities I thought were best practised almost as an example to the rest of us in those very nursing homes. In fact, I am a bit shocked that the religious organisations did not come out and say, `We strongly endorse this because that has been our practice for many years'. I think we could say that in large part it has.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you accusing them of hypocrisy?

—No, I am not accusing anybody of anything. I wish the Opposition would stop ascribing intention and motive to me. I am simply saying that the way this debate has gone is a matter of disappointment and sadness to me when a charter of residents' rights that was a recommendation-I think a unanimous one, but I will not insist on that-from the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes appreciated the importance of acknowledging the rights of people in their last years and, in particular, recognised that some nursing homes were not providing that standard of care or regard for people.

SPEECH.PARA: I am disappointed to see the way this debate has gone because I thought the standard setters in the nursing home industry were those religious and charitable or not for profit nursing homes. I am surprised that they would not have been the first to endorse this charter of rights precisely because they have been doing it in the largest part.

This charter of residents' rights and responsibilities is a responsible and reasonable statement of rights, going not only to the rights of residents but also to their responsibilities. This is not weighted entirely on one side. In essence it is a recognition that once people have been moved to a nursing home they should be able to expect the same kind of regard for their rights as they would have had in their own home; for example, the right to privacy, the right to privacy with their banking account, the right of access to their money and an expectation that that money would be protected on their behalf. All of us could probably tell tales of when things such as that were not the case.

We would also expect that people might reasonably live much of their time, particularly if they are not bedridden, in ordinary clothes and not be required to live for years in pyjamas or nightclothes. We know that many people somehow feel less able to brave the world if they are not dressed in civvies or street clothes. It is one of those small, unspoken ways in which we treat or regard a person with a different kind of respect and right.

I am terribly disappointed that this debate has become a kind of objection to a notion of rights for people in nursing homes. The principal right, of course, is to adequate care. In our report we were able to show where some nursing homes failed miserably not only in the care of their patients but in delivering basic nursing and medical care, when patients had to be moved to a large public hospital that was able to restore many of them to good health-certainly not what they were receiving in one or two of the nursing homes. We all know of the report of one nursing home last week that was closed because of insufficient standards. I hope that this debate on human rights will get back to where it ought to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1990-91, the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1990-91 tonight, I cannot help responding to some of the things that Senator Crowley has just been talking about in terms of the rights of residents of nursing homes. I do not wish to go into the matter in any great detail because I believe that there is another time for proper debate on this issue, but I would like to say that I believe that residents of nursing homes do have rights but that, equally, proprietors have rights that should not be overlooked. I do not believe that we should have to blackmail any of the proprietors into signing anything that runs counter to their beliefs purely on the basis that they will have their funding cut off if they do not sign on the dotted line.

SPEECH.PARA: The way in which Senator Crowley is sarcastically going tut-tut makes me believe that she agrees with Minister Staples in the way in which he is blackmailing the Little Sisters of the Poor and other nursing homes which have chosen to speak out on their beliefs. It all hums very much the same way in which there was blackmail to the States that they either drop their alcohol limit from 0.08 to 0.05 or run the risk of having their road funding reduced. At a stage when they have had so little road funding from the Commonwealth anyway, to have that blackmail-and now this blackmail-is a very sad state of affairs.

I believe that the proprietors must have rights. I happen to know personally of the way in which the Little Sisters of the Poor conduct their nursing homes. They have an excellent reputation within the industry and among the families of those who are residents. We should not start belittling those people purely and simply because they have beliefs that they have the courage to stand up and fight for.

However, I will return to the issue that I care to talk about tonight and that is the 1990 Budget. The Appropriation Bills are an accepted means of evaluating the state of the economy and its management by this Government. Even though the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has had the good grace to admit that he is glad that his Government does not have to face an election, there is still a massive air of unreality about his regime. As recently as 22 August the Treasurer stated that we are living through `the golden years of change'-what golden years they have been-having stated two years before that `we are now well on our way back to prosperity'. Heaven help us: we have a long way to go. In April last year he was talking of having proved Labor's supposedly superior economic strategy and performance.

We all know, if we are to be honest with ourselves, that there are people out there who are hurting who do not see these as the golden years of change and do not see any way back to prosperity. All they see is the rear end of the unemployment queues. Just who does the Treasurer think he is fooling? Australia is moving from a situation where business enterprise is crippled by interest rates to one where activity slumps through lack of confidence, the classic economic depression. Certainly he has succeeded in crushing economic activity in what at best is a recession-led recovery-only the nature of any recovery is uncertain. It is a national problem, but one that is having a particularly severe impact upon my State of Western Australia. Could it be that the Treasurer was anxious for the West to participate more directly in national experience by giving it an extra dose of his own carefully created recession?

With unemployment now standing at 7.4 per cent we are seeing the inevitable result of Labor's policy of dampening demand through interest rates while neglecting productivity and the control of inflation. Over the past year on a national level there has been the loss of 55,000 jobs in the wholesale and retail sectors, and 19,000 jobs lost in the hospitality area. I might say that the hospitality industry is forecasting an even gloomier picture in the near future. Australia is down 36,000 manufacturing and 16,000 construction jobs. And these are meant to be the golden years!

Where have jobs increased? You guessed it-in the Public Service, in public administration, where however good a job is done it can only be supported by the taxes of a diminished private sector. The number of full time job losers has risen from 150,000 to 219,000. These are, in the words of the Treasurer, the golden years! In Western Australia we are not only crippled by the Hawke Labor Government; we have the double-barrelled crippling effect of the Lawrence Labor Government that has wasted thousands upon thousands upon millions of dollars of taxpayers' funds. No-one can deny that because, after all these years, it is now on the public record.

In Western Australia unemployment now stands at 8.7 per cent, the highest of any mainland State. Since July, youth unemployment has risen from 15.6 per cent to over 20 per cent, with young workers being sacked at 18, thanks also to an unrealistic wage structure that this Labor Government has not tried to change. It would simply prefer to see these young people out of work, never getting the experience that will lead them on to any career path or future for themselves as the years go by. High youth unemployment is directly related to a fall in jobs, particularly in the retail sector which is of course highly exposed to falls in economic activity and consumer confidence.
