Whereas on a national level-according to an Australia and New Zealand Banking Group survey-there was a 40 per cent fall in advertised jobs from April last year to September, in Western Australia the fall has been 65 per cent-25 per cent more than the national average. While Australia-wide-according to figures released on 2 October by the Department of Employment, Education and Training-there was a 46 per cent drop in professional and trade job places over 12 months, the Western Australian figure was 68 per cent. The last three months had seen a 22 per cent drop in these Western Australian job places against a 12 per cent national drop.

Western Australia is really hurting. What is this Government trying to do about it? What is the Lawrence Government trying to do about it? The answer is absolutely nothing. Figures released on Tuesday show a further decline in vacancies to 50 per cent below the level of the same three months to October 1989, with the decline in Western Australia still running above the national average. While Western Australians who have jobs now consider themselves lucky-lucky indeed they are-they are hurting worse than the national average in the fruition of Labor's economic policy.

Inflation that was 7.7 per cent in 1989-90 reached 8.6 per cent in Perth, while wages in Western Australia rose 4.6 per cent compared with a national rise of 6.6 per cent. One does not need to be a genius in mathematics to realise that this adds up to a big decline in purchasing power. Indeed, in 1988-89 household expenditure in Western Australia rose above the national weekly average at $512 compared with $502.

Bankruptcies is another problem pertaining particularly to Western Australia, but needless to say it is a problem right across the country. In Western Australia they reached nearly 1,200 in 1989-90, a rise of 34 per cent over the previous year. On a national level, the 9,100 bankruptcies represented only an 11 per cent increase. When I say `only an 11 per cent increase', I do not mean that to be interpreted as saying that is not too bad. The fact of the matter is that yet again the national average is 11 per cent and Western Australia has had a 34 per cent rise in bankruptcies. Not for the first time I must remind the Senate that bankruptcies are an indication of a far larger number of businesses that cease trading before they reach this point. They also mean that unpaid debts can spell grave difficulty for other small enterprises that are their creditors.

The business community in Western Australia knows exactly what we face. The latest quarterly survey of business opinion across all major industry sectors follows an equally pessimistic survey of the June quarter. With one per cent of firms declaring conditions good and expecting an improvement, 77 per cent stated that conditions were poor and 75 per cent expected them to remain poor in the December quarter, despite its traditional boost. They understand that people simply have not got the money to go out and buy things. They do not have the money for luxuries. They are simply battling to stay alive; battling for survival. Yet the Government went absolutely cock-a-hoop today. To see the Prime Minister and Treasurer on the television news one would think they had won Lotto single-handedly because there has been a marginal drop in inflation today. The reality is that that will not help anybody who has lost a job in recent months or is about to lose a job, particularly this side of Christmas.

Sixty per cent of firms reported reduced sales turnover and 41 per cent expect it to fall in December, and that is leading up to Christmas. Fifty-five per cent report lower profitability and 37 per cent have experienced a fall in employment, with 35 per cent expecting to reduce it in the December quarter as against 9 per cent looking forward to increasing it.

It is ominous that 43 per cent reported greater labour costs per unit with 9 per cent stating the reverse. So the trend is clearly there. Business is hurting and the economy is in recession but, oh no, we have this little game going on with the Prime Minister and the Treasurer not wanting to say the word `recession'. They would get far more respect from everyone concerned if they were honest and up front and said, `Yes, we are in recession and yes, there is a possibility of turning it around'. But to do that they have to change policy direction. They are not prepared to take the hard decisions. Therefore, we can expect the decline to get worse.

It is also highly significant that 52 per cent of all businesses surveyed expected capital expenditure to decline over the next year. We must consider that as against the 12 per cent expecting it to rise. We are seeing the lowest level of capital expenditure in over a decade, representing a level 15 per cent below that of the 1982-83 recession. That is the period that we, in the Opposition, get rammed down our throats. Day in day out Government members say that things were crook back in 1982-83. Things in 1982-83 pale into insignificance compared to today. But are those opposite prepared to admit it? No. Here we are 7 1/2 years down the track, after those opposite came to government, yet they still blame the Fraser years for their economic ills and woes and policy decisions of today. So much for the claims of this Government that those days were worse than the current crisis. Not even the harshest critics of the Fraser Government could honestly say that the 1982-83 slump was deliberately engineered, unlike the Keating recession that we are going through today.

Until now, a superficially healthy picture of the Western Australian overall economy could be maintained because of the profitability of the minerals sector. Even here, however, there is little room for further expansion with perhaps a one per cent annual increase in iron ore. No export industry is helped by Labor's monetary policy, which has resulted in an over-valued dollar. It would be well for this Government to be more aware of the role of mining in preventing a total economic disaster. Only a few months ago it was considered smart politics to kick the mining industry by such landmark pieces of political opportunism as the Coronation Hill decision. If this Government continues to prostitute itself to the greenies and not make the tough decisions that will see the economy of this country pick up, we will see ourselves going further down into the mire.

It is such a tragedy. Not only is it the Government's economic decisions that are affecting this country today, particularly the mining sector, but it is also the Government's dealing that it has done for cheap, quick votes. Additionally, the industrial relations policy ensures that we are viewed by overseas as an unreliable exporter of minerals.

Once again, if the tough decisions were made, and made now, maybe there would be some chance. I admit that they should have been made months ago. Even if they were made now there would be a chance. But no, we see the Prime Minister and the Treasurer saying, `Steady as she goes'. Steady as she goes is right-steady as we sink further.

The housing and construction sectors are notoriously subject to rapid fluctuations. The story from Western Australia points once again to a massive slump caused squarely by the interest rate policy of the Hawke Labor Government. Now that interest rates are declining at 15 1/2 per cent to 16 per cent for home loans, this still being a rather large figure, the housing industry must contend with a general crisis of confidence. Yet, as I say, today the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are excited because a few elements have led to a minute reduction in inflation. One is the price of housing, which has come down. Is it any wonder?

The price of cars has come down. Is it any wonder? Car factories-such as Ford Motor Co. of Aust Ltd-are having to close because they have too many cars. The dealers are having to sell their cars at greatly reduced prices. Is it any wonder that the cost of motor vehicles has come down? They cannot give them away, let alone sell them.

Housing starts from January to August this year are down by 27 per cent compared with the same period in 1989 with a 33 per cent decline for all residential units. In Perth, 21,000 housing starts in 1988-89 fell to 12,000 the following year, a drop of 43 per cent, with a further decline to 11,000 anticipated for the year 1990-91 despite a most positive campaign by the housing industry to encourage new home purchasing.

It is all very well for the industries to try to boost their own markets. It is highly desirable and it is necessary. But when they are being strangled from a position that they cannot change because their marketplace simply does not have any money, what else can happen other than these disastrous figures I am referring to tonight?

In Western Australia overall there was a fall of over 10,000 housing starts from 1988-89-a fall of 38 per cent. The bottom line significance of these figures is that the industry knows that it is in a worse situation now than in 1982-83 when Labor rode to power in Western Australia on community anxiety and a depressed housing industry.

Things are a darned sight worse today than they ever could have been back then. People are now seeing the exact results of the Burke leadership in Western Australia, the Dowding leadership in Western Australia and now the Dr Lawrence leadership in Western Australia. The events of recent weeks with various trials in Perth have really started to make people wonder about what they actually lived under in those years and the waste of taxpayers' money that has gone on ad nauseam, unchecked and unaccounted for.

Unemployment in the home building industry is often disguised by the fact that many subcontractors are down to a three day week. But the loss of income here is a further component of the Western Australian version of the Keating recession. But has anything been done? No. We just hear `Don't worry about it. Hide the west across the Nullarbor'.

Further hard evidence of the havoc wrought by the Hawke Labor Government in Western Australia appears in the biennial review of the Master Builders Association, which reveals that there has been a 15 per cent decline in the 53,600 construction work force in the year to August. Over the 12 months, 6,600 full time jobs have disappeared in the Western Australian construction industry and unemployment runs at 8.8 per cent. While the jobless have risen by 2,400, the number employed has fallen by 10,000. This points to a more serious consequence of the Keating recession, with the permanent loss of skilled labour storing up industrial inflationary pressure in any revival in the industry.

In September, 133 advertisements for skilled on-site workers represented a further 6 per cent decline since August. In one month, there was a further 6 per cent decline and the lowest level in five years since the monitoring series first began. The demand for starting trades-brick- layers and carpenters-is down to one twentieth the level of 1989. That is just a bit more than what could be called a `seasonal variation'.

I note also that, on top of the problems that lead back to the failure of the Hawke Labor economic management, the review notes that the latest disguised Labor tax, the training guarantee scheme, could impose `some hardship during a period of reduced activity'.

It was only a few months ago that Labor and the Australian Democrats imposed this tax on the business community with the recession clouds looming, showing once more their lack of concern for private enterprise. We raised the concern in that debate that it was looking very likely that we would be going into a recession, and we asked the question, to which we never received an answer, why the Government and the Democrats sought to impose another tax on business at such a crucial time. But, no, the marriage of the Labor Party and the Democrats went ahead and business copped the extra taxes.

It is a sign of the times that one leading Western Australia company, Bunnings Ltd, reports a 39 per cent decline in operating earnings, deferment of a new headquarters, a four-day week, staff cuts of 450 and a 20 per cent reduction in dividend. This is a company in which Western Australians invest for steady income and growth. Had such a firm succumbed to the lure of heavy borrowing it would be in dire straits indeed. It is no thanks to the policies of this Government that this respected local company still keeps its head above water. Again, as a leading timber producer it has suffered from the disinformation propaganda of environmental extremists that this Labor Government has cynically encouraged. I certainly hope that the Government is going down the path of ditching those extremists. It is not that I am not environmentally aware-we in the coalition are very much environmentally aware and our record proves that, dating right back to the Menzies era. But we cannot afford to have Australia conned by a group of extremists in the way in which they have conned the country to date and conned this Government in particular.

While there can be no question that the Western Australian business sector and economy are suffering because of the failure of the economic management of the Federal Labor Government, the State Labor Government, as I say, has also played its part. Of the $425 in extra tax that it is estimated Western Australians will pay this year-a real rise of 1.5 per cent-$336 is the work of the Federal Labor Government and $89 is the work of the State Labor Government. In order to meet the actual expenditure forecasts for 1990-91 of a State Government confronted by its own squandering of public money in WA Inc., another $293 from each Western Australian taxpayer may be necessary. The dishonesty and incompetence of Dr Lawrence's Government will be visited, to a great extent, on a business community that must pay the bulk of taxes and charges. It is no accident that the exemption level for payroll tax- $320,000-is the lowest threshold of any State.

The slump in the housing industry has been intensified because construction by Homeswest is down by 36 per cent, while the State Labor Government indulges in acts of ideological grandstanding in building a handful of units on prime riverfront land in north Fremantle, or paying people out of taxpayers' money to tap phones. That is where the taxpayers' money goes-on little exercises like that. It is absurd that Western Australians are forced to pay $6,500 a month for a private investigator to tap phones. That is just remarkable. Meanwhile, on 14 December, Wills Industries, a clothing firm that supplies 200 jobs and $10m to the local economy, will close down and move to South Australia. Another straw in the wind; another failure for Western Australia; another failure that can be directly attributed to the policies of both the Federal and State Labor governments.

The rural crisis is another major component of the grim economic reality in Western Australia. Of the State's 16,000 broadacre farms, 1,200 could be at very serious risk and all are feeling the effect of falling incomes and constant costs. This year the average farmer is set for a trading loss of $193,000 compared with a $3,000 profit for 1989. Many have less than $20,000 a year with which to support their families, compared with $28,500 in 1988-89. This Government deliberately brings about policies that are not designed to help the rural sector because it believes that it will never get that sector's vote. That is cynicism of it. Because it is the wealthy rural sector the Government wants to put an assets test on it. Yet earnings are now less than $20,000 a year per family. I would like to see some of the Ministers in this place trying to feed their families on $20,000 or less.

An 18 per cent drop in the value of rural production, posting a loss of $1.6 billion for the Western Australian economy and the possible exodus of 5,000 from country towns, shows clearly that the farmers' problem is the State's problem. Even farmers who are free of debt will expect a $30,000 loss this year. I have no intention of standing here and blaming the Government for the fall in world wheat prices, falls in the demand for wool, or for the structure of wool marketing. I do, however, blame Labor economic management, with its high interest rates and the overvalued dollar that results, for adding to the difficulties that the rural sector faces. Interest rates are a very real part of the picture when the average debt for 5,800 wheat farmers stands at $147,000; when average farm costs of $141,000 include a $14,000 interest rate bill; and when it is estimated that farmers require 80 per cent equity to survive the crisis.

It reflects emphatically on the Treasurer's mismanagement when the Director of the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia joins the Western Australia Farmers Federation and the State Minister for Agriculture in calling for a lowering of the value of the dollar. It reflects upon the unreality of the approach of this Labor Government that on 9 October the Prime Minister evidently thought that he could talk the dollar down by stating that he was not happy with its value. It is getting beyond a joke.

This Government is not sufficiently conscious of the fact that every one cent change in the United States-Australian dollar rate means a $170m difference in national farm income. It is typical of this Government's underlying attitude to the rural community that at a time of such grave crisis it is moving to deprive many farming families of the family allowance and the family allowance supplement. Only a Government that was fundamentally uncaring about families that generally do not vote for it could bring in an arbitrary assets test with a $300,000 threshold that the Prime Minister admits was plucked out of the air. While there may be a proper case, there is certainly not a case in these circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are addressing the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1990-91, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91, and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1990-91 and the very important aspects of this year's Budget in relation to the broad community. In the time available to me this evening I will also attempt to look at the Budget in the context of the recent announcements and statements of the Special Premiers Conference and relate those two matters. In the time that will be available to me tomorrow I would like to look very specifically at how the Budget impacts on northern and regional Australia and how the Budget's issues, which have been identified in so many matters during the consideration of the Estimates by this Senate, should also be dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: In turning to the relationship between this year's Federal Budget and the Premiers Conference, I think it will be very important to note that regional and northern Australia will not be fooled by the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the five Labor Premiers have very substantially changed ground at the Premiers Conference. The total economic ineptitude of the present Hawke Labor Government has become so apparent and the profligacy has become so transparent that the Special Premiers Conference of the last couple of weeks has seen that very significant changing of the goalposts by Mr Hawke, Mr Keating and the five Labor Premiers.

It was only through the actions of the New South Wales Premier, Mr Greiner, and the Chief Ministers of the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory that we were able to see that the policy stances taken at the Premiers Conference were consistent and holding to the long term planning and development that they had been advancing for some time.

If we look very carefully at the communique that was issued, we can analyse the areas where it has been acknowledged that there were past inefficiencies. To use the words of the communique, many areas of the economy need to be `competitive and flexible'. Why competitive? Why flexible? If the Hawke Labor Government had in any way had a decent agenda and a decent commitment to economic achievements for the past seven years, we would not now be in the hole or the mess that this country has arrived in.

We have now seen that it is going to be necessary for the Premiers to sit round the table in a number of very special conferences in order to get this whole process changed; and that is going to mean very fundamental changes in the five Labor States. They are the ones that are going to primarily feel the consequences and the winds of change that are going to have to go through not only issues such as their revenue raising capacity, but also the whole basis and undertaking of the way in which the financial relationships are tied up.

The fact that there has been duplication of services between the Federal Government and the State governments, of course, has been very apparent over the past couple of years, but it has now become necessary to become involved in a very fundamental change to the whole principle of federalism. It will also be very interesting to watch and to target the changes that will be necessary at the next Labor national conference, because that is the body that will be indicative if the Australian Labor Party believes it has any hope of holding on to office federally or in any of the five Labor States. I think we are going to see a lot of blood on the floor between now and that national conference next year or whenever the Labor Party has the guts to get down and address some of those particular issues.

It is also important to look at the fundamental areas to which the communique of the Premiers has had to turn attention. Of course, there are the issues relating to regulatory reform, road transport changes, electricity generation and transmission, and the regulation of the financial institutions. These are all areas where the incompetence of the Labor Government has been so obvious, and it has been coming out particularly in the State arenas over the past few years.
Probably the most telling part of the entire communique is this statement:
The most efficient level for delivery will most often be at the State or Local Government level.

This, of course, does have a major impact on regional and northern Australia. In the Northern Territory, with which I am most familiar, that means that there will need to be very important reviews of Commonwealth agencies that still are being run from Canberra rather than transferred more appropriately to a Territory government. I refer to institutions such as the Office of the Supervising Scientist, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service administration of Kakadu and Uluru and, of course, the administration of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act. It has to be acknowledged very seriously that these issues of function must be transferred back to the appropriate legislative body and, of course, that is the Northern Territory Government.

It was very interesting to note an editorial in the Northern Territory News, the premier newspaper of the Northern Territory, on 2 November, when the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia, Senator Bob Collins, took a severe caning from the Northern Territory News over statements that he had made with regard to the Premiers Conference communique that seemed to put him at odds with the Prime Minister. The headline was `NT needs full rights`, and the article brought out very seriously the fact that Senator Collins had walked away from a commitment to pushing the cause of full rights for the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish. It is not the first time Frank Alcourta has been wrong and it certainly will not be the last.

—I think the editorial writers have had a lot to pick up and they have certainly got a lot to catch. I will cover more of those northern Australia issues tomorrow. It is important to recognise that the Northern Territory needs to fall very carefully into many of these areas.

SPEECH.PARA: The communique draws particularly on the controversial issue in the community at the moment-the environment. I was pleased to note a particular statement hidden right down in the fine print. Of course, there is a lot of commitment to necessary changes in the environment, but let me read one particular statement:
They-
the participants in the Premiers Conference-

further agreed that this meeting would provide a good opportunity to identify the scope for establishing a clearer division of responsibilities between the two levels of government in implementing policies and programs for ecologically sustainable development in Australia's resource industries. It would also assist governments in clarifying the practical measures through which they could be implemented.

That commitment to resource development and resource security is one of the most important announcements from that particular conference. The fact that five Labor Premiers, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have acknowledged that in the resource area they have gone off the tracks and that there is a need to reverse and bring things back is going to provide a very clear situation of change-and that, of course, will also highlight the area where the national conference of the Labor Party will probably have the most problems next year.

I suspect that that statement will give a lot of power to the Prime Minister and the Labor Premiers for dramatic changes which, I hope, will be met in a commonsense way at next year's national conference of the Labor Party. If not, the economy of this country cannot meet up to its necessary challenges and change. We need to have that underpinning of resource security and resource development that is so essential to so many areas that are so terribly important.

It will be a test of this Government to come to grips with the challenges-the 101 and more changes-that have been proposed in the Premiers Conference. If the Government does not seek to implement these through its policies and its budgeting, then there will be no change or reversal of the dire straits that the country is currently in.

There is a need to acknowledge that things have been very wrong; that the Labor Party administrations at the Federal level and the State government level have been unduly restrictive and constraining on our economy. The duplication of services has been allowed to blow out and develop into something far worse than anything that we saw in the years of the Whitlam Administration. There has been this emphasis on the environmental assessment with a blinkered view, rather than also recognising and tailoring the resources area that needs to be addressed. The Premiers Conference statement is a most important guideline and an important change. In view of the time and the other constraints on the Senate, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1990OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REFUNDS) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
That these Bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE
AMENDMENT BILL 1990
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Overseas Students Charge Act 1979 to fix the amounts of the charges payable under the Act for the 1991 academic year. The amounts are shown in the Bill.

The charges are payable by overseas students enrolled in Australian education institutions under the subsidised program to which the Act relates. While the charge remains at the same proportion of the cost of a place as in 1989/90, the total revenue for 1990/91, estimated at $42.5 million, will be some $2 million less than the 1989/90 revenue due to the phasing out of the program. There have been no new enrolments since the end of 1989.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REFUNDS) BILL 1990
The purpose of this Bill is two fold.

Firstly, it will facilitate the payment by the Commonwealth of the refund of advance payments paid before 30 June 1990 by overseas students unable to undertake or complete courses of study in Australia. This may be by way of direct payments to the students or through loans to institutions. In cases where institutions close as a result of the tighter entry and stay criteria, the Commonwealth will refund outstanding living allowance payments to eligible overseas students already in Australia and provide limited financial assistance to institutions who offer places to displaced students. The Commonwealth's liability in these circumstances is limited to those students who had enrolled and paid fees on or before 24 August 1990.

Secondly, the Bill will secure the Commonwealth's position in relation to recovery of monies paid out in refunds on behalf of institutions in difficulty by clarifying matters to do with, for example, evidentiary issues and access to documents relevant to assessment and recovery.
The Bill has no direct financial impact but there is an allocation of up to $50 million which will be included in appropriation Acts for the purposes of this Bill.
The export of education services has grown considerably since 1986 when the policy of encouraging institutions in Australia to accept full-fee paying overseas students came into effect.
Those policy changes have mainly focused on overseas students in our public sector institutions.

The Government is satisfied that with respect to public sector institutions, standards are consistently high, current entry and monitoring policies are working soundly, and there has been a significant contribution to export earnings.
However, many of our overseas students are undertaking short courses, mainly in English language, at private sector institutions.

Given that our chief markets for higher education courses are in Asia, prior English language study is necessary for most overseas students enrolling in our tertiary institutions and the ELICOS institutions provide a valuable bridge to tertiary study.

In 1986 there were fewer than 1400 English language students in Australia, and about 500 students in other non-formal, short courses. At 1 June this year, by contrast, there were 23,500 full fee overseas students studying in Australia in short courses provided by private institutions; 19,569 of these were enrolled in English Language Intensive Courses for Overseas Students (ELICOS).
Between 1986 and 1990, the number of ELICOS institutions had mushroomed from 19 to 105, of which about two thirds are privately owned, some apparently by overseas interests.

To fill this rapidly expanding capacity, it is clear that a number of these institutions marketed their courses vigorously, in ways which sometimes threatened the integrity of Australia's immigration program. In short, they concentrated their marketing efforts in certain countries whose nationals represented a high risk with regard to over-staying their visas.

You may be assured that the Government has taken all necessary steps to protect the integrity of Australia's immigration program. Since December 1986, when streamlined processing for student visa applications were introduced, entry arrangements have been under constant review and have been tightened as necessary.

From July 1988, institutions were required to screen students for suitability to undertake their courses, and prospective students were required to pre-pay course fees and in some cases living expenses. Both institutions and students also needed to make declarations that they would meet their respective obligations under the overseas student program. Regrettably, not all institutions, as subsequently became apparent, behaved with probity in relation to monies paid in advance. It is this misconduct that has led to the need for this Bill.

By the middle of 1989, it became clear that further government intervention in the program would be needed, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs had already identified China as a high risk country in terms of students overstaying with visas. Institutions were, nevertheless, recruiting heavily there and by June 1989 there was a backlog of some 26,000 student visa applications in Beijing.

In August, following the events of 4 June in Tiananmen Square, the Australian Government decided to temporarily suspend further recruitment of Chinese students. It also required those who had already applied to meet stricter entry criteria relating to age, previous level of educational attainment, and the relevance of intended course of study to future employment.

In the meantime, a further 12,000 student applications had been received in China, adding to the backlog. In large part, this was due to some institutions simply ignoring directions by the Australian Government to suspend recruitment temporarily.

In January 1990, recruitment in China was allowed to recommence. However, rigorous new visa requirements were instituted, which were designed to establish that any applicant was indeed a bona fide student coming to Australia principally for the purpose of study.

Pre-visa assessment now ensures that only those students who have a high probability of approval are asked to commit themselves financially. Institutions are now not permitted to collect fees in advance from individual students until pre-visa assessment has been completed.

The accumulation of requests from rejected applicants for refunds of pre-paid monies, coming at the same time as a reduction of the number of new students enrolling in short courses due to the introduction of tightened visa processes, has led to cash flow problems in a number of colleges.

As I indicated earlier, some of these institutions also failed to protect the funds advanced by students. By August this year, the Department of Employment, Education and Training estimated, on figures provided to it by institutions, that of the 17,500 rejected students, mainly Chinese nationals, some 12,000 refunds had been made. This left almost 6,000 students still waiting for the refund of their pre paid fees. The failure of a number of institutions to meet their refund obligation has had severe financial consequences for the rejected applicants. It has obviously damaged the reputation of the industry as a whole, and it has adversely reflected on Australia's commercial reputation.

In view of these considerations-particularly Australia's standing as a reliable trading partner-the Government has undertaken to pay the outstanding refunds to rejected students and pursue recovery action against those institutions who have not repaid the amounts owing.

It has been suggested that the problems of the industry reveal a case of deregulation gone wrong. This represents an essential lack of understanding of the situation. Export of education services is, after all, a new area of economic activity for Australia and has been allowed to establish in an environment of very limited regulation; early on it was thought too much regulation.

In a new industry such as this it is not surprising that there have been problems associated with its establishment. In the light of experience, however, we can now see that the growth has been too fast and that a greater degree of regulation is required.

The Government is concerned to ensure that all institutions providing education services to overseas students meet minimum national standards in terms of the service they provide, their facilities and their financial management.

Accordingly, the Government will be introducing legislation to establish a firm basis for the regulation of the private sector of the industry, in co-operation with the relevant State and Territory authorities.
In spite of the problems, provision of education services to overseas consumers must be recognised as a potentially significant source of foreign exchange earnings for Australia.
Australia is well placed to develop as a centre of international education. Our advantages include:
* Congenial environmental amenity
* English language
* Similar time zone to east Asia
* Relative geographic proximity to Asia
* Facilities for pursuing cultural and religious activities
* Cost competitiveness, in terms of fees and living expenses
We need to be aware, as Ross Garnaut has pointed out, that education of foreign students in Australia does much more than merely provide the economic benefits of an export industry
* It increases the range of courses available to Australians
* It builds interpersonal links that are important to our economic, political and cultural links with the region
* It familiarises young Australians with the regional environment.

As a nation we cannot afford to squander long term opportunities by xenophobic reactions to initial, short term problems. The export of education services is, and will remain, of great importance, both to our economic performance and to our framework of foreign relations, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to the Senate.
