DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that on some interpretations my position was misrepresented by Senator Tate during Question Time, and rather than leave any doubt I wish at the moment to clarify the position. Senator Tate, I think in the spirit of good fun, was referring to my contribution at the Liberal Party Federal Council meeting recently held in Brisbane, and in particular a speech I gave in support of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the Liberal Party supports that Convention in principle but has several reservations. I want to take this opportunity simply to put the position correctly on the record so that anyone who may have misinterpreted what Senator Tate said can be put right. As I said, the Opposition parties recognise the work of the international community over the past 10 years in drafting a convention to set minimum standards of protection which should be afforded to children. We recognise that in particular there has been abuse of children in wars, in employment and in prostitution. These matters, together with others, have been dealt with in the Convention. We believe that steps taken to end these abuses should be applauded.

There are many other provisions of the Convention which are clearly worthy of support; for example, those that declare the rights of children to protection from physical or mental violence, exploitation and abuse; exploitation in child labour; drug abuse; sexual exploitation and abuse; and abduction and exploitation.

These and many other provisions of the Convention would be supported by all responsible people. Concern has, however, been expressed that some of the articles of the Convention as they are presently drafted do not recognise the rights and responsibilities of parents towards their children and may diminish the parent-child relationship. First, the Convention declares that children have the right to freedom of expression, a right described as including:
. . . freedom to seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kinds, regardless of frontiers, either orally, in writing or in print . . .

The coalition parties are of the view that the expression of this right does not acknowledge the right and duty of parents to provide guidance to children on information they should receive in their formative years. That right and duty should be expressly stated in the Convention.

Secondly, the Convention declares the right of freedom of association and freedom of peaceful assembly. Again, this right is expressed in the Convention in such a way that it does not acknowledge the right and duty of parents to supervise the associations that their children keep. That responsibility should be expressly stated in the Convention.

Thirdly, the Convention does not give adequate recognition to the rights and duties of parents with respect to the education as well as the physical, social and moral development of their children. Of course, earlier United Nations documents contain very clear statements of parents' rights and responsibilities with respect to the children's education and upbringing. Those rights and responsibilities were expressly stated in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, the Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and they should be contained in the present Convention.

The Convention provides that the parties may make reservations on the Covenant at the time of ratification. The Opposition believes that on ratification reservations should be made expressing the concerns I have outlined. Appropriate reservations should reinforce the spirit behind Article 5 and the preamble to the Convention, which recognise the importance of parental responsibilities. In the application of the Convention to Australia, the attitude of State governments will be vital, as most of the relevant laws are State laws. We understand that the Australian Government, although it has signed the Convention, has not yet made a decision on ratification.

It is our view that the Australian Government in ratifying the Convention should make the reservations of the nature I have mentioned in my short contribution. Certainly, if it is not ratified by the time the Opposition returns to government, it would be our intention to issue such reservations upon completion of consultations with State and Territory governments.

It was interesting to note that Senator Tate in answer to a subsequent question seemed to indicate that the Australian Government was now coming around to the position that the Opposition has been advocating. It seemed from his answer that upon ratification the Australia Government is now likely to express reservations of the kind I have mentioned this evening. If that is the case, we are pleased that the Government has recognised the importance of the rights and responsibilities of parents in this issue and will make it clear to the international community in the form of reservations. If we come to government and the Government has in fact ratified the Convention without reservations, we will seek to take action by what means are available to us to amend the Convention consistent with the sentiment that we would have included in reservations had that option been open to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably an appropriate time for me to make this speech, coming as it does, because of the rules of the Senate, midway through a speech by my colleague, the shadow Minister for regional development and northern Australia, Senator Tambling, on aspects of the Budget as they affect northern Australia and regional development. It is probably fortuitous and coincidental that Senator Collins, who is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia, is also present in the chamber.
—It may be coincidental; it is certainly not fortuitous.
—Well, I think it is fortuitous.
—I was just expressing my view in response. I just do not want to be here when the chamber adjourns.

—I am sorry to hear that because it is a fairly non-political matter that I would have hoped Senator Collins might be interested in as the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia. It is something that I was going to mention to Senator Collins quite often during this speech in seeking his support for it. It is something that I hope Senator Collins, as Minister responsible for northern Australia, would have a deep interest in. Senator Collins has an office in Townsville; he swans around in Townsville telling people how concerned he is and now he is saying he is glad he is going to leave here.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to talk about the extension of the Townsville Airport. It is very important for northern Australia in both a commercial way and a defence way. In terms of defence it is important in both a direct and an indirect way; that is, by expanding the infrastructure, the population and development in northern Australia, because that is really the best form of defence one could have for regions such as northern Australia, which are the front line of our defence.

I want to take this opportunity to ask the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) and the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia (Senator Collins) to take up with Cabinet this proposal to extend the runway at the Townsville Airport. Townsville Airport is a joint facility controlled by the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) and the Department of Defence. The Air Force owns the airport while the FAC administers landing charges and property rentals associated with the non-military activity at the airport.

But the Townsville Airport does not have the operational capacity and capability, either in length or strength, to allow unrestricted operational use of the most common aircraft used by international carriers. Almost every international commercial aircraft operating is presently unable to use the Townsville runway to land and take off with a full payload. That is an astonishing situation when one considers that the international airport at Townsville has been operational for almost a decade now.

The inadequate runway has been one of the greatest hindrances to the development not just of tourism but of the commercial aspects of the City of Townsville and the region it serves. While Cairns has prospered with the benefits of a pro-development city council and a privately owned airport, Townsville has gone nowhere with the exact opposite-that is, an anti-development and short-sighted city council, complemented by a publicly owned airport.

The city has lost countless tourism and development opportunities due to the lack of international flights, whilst local export industries find themselves having to send international cargoes by road either to Cairns or to Brisbane to air freight them out of the north. In addition to the commercial disadvantages now faced by the Townsville community because of the runway, the operations of the Air Force headquarters at Townsville are presently significantly limited by the runway. It is of some concern that many of the larger aircraft used for military transport in times of emergency would be unable to take off from the Townsville Airport with full loads. I am advised that the operations of FA18s would also be restricted by the inability of refuelling aircraft to take off from the Townsville Airport with full payloads and refuel mid-air.

There is no doubt that the larger military aircraft used by the Americans, which in the event of an emergency should be using bases in Townsville if the threat came from the north, would be restricted in the use they could make of one of the northern operational defence bases to support our defence operations. It is a fact that some of our own aircraft would be incapable of operating to a full capacity from Townsville. Townsville is the headquarters of Australia's operational deployment force, and that is the force which is supposed to be ready to move in the event of an emergency. It combines different elements of the defence forces and it must be restricted by the fact that it cannot use the Townsville Air Force base in a fully loaded way because the airport runway is too short and not strong enough. Many honourable senators will be aware that the Department of Defence has allocated $100m to build a bare base 26 kilometres east of Weipa on Cape York to be known as Scherger base.

Support for the Scherger base is very strong on both sides of this chamber and although the coalition has raised some concerns about whether the base would be better situated on the east coast of Cape York, combining the operations with the runway operations for the Cape York space base, nevertheless, I am completely in favour of the construction of Scherger base and so is the Liberal Party. But I recognise that Cape York is an area of vulnerability in our defence capability until Scherger is completed.

I understand that the Cape York area is the only region not serviced by an adequate runway to permit continuous operations by high performance military aircraft. I understand that, as far as the Department of Defence is concerned, this is one of the most important bases yet to be completed because it gives that cover over the top of Australia. It seems extraordinary that the Government is about to spend $100m on a 3,050 metre runway in Cape York which will be used for only a couple of weeks a year except in an emergency when the headquarters of the Australian Defence Force in Townsville has a runway of only 2,600 metres which could have major shortcomings in the event of a serious threat to northern Australia.

I know that the Townsville Thuringowa Development Board was considering asking the Government to postpone the construction of Scherger base by a year or so, in the hope that some of the money allocated to Scherger could be reallocated in the first year to the extension of the Townsville runway. Maybe the Department of Defence would not accept any reallocation of funds that have not already been allocated for Scherger considering that the ADF headquarters at Townsville is considered as fulfilling all present requirements with the existing runway. But the Air Force has told the Townsville Thuringowa Development Board that it would support any proposal to lengthen the runway short of providing its own funds to do so and that it would, in reality, welcome the upgrading of the runway. The Air Force, of course, is reluctant to spend its own money on the extension of the Townsville Airport because it, like all of the other defence forces in Australia at the present time, has been severely restricted by this Government's penny-pinching and mean attitude to adequate defence allocations.

My intention tonight is not to ask Cabinet to fund the Townsville runway extension for defence reasons alone, although defence is a very compelling reason. There are a number of other reasons that it should look at for the funding of the extensions. I want to touch upon a few of the commercial imperatives which would justify an extension of the Townsville Airport. The weight restrictions imposed on the airport make it difficult for the 12 or so overseas carriers with landing rights in Townsville to use it. It has become so difficult that many of them have given up trying. The weight restrictions imposed mean that carriers are in a position where they cannot bring in and take out a full load of paying passengers. Consequently, the profitability of bringing aircraft into Townsville falls into some doubt. It is also my understanding that the bilateral airline agreement and regulations between Australia and other countries are strict regulations which deny newcomers the flexibility of flying into one Australian port and out of another. I am advised that carriers would need to forgo some of the incoming seats they provide on established routes in order to take up services to places such as Townsville.

This situation seems ridiculous to me, given that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) has made a commitment to a more liberal aviation environment, referring in particular to overseas airlines. Extending the runway would overcome one obstacle for incoming carriers, but the true opening up of the Australian skies, which my colleague Mr Jull has advocated for some time, needs to happen as well to develop the airline industry and the tourist industry in northern Australia.

There is without doubt a tremendous tourist attraction through the Townsville region. Townsville is the sunshine capital of Australia. It has more days of sunshine than any other centre in Australia. It provides international tourists with a unique opportunity to enjoy the Barrier Reef, rainforests, historical outback towns like Charters Towers and Ravenswood, along with the highlights of Townsville itself, including the casino. I mention Magnetic Island in particular which is the only coastal tropical island in Australia that is developed as a suburb of a major city. It is an island where people can live, at a very reasonable cost, in a delightful setting. It is where tourists can go at a reasonable cost and enjoy all the facilities of a tropical resort.

Recent Qantas delegations to South East Asia have met with great response. There is an upsurge of interest in tourism into that area and the new service which Qantas has initiated between Townsville and Singapore direct has been booked out until well after Christmas and this shows an enormous interest in tourism to this part of the world. Unfortunately, the aircraft that Qantas can use on the Townsville-Singapore direct route are smaller aircraft-they are 767 Boeings-and even these cannot be fully laden because the runway at Townsville Airport is too short and not strong enough to allow fully loaded aircraft to take off. Apart from these tourist reasons, there are other commercial reasons for extending the runway and I have mentioned that the city is disadvantaged because of the limitations on air freight services out of Townsville.

Much of the produce produced in northern Australia and north Queensland is in great demand overseas but a lot of it is of a very perishable nature, which means it has to be got out of northern Australia very quickly and into its point of destination. There is a great demand for prawns which are gathered in north Queensland and northern Australian waters. These go to Japan, but they have to be alive when they arrive in Japan. They cannot be frozen. They are the best prawns because the Japanese are prepared to pay for them, but they have to get there quickly and in a live state. That means that cargo freight from north Australia has to be upgraded. Certainly in the Townsville region, where a lot of these prawns would be exported from, the capacity is needed for additional air freight.

The mango industry, which is of particular significance in the north and an export trade which is flourishing, needs a regular and viable cargo service out of the Townsville region because Townsville would be the port for Bowen, and the Burdekin and Ingham areas, which produce a great majority of the mangoes for export. But unfortunately because of the runway strength, these exports cannot be loaded as often as should be, or in the capacity that is necessary on existing commercial international flights because of the runway limitations.

The third commercial reason for extending the runway is something which I know Senator Collins is very familiar with, that is, the likelihood that Townsville may be used as a maintenance base for international aircraft. It is well known that worldwide there is a shortage of maintenance facilities and maintenance staff. Airlines all over the world are increasing their fleets. They are keeping older aircraft flying longer and all of this has meant a very great increase in the maintenance facilities and maintenance staff needed. I am told that there is such a shortage that Qantas is having to maintain some of its aircraft overseas, even in Ireland, which would at times make one wonder.

Townsville is ideally situated for the location of a maintenance facility and maintenance staff. It is on the Pacific Rim. There is an enormous number of aircraft flying across the Pacific, into South East Asia and through New Guinea and Indonesia, and Townsville would be an ideal location for that facility. It has the international aircraft, it has large areas of land close to the runway and it has plenty of nearby real estate which is owned by the Federal Airports Corporation and the Queensland Government.

The Townsville Thuringowa Development Board first promoted this idea and, together with the regional projects investments program, is now working to attract a maintenance facility to Townsville. Already it has received positive expressions of interest from a number of companies, including a Hong Kong air freight operator, which is interested in coming to Townsville to establish a maintenance base, but it is reluctant to do it unless it can be sure that the Townsville base will be used by all manner of international airlines, and that it will be sufficient and capable of bringing in the aircraft it wants to service.
Now Minister Collins has given this pledge to the people of Townsville-and I am sure he will remember this and will support it again and again-as follows:
Townsville's airport runway would be extended if proposed aircraft maintenance facilities are established here.
This was an absolute commitment, and I know it is one that Senator Collins will abide by and will push.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will.

—I know he will. I make that comment without any reservations. I am somewhat sad that the proposal that would have allowed a maintenance base there earlier this year was sent by the Government to New Zealand, and I think it has fallen flat over there at this particular time. Nevertheless, if a maintenance base can come, Senator Collins will certainly be to the fore in getting that airport extended and strengthened. I ask that Senator Collins might even take that action now and try to get the Cabinet to do it because it is really the chicken and egg approach-should it be extended first or should the maintenance base be established there first? The maintenance base people who are looking at it are a bit reluctant to come in until they can be sure the airport runway will be extended.

SPEECH.PARA: I trust Senator Collins and I know that he is a man of his word and that he will do what he says. But maybe the people who are looking at establishing a facility there do not know Senator Collins as well as I do, and maybe they do not trust his word as much as I do. So maybe the runway should be extended first and then these maintenance people would have no doubt of the viability of Townsville as a base for that operation.

I know that this is a great opportunity for the Government to show some real commitment to northern Australia with bipartisan support at all levels of government. The Queensland Premier, Wayne Goss, has signalled his intention to develop Townsville as a commercial and industrial capital, and I have no doubt that he would support the extension of this runway. The Queensland Tourism Minister is also strongly supportive of the Townsville tourist potential and has expressed the desire to have more international flights into the city.

The federal member for Herbert, Mr Lindsay, is strongly in favour of upgrading for the reasons that I have just canvassed. The Labor Party State members, Mr Davies and Mr Smith, have expressed their support publicly, and even the ALP Mayor of Townsville, Alderman Mooney, has recognised that the extension of the runway would put in place one of the key elements for the city's development. I know that the Liberal and National parties do support that, and I guess that even the Australian Democrats would be in favour of something that would develop Townsville as a major regional centre in north Queensland.

I hope that Senator Collins will take on board the things that I have been saying. A lot of it is not new to him and he has heard it from people before, but it is something that constantly needs pushing. It is something that has to be kept to the fore, and it is something that I hope Senator Collins would take before Cabinet. It may give him and his Cabinet colleagues something positive to think about rather than the distress I am sure they suffer every time they go to a meeting and see the dreadful state that the economy is in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was with you right until you said that, Senator.

—But this will give him something to look forward to. It will give the Cabinet a bit of an uplift, something a bit positive and something it can do that can be assured of advancing Australia and not taking it along with as many of the other decisions that the Government has taken. But here is one where, with bipartisan support, maybe we can get that facility organised and operating. I know that Senator Collins, as I do, would very much like to see Townsville prosper, and this is certainly one way of doing it. I could suggest to Senator Collins-and this may be important to him and his colleagues because they probably need it-that he would get far more political points by succeeding with this airport than I ever will by raising it here this evening. But I do not mind about that, because if there is anything I can do to have even a minor part in removing perhaps Townsville's weightiest handicap, then that is satisfying enough for me.

SPEECH.PARA: I do hope that Senator Collins and the Government may give some consideration to this matter and keep it firmly to the fore of the projects that they are considering so that the Townsville airport can be expanded. It has enormous commercial relevance, and it also has a very significant defence relevance as well. For all of those reasons, I would certainly hope that some work can be commenced and some positive statements made in the not too distant future on the extension of the runway for Townsville airport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I say at the outset that it was not my intention originally to speak in the adjournment debate tonight, and as I understand the custom of the Senate on a Wednesday evening I will confine myself to a few brief remarks on some issues raised earlier this afternoon. Unfortunately, when matters related to the National Crime Authority (NCA) were raised in the Senate earlier this afternoon I was at a meeting on the Middle East, and there was insufficient time for me to respond and join the debate at the time. I must say also that the politics of the Middle East are perhaps more refined than some of the tactics of certain members of the Opposition on the NCA Committee. However there is little time and only a brief opportunity tonight to make a contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: As has now been established in the Senate, there has been a wilful misrepresentation of the Government's position on the National Crime Authority Committee by some honourable senators opposite. In particular, there has been a concerted attempt to destroy the effectiveness of a committee of this Parliament. That is especially and peculiarly destructive where the committee concerned involves the oversight of the National Crime Authority.

It may be of interest to the Senate to know that on Monday the NCA Committee went to Melbourne for public hearings on evaluation, and one or two extraordinary things occurred. These things occurred as a direct consequence of the malice demonstrated by some in the Opposition as to the Committee's workings. Unfortunately, that malice appears to be born of a frustration and obvious incapacity to grasp the real issues of law enforcement. It also appears to be born of a political perspective that chases tangents rather than endeavouring to concentrate on primary issues of substance, and it is born of a provincialism that is staggering in a national parliament.

The Committee on the NCA is chaired by Mr Ted Lindsay, MHR. He is a fine and dedicated individual. From time to time he incurs the ire of some in the Opposition because he simply refuses to be diverted from the responsibilities of the NCA Committee. He refuses to preside over a committee that rushes to judgment and behaves like a circuit court, seeking only to execute people or to annihilate reputations.

I do not resile from anything I said during the adjournment debate a week or so ago on the National Crime Authority and related matters. Nor should I. What I said was the simple truth. There is a clear Opposition strategy to ruin this Committee on the NCA as a functioning body. As far as some in the Opposition are concerned, if that damages the National Crime Authority as an organisation, so be it-that is the price the Opposition is prepared to pay. That is obviously something that the Government rejects out of hand.

I shall make a couple of brief observations about Monday's meeting in Melbourne of the NCA Committee. It is appalling to relate this but I think the Senate is entitled to know. It was not possible to have on the record a briefing for the Committee from Justice Phillips and his colleagues in the NCA. Hansard was excluded from the Committee meeting. It was excluded because Government Committee members believed-I think rightly-that the security of the briefing could not be guaranteed. That is certainly not a reflection on Hansard. Government members did not want to read the briefing in the Adelaide suburban newspapers the next day, and some of the Opposition members on the Committee believe that a headline in a suburban throwaway is of more importance and more significance than the integrity of the Committee, the objectives of the NCA or the obligations of the Parliament.

As well as that, the Chairman warned all the witnesses-including Mr Frank Costigan, QC-that no guarantee of confidentiality could be given. That is hardly surprising given what happened in the Senate the other night with the tabling of in camera evidence that had been given to the Committee. That action is probably the most irresponsible and most derelict behaviour that I have seen in 20 years of politics, State and Federal. I might add that in endeavouring to do his job as Chairman, Mr Lindsay confronts a difficult task. Some in the Opposition have set out to make that impossible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. If an honourable senator is to make a personal attack on other honourable senators, it has been customary in this place to tell them. I am wondering whether Senator Loosley has advised those on the Committee, who he is obviously attacking in a very personal way, whether he intended to do so during this debate.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—I was invited to speak in the chamber on this matter by someone opposite.
—After the attack on your credibility in the chamber this afternoon.
—Precisely. I am merely responding.
—They can dish it out but they cannot take it.

—It is always the case with the Tory party. Some in the Opposition have clearly set out to make Mr Lindsay's job impossible. It is staggering that witnesses before the Committee on the National Crime Authority cannot be given any assurance of privacy, let alone confidentiality. When Mr Lindsay makes the valid political point that this is intolerable, he is abused for it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee on the NCA now acts on the premise and on the basis well founded in fact that anything taken in camera will probably end up being the property of the Senate and the public property of all who care to listen, observe or read. For the Committee on the NCA to be obliged to work in that way is intolerable. I wonder how long it will be before commonsense, indeed sanity, prevails in the Opposition's ranks. On most other parliamentary committees that may not matter; it would simply make its deliberations very difficult. But on the NCA Committee it makes life intolerable.

Let me reaffirm what I said the other night for the benefit of those honourable senators who may not be aware of the situation we face on the Committee on the National Crime Authority. Senator Collins also made reference to this point at the close of the debate. Members and senators who serve on the National Crime Authority are not supposed to leave material with their staff. We are obliged to handle this material personally-the material is that sensitive. Moreover, special safes are provided in our offices for security. The extraordinary thing is that that begs the question: If some in the Opposition have no respect for the processes which afford confidentiality and table in camera evidence, why on earth should anyone be provided with these special safes?

The reality is that material which comes before the Committee on the NCA is of extraordinary confidentiality and sensitivity. Although I am relatively new to the Committee, that is a conclusion which I drew at a very early time. It is not overstating the case before the Senate tonight to say that if people breach the confidentiality of the Committee on the NCA, they could put people's lives at risk. Unfortunately, that does not seem to have struck everyone in the Opposition; the contrary seems to be the case.

Opportunities are now sought to engage in public wrangling over what should be matters of calm deliberation. That form of politics is negative. It is a form of political myopia which ought not to intrude into this chamber. That form of politics achieves absolutely nothing. It is representative of an incapacity to approach important matters rationally, with some degree of reason and commonsense. No-one in the Government wants to see the NCA Committee behave in a partisan way; the opposite happens to be true. There has been such unrelenting antagonism and aggression on the Committee, apparent in the behaviour of the Opposition, that there is no choice for it but to be left to the Government, hopefully with the support and contribution of Senator Spindler, to ensure that the Committee works effectively and well.

Earlier today someone asked how does someone reach a conclusion. Unless someone behaves in the manner of some in the Opposition-best described as feckless-the short answer is that we arrive at a conclusion based on a reasoned assessment of the evidence. That is what the NCA Committee report, which was debated earlier today, sought to do. No amount of obfuscation from some opposite can get away from that. As I said earlier, the behaviour of some in the Opposition on the Committee on the NCA has left no-one in the Government in any doubt whatsoever that the attitude is: wreck the Committee and erode the value of its recommendations. That is not behaviour that lends any dignity to the Senate, and it is not behaviour that should be tolerated by any parties represented in this chamber.

I conclude by saying this: as long as I have been alive I have detested bullies, and have detested them passionately. This is a classic case where the tactics of intimidation have to be met with utter resolution. The tactics of the political threat should always be resisted. If there are one or two members of the Opposition who hope that these tactics will succeed, I can tell them on behalf of the Government members of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority that they will fail. Every time those tactics are tried, they will meet with an uncompromising response. This is one situation where, for the Opposition, ignorance will not prove to be bliss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that, because Senator Loosley basks in the ignorance from which he clearly comes, I was not notified of his intention to speak this evening.
—Why should you have been?
— Senator Collins, do not join him in that ignorance.
—How much notice did he get? What about the 30 minutes of disgraceful performance that you turned in on the adjournment in the last sitting week?
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne.
— Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—He could not string two words together.
— Senator Collins, on the adjournment on the last occasion you accused me of being affected by alcohol. By implication that was a disgraceful allegation.
—I did not. In fact, Bolkus did.
—By innuendo, so did you, Senator Collins, if I may address him through you, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—But do you know why he did? The reason he did so was because you were as drunk as a skunk.

—He is quite wrong. The truth is that there is nobody more obese, more unattractive and more tempting to attack in terms of his presentation, but we resist because we know that it is bad taste, bad manners and bad for the chamber.
—You were as drunk as a skunk.
—I was not.
—Order! I ask Senator Collins to withdraw.
—I withdraw the assertion that Senator Crichton-Browne was as drunk as a skunk.

— Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I did not hear the vast majority of that which was said by Senator Loosley. It used to be the case, in the tranquillity of this chamber, that when a senator intended to make observations about another senator or to reflect adversely on another senator the senator concerned would be advised accordingly. It is not in the Standing Orders. It is just intrinsic good manners that one either is born with or one learns or one just never attracts.

SPEECH.PARA: The two or three matters that I did hear Senator Loosley raise I found somewhat unsettling. At the meeting in Melbourne, to the extent that the procedures and proceedings of a private meeting are to be canvassed in this chamber, part of the agenda was what I understood to be a formal meeting-an agenda presumably agreed to by all members of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority. It was to be a formal meeting with the National Crime Authority (NCA). Members of the NCA came along to address us. I had to leave the meeting for a moment or two to make a phone call in respect of my travel arrangements, which had been changed. When I returned I was surprised to almost see the process taking place of Hansard being invited to leave the room. We were all informed that the meeting was and had always intended to be not a formal meeting but an informal meeting with the NCA.

I do not know what the understanding of the Chairman is, but the status of the meeting does not change simply because Hansard is not present. However, be that as it may, we had what I thought was a rather futile meeting. On two occasions when questions were put to the Chairman of the NCA, Justice Phillips, he replied-and I thought on the second occasion in a rather sharp way-in response to questions by Government members that he was not interested in becoming involved in or in commenting on matters of difference between members of the Committee. He was not interested in becoming involved in political considerations, which was a very sensible and logical response to what, quite frankly, was an unnecessary and embarrassing question.

At the conclusion of the meeting, before we rose, I asked the Chairman whether I had misunderstood the agenda, whether it was always intended to be of an informal nature or whether it had changed. I was assured by the Chairman that I did have it wrong, that it was always to be an informal meeting, and that that was the understanding of all present. I apologised for not being aware of that, except to say, as I did then, that, had I known that the meeting was to be of that nature, I would have caught an aeroplane to Canberra in the afternoon because I had a public hearing of the Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade dealing with Papua New Guinea.

I find it absolutely disgraceful now to be informed that in an arbitrary way, by a private resolution of the Government members without the knowledge of the rest of the Committee-I understood that committees were made up of members of all political parties but were a committee in the whole, so to speak-they had decided for their own reasons that the meeting would not proceed. I would add that Senator Spindler did not know about it; he was surprised; he was not informed. Therefore, the Government members were aborting a meeting without resolution or determination by the Committee. We are now told that the reason is that the Labor members decided what could be on the Hansard record. That was decided not by the Committee, not by resolution, not by determination of the Committee, but because three members of the Australian Labor Party caucused together to decide what the Committee's tactics would be. Perhaps that more than anything else sums up the Government's attitude towards these committees-and, most of all, this Committee. They see it as part of the Executive Government and an organ of the Labor Party.

As I listened to Senator Loosley when I came into the chamber, it reminded me of all those terrible things that I had heard about the thugs in the right wing of the New South Wales Labor Party, where threats are made and carried out. If my memory of events in New South Wales is correct, people are threatened and told what will be the consequences if their decision is different from the view of the thugs from the Right. If that is where committees are to be for the future, one has to contemplate whether the committee system has any place.

We all know, because it has been no secret, that people such as Senator Robert Ray have given their views very frankly and openly on this matter. Senator Ray has said that he is no great supporter of the committee system, and many others curse the day that Lionel Murphy had the enterprise to set them up, develop them and breathe life into them in the way they now exist. Perhaps this is just another step.

The objection to having the Labor Party on this Committee is that some of the members stick to the Standing Orders, and when we find that a matter before the Committee, such as an inquiry into Operation Ark, is going to be aborted by a short, sharp meeting without proper resolution or determination, and when we conclude that substantial evidence is being denied the Parliament, contrary to section 55 of the National Crime Authority, and we write a report, setting the wrongs right-that includes in camera evidence, which by a normal, reasonable measure by any intelligent and informed person does not include one single paragraph that could not be reasonably put on the public record-that makes us the sinners in our determinations. Labor Party members resented the fact that we exposed what they were trying to cover up. It seems to me that that is how the Labor Party members are proposing to fashion this Committee. In spite of the brutality of their numbers they were unsuccessful and they seek revenge and vengeance.

I have to say that Senator Loosley ought to start to learn his Standing Orders. Perhaps he ought to start to learn the provisions that are available to members of the Committee as individuals or as a minority-not only their rights, but their absolute responsibilities. Being the minority on a committee does not absolve a person from doing that which is right, that which is proper and responsible. The sheer tyranny of numbers is no excuse for those of us who know it is wrong to do nothing on the grounds that we have been rolled. If we believe that the report that has been proposed to be put down by the majority on the Committee is not adequate, satisfactory, responsible, or fulfilling the obligations in the charter under which the Committee was set up in the legislation, then we have a responsibility to do something about it.

I find it interesting that Senator Loosley sets himself up. The new boy who cannot get a thing right, and has not thus far in this place, has some sort of authority on what in camera evidence can be included in minority reports and majority reports and what cannot. What offends his morality? What offends his sensitivity? More importantly, what offends him because he never wanted it exposed in the first place?

I have sat for a short time with Senator Loosley on this Committee and, in my view, on the occasion when we were hearing the most crucial evidence that any committee could reasonably be hearing, Senator Loosley spent most of his time at an Estimates committee. The only time we could ever be certain he would be with us was when it was time to put his hand up to vote with the majority. His prime consideration seems to be to make sure that the numbers are right. Perhaps there is something exquisite about the argument that if we have the numbers we do not have to worry about the logic. Perhaps it is the final arbitrator in politics, perhaps it is the winning point, but that does not make it right or proper and does not make the substance of the resolutions necessarily correct.

As long as I am on the Committee I will do what I believe is proper, as distinct from Senator Loosley. There is no man more dangerous than he who knows he is right and never questions it. Senator Loosley talked about headlines appearing in provincial newspapers and he referred, particularly, to the Adelaide newspaper. There was nothing subtle or clever about that, it was just crude, common politics. If Senator Loosley has something on his mind, rather than crafting some words in his office by the hour so as to be able to say what he intends to say without saying it, but leaving the inference there, he ought to have the courage to come in and say what he intends to say and see whether he can be challenged on his integrity.

I conclude for the moment, until I read the Hansard, by saying that it is my judgment as events unfold that the Government may well maintain the majority on this Committee by relying on the Chairman on every occasion for his casting vote. I suspect that as events unfold and this conduct is revealed that Senator Spindler, for one-I do not know him very well, but in the short time I have seen him on that Committee he has conducted himself with absolute propriety and integrity and, most of all, absolute responsibility-will not succumb to the impost of the Labor Party in seeking to have its way on matters and issues that he knows are not right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add only a few comments to the record in reference to the debate that we have just witnessed. I do not, in any way, want to join in the debate because I am not confident that I know enough about the subject matter that is being debated. I have not partaken in any of the previous debates in this chamber and elsewhere on this subject matter, so for that reason I will not enter the formalised part of the debate on the question of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. However, I want to follow through on the point of order taken by my colleague Senator Reid on a convention that is said to be existing in this chamber. That was also alluded to by Senator Crichton-Browne. I have not been here as long as either of the two named senators and I certainly know of many instances where, if that convention does exist, it certainly has not been followed.

SPEECH.PARA: In making that comment I admit that the culprits are not only on the other side of the chamber, but also on this side of the chamber. If the convention has existed in the past it is perhaps a good convention that ought to be, if possible, reinstituted in this place. It certainly was not reinstituted this afternoon when Senator Vanstone openly and publicly challenged Senator Loosley and said some unkind words about him.

TALK.START.PARA: —She was debating a report.
—She also made--
—He was a member of the Committee and should have been here for that Committee report.

—Yes. We will tap the table, cast that in concrete and have it here, and every honourable senator, irrespective of which side of the Parliament he comes from, will sit in and listen to all the debates on all the committee reports that happen in this place. It just does not happen like that. I know that Senator Tambling has been in this Parliament as long as I have, so he is learning on the way through, as I am. I am trying to be productive in this process. If such a convention has existed in the past, I put it to the chamber that it would probably be worth while looking at it again in the future. Despite the fact that I am on the Government side of the chamber, I know what it is like to be in a minority on a committee. It can sometimes be uncomfortable. If there is a will on behalf of all committee members we can do the best thing for Australia and the people of Australia which, after all, is the reason we are here.

SPEECH.PARA: On the way through we can play political games, but there are times when we get a bit carried away with ourselves and denigrate each other personally and that does not reflect well on the person on the receiving end of that reflection. I noticed a very nasty reflection on Senator Collins in the earlier part of Senator Crichton-Browne's contribution. I was tempted to take a point of order, but Senator Collins is big enough to defend himself. He may not have seen the need to defend himself; he knows that he can dish it out.

I conclude by saying-I had not intended to speak for so long on the matter-that perhaps the convention ought be looked at. I am more than willing on this side of the chamber to use whatever powers are in the temporary office that I hold to try to bring about a reinstitution of the convention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief in responding to the contributions that have been made to the adjournment debate tonight. In respect of Senator Macdonald's comments about Townsville Airport and the extensions, I acknowledge as correct the statements he made about the confirmation that I gave publicly to commitments that have been given by the Federal Airports Corporation that it will consider extending the runway at Townsville Airport if it can be demonstrated that it is commercially viable for it to do so; that is, contingent upon the facilities that are being speculated upon-I place it no stronger than that-in respect of Townsville aircraft maintenance facilities proving to provide the Federal Airports Corporation with a return on the considerable investment that would be required for the extension of the runway.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of Senator Crichton-Browne's contribution, I say this: in the many years that I have been a member of parliament, it has never been my practice to make personal reflections upon other members of parliament in the manner referred to by Senator McKiernan a few moments ago. I take considerable exception to being accused publicly, and therefore having it recorded in Hansard, that I have done so, when I took considerable pains at the time not to do so.

To my total astonishment, this evening Senator Crichton-Browne accused me of accusing him of being drunk when he participated in the adjournment debate when the Senate last considered the matter. And what a long evening it was. As the Senate Hansard clearly shows-I certainly recall the debate only too clearly-it was Senator Nick Bolkus who made that accusation. Perhaps I should not be too hard on Senator Crichton-Browne because there is probably very good reason why his memory is confused as to what happened that evening during the adjournment debate. I would not have accused Senator Crichton-Browne of being as drunk as a skunk during that adjournment debate despite perhaps the intense provocation that 30 minutes of mindless gibberish that he delivered during that debate might have occasioned. Despite the intense provocation that that may have given me to make such an accusation, the reality is that I did not do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did it by interjection tonight.

—I respond to Senator Tambling's mindless interjection by saying that I certainly did, for the simple reason that I was angry enough at being accused of indulging in a piece of parliamentary practice which, as Senator Tambling knows full well, it is not my style to indulge in. I thought that if that is what is going to happen I may as well be guilty of the offence of which to that point in time I had been innocent-the offence that I am being accused of by Senator Crichton-Browne. I did so because it was a very long, tedious and mindless contribution that Senator Crichton-Browne made to the debate. I have no hesitation in saying that. Of course, none of that is unparliamentary. Despite the intense provocation it may have given me, because it was not a particularly edifying performance, I chose deliberately not to do so, because it is not my style. I want to put that on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: I might add that not just the Hansards of this chamber but a set of Hansards that would fill several of these desks from 10 years of parliamentary contributions prior to becoming a member of this Parliament will demonstrate that to be the case. Senator Tambling knows full well that that is so. It is not my style. So I do not particularly like being accused publicly of doing it. I want to correct the record in that sense, with some degree of irritation. Even though, as I say, Senator Crichton-Browne could be forgiven for being confused about the events of that evening, he should consider the Hansard record before he accuses me of making such personal reflections which I did not make at that time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 8.35 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 14 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the hormone stilboestrol which acts to prevent the spread of cancer of the prostate gland been replaced with another; if so, what is the reason.
(2) Has the medical profession said an alternative hormone is not as effective as stilboestrol.
(3) Did the suppliers of stilboestrol refuse to accept a lower price in payment for the drug.
(4) Is surgical castration the only sure way of ensuring cancer of the prostate does not re-occur.
(5) Is stilboestrol still available in New Zealand; if so, why can that country provide the hormone when Australia cannot.
(6) Can Australians travel to New Zealand and obtain the hormone.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Other hormonal therapies used to treat cancer of the prostate continue to be available on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) but should not be seen as replacements to stilboestrol. The other drugs are fosfesterol sodium, leuprorelin acetate and goserelin.

(2) It is understood that some members of the medical profession have expressed the opinion that stilboestrol is more effective than the other drug which is available in oral form, fosfesterol sodium (fosfesterol is stilboestrol diphosphate).

(3) Stilboestrol products were removed from the Schedule of Pharmaceutical Benefits at the request of the manufacturer. The decision by the company to withdraw stilboestrol was based on concerns about the commercial risk associated with its continued manufacture and the consequential inability to obtain liability insurance. An application for a price increase was rejected by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority in January 1988. Part of the increase sought was to cover liability insurance. The manufacturer was not, however, asked to accept a price decrease.

The price was further reviewed in May 1989 by the Pricing Authority with the company being offered a price substantially above its previous list price and the price sought in 1988. Price negotiations were deferred pending a PBS listing application. At that time, the Australian manufacturer proposed to market a 1mg tablet imported from New Zealand. A letter detailing the data needed to support such a proposal was sent by the Department of Community Services and Health to the Australian manufacturer in May 1989. So far, no response has been received.

(4) There is no sure way of ensuring that cancer of the prostate does not recur. However, surgical castration or stilboestrol are regarded by experts as equally effective treatments in the control of prostatic cancer.

(5) A form of stilboestrol tablet is currently available in New Zealand but it remains a matter of company policy whether or not the drug is available in Australia. If a company chooses not to market a drug, there is no way that it can be forced to do so.

(6) There are no legislative restrictions on a person leaving Australia and seeking medical treatment in New Zealand. Alternatively, it is permissible to import for personal use a quantity of stilboestrol to provide three months' treatment at the manufacturer's recommended dose.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 31 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the terms of reference of the Industries Commission's 1990 inquiry into railways and when will the report be available.
(2) What is the amount paid by the states to the bicentennial roads program collected through the Commonwealth levy.
(3) What is the amount paid to the bicentennial and centennial roads program collected through the Commonwealth levy.
(4) What is the amount of fuel excise collected from the railways through excise during 1980-1990.
(5) What amount has the Commonwealth returned to railways through capital works or urban transport programs, etc. during 1980-1990.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Terms of Reference, specified by the Hon. P J Keating, for the Industry Commission Inquiry into Rail Transport are as follows:
(in pursuance of Section 7 of the Industry Commission Act 1988)
1. refer railway systems (including carriage of urban and non-urban passengers and freight) for inquiry and report within fifteen months of the date of receipt of this reference;

2. specify that the Industry Commission report on institutional, regulatory or other arrangements subject to influence of governments in Australia which lead to inefficient resource use, and advise on courses of action to reduce or remove such inefficiencies;

3. without limiting the scope of the reference, request that the Commission give priority to areas where greatest efficiency gains are in prospect, and areas where early action is practicable, having regard to:

(a) the scope for improving the efficiency of rail transport systems including through changed management and work practices, pricing, the removal of structural impediments and the use of, and investment in, new technology;
(b) alternative efficient sources for infrastructure and other capital investments and any efficiencies arising from the adoption of alternative mechanisms for raising loan and/or equity funding;

(c) the potential for joint development as a means of reducing operating expenses and capital costs, including the opportunities to standardise equipment to benefit from the lower costs of mass production;
(d) the identification of efficiencies in the use of energy and land of rail transport compared with road transport;

(e) the benefits and costs of possible changes in regulation of rail transport including its likely effects on industry, roads, road safety, the environment, regional areas and funding requirements of the three levels of Government;
(f) the appropriateness of rates charged by relevant rail authorities for transport of commodities, including the structure of royalties and taxes, and the effect of rail freight charges on industry;
(g) implications for rail transport services and the economy generally of regulations, charges and arrangements affecting competing and complementary modes of transport; and
(h) the effects on users and non-users of improved efficiency of passenger rail systems (particularly in cities) and of freight rail systems;
4. specify that the Commission is to have regard to the established economic, social and environmental objectives of governments; and
5. specify that the Commission is to avoid duplication of recent substantive studies undertaken elsewhere.
The Commission is to report by 21 August 1991.

(2) The Australian Bicentennial Road Development (ABRD) Program was established to provide financial assistance to the States and the Northern Territory for expenditure on upgrading Australian roads for the celebration of the Bicentenary in 1988 and included provision for urban public transport projects. It was a six year program funded by a surcharge on motor spirit (petrol) and diesel fuel, over and above excise paid by motorists and other users not eligible for rebates. A one cent per litre surcharge applied from 17 August 1982 until 30 June 1983 and a two cents per litre charge applied from 1 July 1983 to 31 December 1988. ABRD Program surcharge receipts, net of rebates, refunds and remissions are set out in Table 1, below.

The Australian Land Transport (ALT) Program commenced on 1 July 1985. It provided financial assistance to the States and the Northern Territory for expenditure on construction and maintenance of roads, funding of land transport research, road safety activities and for capital improvements to interstate mainline railways. It was funded by a portion of excise on petrol and diesel. Initially 3.66 cents per litre the rate was indexed to movements in the Consumer Price Index. The excise rate was also adjusted downwards on three occasions. ALT Program receipts net of transfers to the Consolidated Revenue Fund are set out at Table 1.

(3) The Australian Centennial Roads Development (ACRD) Program is a five year program which commenced on 1 January 1989 replacing both the ABRD and ALT Programs. It provides assistance to the States and Territories for road upgrading and maintenance including funding for urban public transport and mainland rail projects and land transport research. The ACRD Program is funded by a portion of product excise, designated as a road user charge. Initially 4.95 cents per litre the road user charge is currently 5.931 cents per litre. It is indexed six-monthly to movements in the implicit price deflator for gross non-farm product, with adjustments taking effect from 1 April and 1 October. Receipts to 30 June 1990 are set in Table 1.

(4) Railway excise payments are not separately identified by Australian Customs Service records. However, the InterState Commission has estimated that the rail systems paid $123 million in excise in 1986/87 (``Road Use Charges and Vehicle Registration: A National Scheme-Volume 1'', AGPS, Canberra, 1990 at page 135). It should be noted that prior to 1982 the rail systems were exempt from excise.

(5) There is no hypothecation of excise receipts to railways. However, $231 million was provided directly to the States and to Australian National by the Commonwealth for railways capital expenditure and rail-related urban public transport projects over the period 1980/81-1989/90.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 19 July 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's Department, or any statutory authority or organisation for which the Minister is responsible, employed consultants since July 1986; if so; (a) who has been employed and for what purpose; (b) what work plan was given to them; (c) what was the cost of their services; (d) when did their services commence and finish; and (e) was any fee in excess of the initial quote paid to the consultant; if so, what amount.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, my Department and the Australian War Memorial have engaged consultants since July 1986.

The information to parts (a) and (c) of Senator Newman's question concerning who has been employed, for what purpose and at what cost, for 1986-87, 1987-88 and 1989-90 (and 1988-89 in respect of the Australian War Memorial) copies have been sent to Senator Newman and additional copies are available from the Senate Table Office. The relevant information for 1988-89 is contained in the Department's 1988-89 Annual Report.

In reference to part (b) of the question, the Department's Guidelines and Procedures for the Engagement of Consultants stipulate that the following minimum information be provided to potential consultants:
(a) precise statement of the results required;

(b) sufficient background detail to explain the task to be done, this should identify key `users' (who will own the final product etc.) and may address rationale for approaching the task in a particular way;
(c) the expected tasks for the consultant including requirement for any specific product eg interim/final reports, consultant's role in implementation if any;
(d) a timetable for completing the project, including commencement, milestone and finish dates-any external constraints (eg budgeting timetable) should be highlighted;

(e) the facilities the Department will provide, eg further background information; access to departmental staff; if the project is to be completed on site what sort of accommodation; what supervision will be provided;
(f) the skills and/or knowledge being sought from the consultant; and
(g) a set of criteria upon which the selection of the consultant will be made, including specific skills the consultant must have and reference to any potential or actual conflict of interest.

It should be noted that one of the key factors distinguishing consultants from employees is that consultants are not directed in the way they carry out their work. It is the consultants' responsibility to develop a `work plan'.

In relation to part (d) of the question, the information requested is not maintained in any consolidated form. It would be time consuming and resource intensive to collate the information and I am not prepared to provide this information for the periods requested.
Concerning part (e) of the question, most consultancies commissioned by the department are for a stipulated duration and cost. Fees payable would therefore be those initially quoted.

Cost increases may occur in longer consultancy projects. In these instances cost variations may only be justified in cases where the consultant is requested to undertake different or additional work; an extension of time; or where cost increases beyond the consultant's control can be demonstrated. Under no circumstances would additional fees be paid to consultants who fail to cost the proposal accurately or for additional work undertaken without prior approval.

On this basis, fees in excess of the accepted quote are unlikely to have been paid. To verify this with every consultancy commissioned during the periods nominated would again entail considerable time and resources and therefore, I am not prepared to supply this information.
Note
Consultancies marked with an asterisk (*) relate to staff training/development courses and sessions and were commissioned because-
(a) expertise was not immediately available in-house; or
(b) existing staff development resources were engaged on other projects at the time.
Consultancies marked with a cross-hatch (#) were commissioned by the Australian War Memorial because-
(a) requisite expertise and/or resources were not available in-house; or
(b) a need existed for independent analysis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 23 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) How many proposed aid projects have been reviewed under the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau's (AIDAB's) new Environment Assessment Guidelines since the guidelines were adopted in 1989; (b) how many were categorised as (i) list 1, (ii) list 2, and (iii) list 3; and (c) of the projects classified as `list 2', how many have been approved or are still under consideration.

(2) (a) How many reviews of environmental factors have been undertaken in accordance with the above guidelines; (b) in how many cases did the REFs recommend that the proposed project be rejected or substantially altered; and (c) of the projects which were the subject of REFs, how many, if any, have been approved or are still under consideration.

(3) (a) How many proposed projects have been referred to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) in accordance with the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act or otherwise; (b) in how many cases did DASETT recommend against funding the project; and (c) of the projects which DASETT recommended not be funded or be substantially altered, how many have been approved or are still under consideration.
(4) In total, how many projects have been rejected, abandoned or substantially altered, which, but for the new AIDAB Environmental Assessment Guidelines would have been approved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In the Government Response to the Report on Environmental Impact of Development Assistance by the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, the Government announced that there would be an annual environmental audit of development cooperation activities. This audit will provide detailed answers to the questions raised by Senator Vallentine. In the interim, the following information is provided.
How many proposed aid projects have been reviewed under the AIDAB environmental assessment guidelines since the guidelines were adopted in 1989?

The environmental assessment guidelines became operational in July 1989. Since then, 200 projects have been proposed. Of those, 164 have been reviewed and 115 have been approved. The remainder are still under consideration.
How many projects have been categorised as Lists 1, 2 and 3?

Of the 164 projects reviewed, 90 are List One (activities for which environmental screening is required), 18 are List Two (environmentally related activities) and the remaining 56 are List Three (activities for which screening is not normally required)
How many ``List 2'' projects have been approved, or are still under consideration?
Thirteen ``List 2'' projects have been approved, and 5 are still under consideration.
How many reviews of environmental factors (REFs) have been undertaken in accordance with the above guidelines?

Since the introduction of the environment assessment guidelines, all 164 projects have been subjected to procedures in which environmental factors are considered as an integral element, the remaining 36 are still being processed. Terms of reference for feasibility studies, and design and appraisal missions have emphasised environmental factors. The development of logical frameworks within project design documents, and detailed project implementation documents have incorporated environmental considerations. Current and future sectoral analyses have been tasked to make recommendations on the integration of sustainable development objectives.
In how many cases did the review of environmental factors recommend that the proposed project be rejected or substantially altered?

No project has been rejected due to REF recommendations; however in many cases, individual components of projects or approaches have been altered to accommodate environmental concerns or considerations. A major task of appraisal teams has been to ensure that environmental factors as well as other important cross-cutting issues have been considered fully in project design.
Of the projects which were the subject of REFs, how many, if any, have been approved or are still under consideration?

The screening guidelines contain information relating both to the project conception phase and to subsequent phases in the project cycle. The term ``review of environmental factors'' incorporates both the initial screening and the subsequent environmental management plan and costings.

In all cases where environmental concerns have been identified in project formulation, these concerns have been addressed through alterations of the project's logical framework and design; in no case has a project been rejected on environmental grounds. Those still under consideration are currently at various stages in the project cycle, in which environmental aspects are considered at each stage.

How many proposed projects have been referred to the Department of Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) in accordance with the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act or otherwise?

AIDAB is discussing the content of a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with DASETT which will define the requirements for consultation under the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Since the Government Response to the Senate Committee tabled in Parliament on 16 May 1990, DASETT and AIDAB have engaged in active dialogue on international environmental issues and bilateral development cooperation. Until now, DASETT's input has related mainly to programs, during the routine monthly meetings that have been instituted. Some projects have been referred to DASETT. The more direct input has resulted from the attachment of a DASETT officer to the technical Environment Group of AIDAB. This attachment has enhanced the ability of the two agencies to communicate effectively on development cooperation design and delivery.
In how many cases did DASETT recommend against funding the project?
In no case has DASETT recommended against funding of a project.
Of the projects which DASETT recommended not to be funded or be substantially altered, how many have been approved or are still under consideration?
DASETT has not recommended that any projects be abandoned or substantially altered.
In total, how many projects have been rejected, abandoned or substantially altered, which, but for the new AIDAB environmental assessment guidelines, would have been approved?

AIDAB's environmental assessment guidelines have targeted the next generation of development cooperation activities. By placing the concept of sustainable development at the core of AIDAB's program, significant changes are being introduced. In negotiating with bilateral partners Australia has recorded its wish to engage in environmentally sound activities, and to develop strong relations with the environmental ministries of these countries. AIDAB's overseas posts have been instructed to identify requests which do not conform with the environmental standards that have been laid down. The aim is to ensure that unsuitable activities are rejected at the earliest opportunity. The combination of the guidelines and this new approach is having a significant effect on the choice and content of new projects, particularly on environmental grounds.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the following question, upon notice, on 24 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government asked the Skills and Training Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET) to identify ways in which TAFE's needs for continual updates of equipment and staff in marine technology can be best met; if not, is such a request contemplated in the near future.
(2) Has NBEET identified higher education institutions for special development in marine science and technology; if not, does it intend to do so in the near future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
