ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Country Passenger Rail Service: South Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 24 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's department received a submission from Australian National (AN) in relation to the closure of South Australian country passenger rail services; if so, can the Minister table the submission and when was the submission received by the Minister.
(2) What groups will the Minister consult with before making a decision on the future of those services.

(3) Will the Minister take into consideration just the impact of such closures on AN's balance sheet, or will he consider costs to the community as a whole, such as road maintenance, increased road trauma and an increased burden on health, justice and law enforcement agencies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In 1986, the Government accepted Australian National Railways Commission (AN) advice that it would continue to incur large losses on its passenger operations. While requiring AN to continue to operate these services at that time, the Government was not prepared to write AN a `blank cheque', and set AN a cost recovery target of 60 per cent for these operations. AN was advised that the Government would take its success in meeting this target into account when determining continued financial support for these services.

AN constantly monitors the performance of its passenger operations against this target and advises the Government of progress. In a recent review of passenger operations, AN addressed the implications of continuing particular poorly performing services such as the SA country passenger services. It is AN's assessment that it cannot meet the established cost recovery target while these services continue.
Answers to the specific questions are:

(1) The Hon Bob Brown, MP, Minister for Land Transport, has received three letters or submissions from the Chairman of the Australian National Railways Commission on this matter. These were received in the Minister's office on 19 September, 21 December 1989 and 2 January 1990. I do not propose to table these documents.

(2) The Minister has consulted local authorities representing the communities affected over the future of these services. On 9 October 1990, he convened a meeting in Canberra which was attended by the Mayors of Mount Gambier, Port Augusta, Whyalla and Broken Hill, and the Deputy Mayor of Port Pirie. Officials of the Australian Railways Union and the Barrier Industrial Council also attended.
Should the Government decide to proceed with closure, the Minister would consult the South Australian Minister of Transport.

(3) The Minister will take into account all relevant factors. The Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics has completed a study of AN Passenger Services, which will be released shortly. This study forms part of the basis for consideration of this matter and the Terms of Reference for the study included consideration of `the financial, economic and social benefits of closure or continued operation of AN's passenger services'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the decision to have the Department of Defence pay import duty, will the department be employing a private customs agent or will Department of Defence staff be undertaking these duties.
(2) Has any estimate been made of the size of the additional staff allocation needed by the department to administer this tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Defence intends using the services of the Department of Administrative Services Transport and Storage Group to arrange the customs clearance of goods imported directly by Defence.

(2) The initial estimate of additional staff allocation required to administer the payment of Customs duty is nil. However, a redirection of staff effort from within existing resources has been necessary in most elements of the Department and the Services involved in the process. It may be necessary to review staff requirements once the administrative systems for payment of Customs duty are in place.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 11 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of a recent article in The Australian which claims Australia's beef exports to Japan had been `overestimated and would be slashed'.
(2) How much beef, if any, is grown in feedlot properties on Australian soil by the Japanese.
(3) How much beef is Australia expected to export to Japan in 1990.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of recent media reports indicating that prospects in the Japanese beef market may not be as bright as previously indicated, including the article referred to in the honourable senator's question.

A high level of stocks of beef and low wholesale prices, coupled with high retail prices, is creating a general uncertainty in the Japanese beef market. However structural change in the Japanese beef market in this period prior to liberalisation is to be expected and no doubt further uncertainty will be present in the market until things settle down after liberalisation.

A consultant's report recently released by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation and the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation noted the prospect of an initial decline in Japanese imports of beef after liberalisation and that the current high level of beef stocks would need to be disposed of before market forces would determine the level of appropriate imports. The level of Japanese beef stocks is expected to run down considerably during 1991, and consequently decrease its influence upon Japanese beef import demand. Despite this initial uncertainty liberalisation of the Japanese beef market does offer considerable benefits for the Australian beef industry in the longer term. I remain confident that Japan will continue to meet its commitment under bilateral agreements, to import a total of 394,000 tonnes of beef in JFY 1990.

(2) The Australian feedlot industry currently supplies approximately 16 per cent of all cattle slaughtered in Australia. The current annual turnoff from feedlots is approximately 800,000 head of cattle. Japanese ownership or partial ownership of feedlot facilities is currently estimated to account for 10 per cent of cattle turned off feedlots.

(3) On current trade patterns, it is estimated that Australia will export 200,000 tonnes of beef to Japan in 1990. Exports of beef to Japan for the eight months to end of August totalled 124,031 tonnes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 18 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why was it considered necessary for Janet Strickland and Associates to conduct a review of the Telecom 0055 Service.
(2) How many complaints about the 0055 Service had been received from the public in the 12 months to May 1990.
(3) What is the budgeted cost of the review of the 0055 Service.

(4) Has the consultant been directed to use the Film Censorship Guidelines where applicable; if so, has the management of Telecom taken into account public controversy regarding the adequacy of these guidelines.
(5) Does this review contain any reference to the content control of future viewer-paid satellite television programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from Telecom:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The review being conducted by Janet Strickland and Associates is part of an independent review into the message content and advertising standards of the 0055 telephone information service. This review was commissioned by Telecom in February 1990 in response to concerns voiced by the public and 0055 service providers.

Telecom Australia set standards in these areas when it introduced the service in mid 1988. However, Telecom has found from practical experience that it is not necessarily well equipped to judge what standards should be appropriate, having regard for community expectation in these areas, nor is it necessarily well equipped to judge whether individual messages or advertising are in breach of the standards.

Accordingly, Telecom has engaged a consultant to advise on the most appropriate process for setting, administering and enforcing 0055 message and advertising standards (not to determine what the actual standards should be). Janet Strickland and Associates were commissioned in view of the extensive experience of Mrs Janet Strickland in areas which bear a close relationship to this, namely film, broadcasting and television.
(2) Between the period 5 April 1989 and 4 May 1990, 68 complaints were received by Telecom's Product Group responsible for the management of the 0055 service.
(3) Telecom has indicated that this is a matter of commercial confidentiality between Telecom and Janet Strickland and Associates.

(4) Telecom asked the consultant to have regard for general community expectations and requirements using, where appropriate, established benchmarks such as film censorship guidelines, broadcasting guidelines, advertising industry standards and self-regulatory guidelines developed in other related industries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 20 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: What does the Government propose to do to support Australian wheat farmers competing in international markets in the face of subsidies by the European Community and the United States of approximately $A60 per tonne, on a selling price of $A135 per tonne, in sales to Tunisia and other West African countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Australian wheat farmers are currently experiencing very difficult marketing conditions. The world wheat price has been declining during 1990 in response to a number of factors including; a forecast record world wheat crop in 1990/91, a decrease in import demand by the major importing countries (China and USSR) and the Middle East crisis.

Although Tunisia and other West African countries are not markets for Australian wheat the intensification of the export subsidy war between the US and EC is of concern to the Government. Not only will it place further downward pressure on the world wheat price but it may also encourage other importing countries to request subsidised sales, which could make it difficult for Australia to compete in these markets.

The Government will not consider entering the subsidy war (it would only represent throwing good money after bad and take the price down further) but will continue to lobby the US and EC over their domestic support and export subsidy policies. These policies encourage production even when world demand is declining which in turn leads to the use of export subsidies to dispose of the surplus production.

In the current GATT Round, Australia as a member of the Cairns Group, is pressing for fundamental reform of agriculture to bring it fully into the GATT and for the substantial reduction of all trade distorting policies (including export subsidies).
On the domestic side the introduction last year of new marketing arrangements under the Wheat Marketing Act 1989, will help growers to cope better with the depressed marketing outlook.
They now have a greater choice of marketing options that not only allow them to seek the best return for their wheat but also to minimise off-farm costs.

The Australian Wheat Board (AWB) has also been given greater commercial flexibility and is already offering a number of options such as cash purchases and on-farm storage of pool wheat to assist growers.
The AWB is also able to provide greater flexibility in the timing of payments to growers and the provision of alternative payment arrangements to help growers with their cash-flow situation.

Finally, under the legislation an Aggregate Estimated Net Pool Return (AENPR), determined each season by the Minister, enables the AWB to access guaranteed borrowings up to a set limit of the AENPR to make advance payments to growers. The level of advance payments is determined by the AWB as a percentage of the estimated net pool returns.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 20 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Department of Primary Industries and Energy approved a deal between Queensland Mines and the uranium broker NUKEM involving the purchase by NUKEM of Queensland Mines' stockpile of 6.5 million lbs of U3O8.

(2) Has the department approved an agreement between Queensland Mines and NUKEM involving the purchase by NUKEM of three contracts with Kyushu Electric Power Company, Arizona Public Service Company and Duke Power which included an uncontracted stockpile of 2.5 million lbs of U3O8; if so, can the Minister verify that the 2.5 million lbs which was involved in the sale was actually sold at US$10/lb.
(3) Given that the spot price has now reached the levels of approximately $11.75/lb, did the department act in haste by authorising the sale at $10/lb.
(4) Does the NUKEM contract now mean that the Federal Government has given Australian uranium producers the authority to arrange all future sales on an `on spot' basis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1, 2 &3) The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has approved a contract between Queensland Mines Limited (QML) and Nukem Inc for the sale of QML's stockpile of 6.4 million lbs of uranium oxide concentrate (yellowcake). The contract also involved the assumption by Nukem Inc of some contractual obligations with QML's customers. The pricing terms were in accord with the Government's uranium contract pricing policy. That policy was set out in a press release by the Minister on 4 September 1989. It requires that prices be fair and reasonable and at least comparable to what others are getting in the market. The pricing terms of the contract met these criteria. Details of the terms, however, are regarded as commercial in confidence information.

(4) The QML contract does not alter the Government's uranium contract pricing policy. The policy allows producers to sell at fair market prices. The spot market accounts for only ten to twenty per cent of world sales of uranium. For sound commercial reasons, most transactions continue to take place by way of long term supply contracts.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Council of Trade Unions: Grant

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 15 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What grants has the Minister's department issued to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) during 1990-91.
(2) What grants, if any, does the Minister's department anticipate issuing to the ACTU during the remainder of 1990-91.
(3) What grants were paid by the Minister's department to the ACTU from the period April 1983 to June 1990, inclusive.

(4) For (1), (2) and (3) above, what were the details of the amount of each grant made, or anticipated to be made; the purpose for each of the grants made, or expected to be made; and the date that each of the grants was made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Retirement Benefits Office (RBO) has made one payment of $5,000.
(2) Nil.
(3) Nil.

(4) The amount was a financial contribution to the ACTU-Cameron Walshe Information Campaign on the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme (PSS). That campaign was seen to be closely related to and of some assistance to the objectives of RBO's own information campaign on the PSS. The contribution was made on 31 August 1990.
